name: Presidente. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, Presidents, 'There is nothing more beautiful than distributing happiness to people'.  These are words by Ludwig van Beethoven, made real by his music, by his art. For him, music was the ground where the spirit lives, thinks, invents, dreams and playing it without passion was unforgivable. His music and passion symbolise the ideals of Europe. The ideals of solidarity, peace, freedom and our project in a better world.  On the occasion of the 250th anniversary of Beethoven's birth, I would like to share with you a moment of inspiration. The Ode to Joy of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony was adopted as the official anthem of the European Union and is performed in Parliament at the opening of our every constituent session and on solemn occasions. It's kind of our business card. It will be performed today by the Oxalys Ensemble in Brussels, with arrangements by composer Jago Moons. No more words, here is for everyone the Ode to Joy: United in Diversity. (Standing assembly listens to the recording of the Ode to Joy performed by the Oxalys ensemble)

name: Charles Michel
text: President of the European Council. Mr President, last week's European Council was a memorable one. We sealed the deal on two crucial agreements: the European budget and the Recovery Fund, and the new climate goal for 2030. We worked around the clock. The negotiations were intense, but we took our responsibility. We overcame the obstacles and came together for the good of Europe. In this process all the institutions, including your Assembly, played important roles and helped shape the final outcome.  These agreements represent major steps forward. We have the resources - EUR 1.8 trillion - we have solidified the rule of law with new and effective legislation, and we have agreed to step up our climate goals for 2030.  Let me briefly summarise these decisions. You all know the impasse we faced in recent weeks. Our EUR 1.8 trillion agreement came with conditionality for the protection of our budget. There was a collective decision by all 27 leaders taken last July, but two Member States could not approve the package. We found a way to unblock the situation, and here I want to pay tribute to Chancellor Merkel and her team for their tireless efforts. The adoption of the regulation and the conditionality mechanism is now under way.  Our second major decision was not only a win for Europe, it was also, and it is, a win for our planet. We agreed to reduce our carbon emissions by at least 55% by 2030 and we reaffirmed our goal of carbon neutrality by 2050. This demonstrates our credibility as the global leader in climate action. It was a difficult negotiation. Some Member States needed more safeguards for their businesses and workers, and some Member States have asked to address the possible imbalances of the modernization fund.  For our economies, going green doesn't mean going broke. Quite the opposite. Our climate action will spark economic growth and create jobs and speed up the transformation of our economies and give us a competitive edge. But greater ambition requires greater investment, and this is why we will work to develop common and global standards for green finance. This agreement is the start of a process. The implementation will be agreed later this year.  Dear Members of Parliament, when COVID struck we were taken off guard. It hammered our economies and disrupted our societies, but today Europe is rising to the challenge of COVID. We are recovering and we are getting stronger in four key areas.  First, we vaccinate. The global community has developed vaccines in record time. The EU has played a leading role in this venture and this global success could also be a European success story.  Second, the EU has taken the irreversible decision to collectively borrow, invest and reform - a clear sign of unity and confidence.  Third, we have solidly entered our prosperity and our social transformation into our climate ambition. But prosperity alone is not enough. We must focus more than ever on the individual and the collective well—being of our citizens.  Fourth, our long-term goals. COVID may have dominated 2020, but it will not monopolize our priorities and our vision for the future. Our vision for Europe's place in the world remains crystal clear: less dependence; more influence; a stronger Europe that better contributes to a fairer world.  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are mobilised to face the challenges ahead of us, especially those that will probably mark the year 2021 that is open to us. The first goal we all share: defeating COVID-19. Make 2021 the year when we take control of the virus and where we can really restart a process of recovery and economic transformation. The year, too, when we manage to make progress in terms of Europe's place in the world.  For COVID, of course, it will not be easy to continue cooperation in order to deploy vaccines when they are available and to continue efforts on testing and tracing.  Achieving economic transformation also means ensuring that, as was one of the points of the debate at the eurozone summit, progress can continue to be made for the banking union and the capital markets union in 2021. We have thereby commended the work that has been done recently by the finance ministers. We want to encourage further efforts in 2021 in order to make progress in line with these two objectives, which are extremely important to us, to support the international role of the euro, but also to ensure that economic development in the euro area is consolidated and strengthened, based on the two pillars: the climate pillar and the digital pillar.  And, finally, a long-term, difficult goal, which requires tenacity and commitments to build, day after day, more unity and solidarity at the European level: this ambition to express a stronger position at the international level.  This is the meaning of the debate that was undertaken at the last European Council in October in order to define our short-, medium- and long-term strategy in relation to the Eastern Mediterranean.  This is also the meaning of the debate we had last week and the decision that was taken to take sanctions against Turkey, but also to maintain a more positive capacity for an agenda when Turkey chooses to stop its hostile rhetoric and unilateral actions towards the European Union or Member States of the European Union. This is also the meaning of the debate that has been undertaken between the Member States on the relationship, which we want stronger, with the United States, a great and important ally for the European Union. It was therefore important, it seems to me, to start the work in order to be able to make an offer on possible points of partnership with this great country: certainly the battle to ensure that we can defeat COVID, certainly the commitment to more international cooperation and support to multilateralism, certainly also the issue of international trade and economic development related to it. , but also security and geopolitical issues.  As you can see, this year's last European Council - in principle at least - is an important moment, because it reflects the ambition to take a step forward in making progress on these issues that we hold dear.  I would like to thank you, Mr President, but also the members of your Assembly, for the intense and difficult work that has been carried out, especially in the context of the trilogue, under the responsibility and leadership of the German rotating presidency. I am totally convinced that the points that have been made in recent days are points which are important for the 450 million European citizens.  There is still a lot of work to be done, a lot of challenges ahead of us. We hope that the next few days may lead us to have more clarity also on another major issue: the future relationship with Great Britain. The mandate expressed by the European Council is clear, and it is in this context that our negotiators carry out this work with patience, seriousness and tenacity.  Thank you, in any case, for the cooperation throughout the year 2020. You can count on me personally, but also on the European Council, throughout the next year to continue working with the European Parliament in the service of the European project.

name: Ursula von der Leyen
text: présidente de la Commission. – Monsieur le Président, Mesdames et Messieurs les députés, je voudrais commencer en rendant hommage à Valéry Giscard d’Estaing. Avec son décès, nous avons perdu un président, un patriote et un père fondateur de l’Europe. Né à Coblence, combattant à la libération de Paris, bâtisseur de la paix et de l’amitié, il incarne l’Europe pendant toute sa vie. Il a été à la fois l’artiste, l’architecte et l’artisan de notre démocratie européenne. Et c’est ici, dans cet hémicycle, qu’il nous rappelait en 2002 que l’Europe doit toujours amener au monde et à ses citoyens les – je cite – «trois apports fondamentaux de la raison, de l’humanisme et de la liberté». These three words - reason, humanism and freedom - are at the heart of so many of the historic decisions we have taken in this year quite unlike any other. With tomorrow’s vote on Next Generation EU, you are writing history.  It is worth just pausing for a moment and looking at the big picture here. I say that, because Next Generation EU can lead to the most ambitious overhaul of the European economy in decades. It will drive our green and jobs recovery, it will be investing in everything from renewables to renovations, to restoring our nature, it will speed up our Digital Decade by financing faster internet, safer infrastructure and newer technologies, it will make our economies more resilient, driving forward reforms, and, crucially, it will provide massive and quick investment where it is needed and to those who need it. It will give citizens, workers and business real support and real hope after the pain of the pandemic and the lockdowns. Well, this is Europe getting back on its feet and moving forward together and I want to thank this House for working with us to make this a reality.  Honourable Members, I also count on your support to finalise negotiations on sectoral programmes and the Recovery and Resilience Facility as soon as possible. I know you will be just as ambitious and determined as you were when you were securing crucial extra funds for research, health and external action, when you ensured a clear roadmap for the introduction of new own resources, when you enshrined ambition on climate and biodiversity spending, and when you protected the general conditionality framework.  It is against this background that I’m pleased that the Council has finally endorsed the general conditionality mechanism which you agreed with them.  The conditionality mechanism has not been reopened. This was a red line for me and I know that this was also a red line for you. It is path—breaking that, for the first time, the Union is equipping itself with a mechanism to protect the budget against breaches of the principle of the rule of law, not just individual breaches that have already occurred, but also, and more importantly, systemic or recurrent shortcomings that could in a direct way threaten the budget and the EU financial interests in the future. The Council conclusions ultimately do not change anything about the conditionality mechanism, neither in the law nor in its application.  Let me address some of the understandable concerns that these conclusions have raised in this House. In essence, as I understand it, there is a fear that the application of the regulation will be delayed and that justice delayed might be justice denied. This will not happen. The regulation will apply from 1 January 2021 onwards and any breach that occurs from that day onwards will be covered.  I can assure you that the Commission will always act in full autonomy, full respect of the law and full objectivity. We will start the necessary work of monitoring immediately. When concerns arise, discussions with Member States will also commence without undue delay. We will adopt guidelines on the regulation, as we were planning in any event, and these guidelines do not of course change the law. They just set out how we will make our role in implementing it. It is only natural that, if there is a court case on the underlying law, we take the European Court of Justice judgment into account in finalising the guidelines. Crucially, any case occurring after 1 January 2021 will be addressed; no case will be lost. Finally, I am sure that the Parliament will stand with the Commission in defending the regulation if it comes to a court case and ask for an expedited procedure.  I started by talking about how Europe is moving forward with reason, humanity and freedom, and nowhere is this clearer than when it comes to the future of our planet. The decision by leaders to back the Commission’s proposal for a 2030 emission reduction target of at least 55% was based on science and on reason. It was based on protecting humanity and on ensuring freedom for future generations. With this argument and this agreement we set ourselves on the path towards climate neutrality by 2050 and we show true leadership.  The good news is that we are far from being alone. Just last week, we saw 70 world leaders stand up at the UN Climate Ambition Summit and another 60 of Europe’s biggest companies stand behind the 2030 target. Building on this momentum, I count on the support of this House to rapidly conclude negotiations on the European Climate Law. This will be the first ever law that will bind a continent to become climate neutral. But let me be clear. Setting the target is the easy part in this difficult endeavour. Delivering on it must start now. It will take a major collective and systemic effort, but it is worth it.  Our Union has taken bigger steps forward this year than it probably did in the decade before and we did this in spite, and in some cases even because, of a fierce global pandemic. But any recovery starts with overcoming this virus and nobody should think that we are out of the woods yet. Not when more than 3 000 Europeans die of COVID—19 every single day or when infections and hospitalisations are still going up in some Member States. But there is finally some good news. We have agency and we have hope. This is the message I passed to the leaders at the European Council. The Commission has negotiated the broadest portfolio of vaccine candidates and finally, within a week, the first vaccine will be authorised so that vaccinations can start immediately and more will follow in the new year. In total we have bought more than enough doses for everyone in Europe and we will be able to support our neighbours and our partners around the world through COVAX so that no one is left behind. But to get to the end of the pandemic we will need up to 70% of the population to be vaccinated. This is a huge task, a big task. So let’s start as soon as possible with the vaccination together, as 27, with the start on the same day. As we’ve gone in unity through this pandemic, let’s start the eradication of this horrible virus together and united. Allow me to end with a brief update on the unfinished business of this year. This is our future partnership with the United Kingdom. As I speak, our teams are working to try to reach an agreement. They are working day and night, sometimes against all odds, and I want to pay tribute to all of them and I want to thank, in particular, our chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, for his dedication and resilience. As things stand, I cannot tell you whether there will be a deal or not, but I can tell you that there is a path to an agreement now. The path may be very narrow, but it is there and it is therefore our responsibility to continue trying. The good news is that we have found a way forward on most issues, but this is now a case of us being so close and yet being so far away from each other because two issues are still outstanding. You know them: the level playing field and the fisheries.  First, on the level playing field, our aim is simply to ensure fair competition on our own market. Very simple. And this is why we need to establish robust mechanisms. The architecture we are working on rests on two pillars, state aid and standards. On state aid, we have made progress based on common principles, guarantees of domestic enforcement and the possibility to autonomously remedy the situation where needed. On standards, we have agreed a strong mechanism of non—regression. That’s a big step forward. This is to ensure that our common high labour, social and environmental standards will not be undercut. And of course difficulties still remain on the question of how to really future—proof fair competition, but I’m also glad to report that issues linked to governance are by now largely being resolved. On fisheries, the discussion is still very difficult. We do not question the UK’s sovereignty over its own waters, but we ask for predictability and stability for our fishermen and our fisherwomen. In all honesty, it sometimes feels that we will not be able to resolve this question, but we must continue to try to find a solution. It is the only responsible and right course of action.  The next days are going to be decisive. I know I have said this before and I know deadlines have been missed time and again. The clock puts us all in a very difficult situation, not least this Parliament, and its right to exercise democratic scrutiny and ratification. That is why I want to sincerely thank you for your support and your understanding. I know that, if we do get there, I can count on you to ensure a good outcome. As in the past, we must all walk these last miles in the same shoes.  Thank you so much and long live Europe.  (Applause)

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President of Parliament, Mr President of the European Council, Madam President of the Commission, honourable Members, I would like to thank the President of the European Parliament for his excellent work and for his excellent work. When the budget negotiations began in 2018 with a proposal from the European Commission, the world was, Europe was still very different. We are currently experiencing one of the most serious health crises, with hundreds of thousands of deaths in Europe, millions of people infected and sick, and we do not yet know where all this will lead. Nobody knows. But the citizens of a united Europe already know one thing: that we have learned from the crises of recent years. This time, together and in solidarity, we are leaving this crisis. We don't leave anyone alone. That was the focus of the German EU Presidency, and I would also like to take this opportunity today – also on behalf of the Federal Chancellor, also on behalf of my colleagues in the government – to thank you all. I know that the institutional fabric in the European Union is very difficult and that there is always some competition between the Council and Parliament. But we need trust, and I had the impression that there was and there was a close bond of trust between the European Parliament and the Council, because we all knew equally about responsibility. Dispute was necessary in substance. We have tried to build bridges, to forge compromises with regard to the multiannual financial framework, but it is also an attitude. And you all know that there is a great dispute that has divided Europe for years, and that is the question of the rule of law. I would like to say very clearly that your clear position is important, because we cannot simply set this conflict aside, but because we have to resolve it – constructively – in order to regain a common understanding of what holds us together in Europe, because we are not just an internal market and not just a monetary community, but above all a community of values and the rule of law. Your clear stance has also encouraged us to continue along this path and, in the end, to forge a compromise – and President-in-Office of the Council Charles Michel has pointed out the difficulties of this negotiation – which could ultimately be supported by 27 Member States. And that is not self-evident, but it is necessary! And I am defending this compromise because, on the one hand, it has not changed a single word on what we have negotiated with you, and on the other hand it also opens up the opportunity for peace. The European Court of Justice will send out a signal as to whether what we have negotiated is in conformity with the Treaty, and perhaps then there will be an opportunity for those who are constantly talking about lack of conformity and saying that individual institutions want to be attacked here, that they are interfering too deeply with national cultures, national identities, national traditions, perhaps this will give rise to the opportunity – by a decision of the European Court of Justice – that we come back together and that we come back to a common understanding of who we are, and that values no longer divide us. That is why it was also important for us to agree on another instrument in the Council, also in close cooperation with the European Commission, which for the first time presented a report on the rule of law, namely a dialogue on the rule of law, a check on the rule of law, to which all the Member States of the European Union must undergo the same. We have made a promise: together and in solidarity from this crisis. We are not leaving anyone alone, and we have promised that the money will arrive as quickly as possible where it is most needed: the people who are sick; in the regions so badly affected by the pandemic; in the economic sectors. And we can, I hope at least, keep our word. The money will be available very quickly from next year. And that is important that we mitigate the economic and social consequences of this pandemic as best we can, with a large reconstruction programme of EUR 750 billion. But it is not reconstruction, honourable Members! It is the building of a new future, because we invest in climate protection, because we invest in digitalization. Because we encourage people, because we want to strengthen social cohesion. This is also reflected in the budget, in the multiannual financial framework. And we have made a mark on this with Mr Van Overtveldt and with the negotiating team – to whom I would like to express my sincere thanks, because it has always been a matter of substance, of a substantive orientation. There is something in the EU budget, in the multiannual financial framework, that is unlikely to exist in any national budget of the European Union – and I say this as a representative of the European Union. Council , namely that we are tying 30% of the budget, the multiannual financial framework, to climate protection. That we make gender equality a guiding principle of this multiannual financial framework. That we ensure that women and men are equally affected by the expenditure. That we are putting in place own resources, which have been the subject of controversy in the Member States for many years, where there is no consensus. We have achieved something here so that Europe can be put on a new footing. And I think that this is an infinitely important sign at this difficult time, when democracy is under pressure worldwide and where authoritarianism is growing, that we are making it clear that liberal democracies can be crisis! We can protect people from terrorism, from health risks, from the injustices of this world, from other threats. And here Europe has set standards, above all, in terms of climate protection, and this could only work because the three institutions worked together in a contentious manner. Europe is made of courage. We have all shown this courage. I thank you from the heart for this, and I hope that you will be able to give the following Portuguese Presidency the confidence you have given us, because we still have a lot of work to do. And I wish you all the best for your work, so that Europe becomes better, more sovereign, more united and stronger.

name: Manfred Weber
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, EUR 1.8 trillion, a lot of money is now on our table and the European Parliament as the budget authority of the European Union has a huge responsibility. We all know it’s not about figures, it’s about content. What does this proposal now mean? EUR 1.8 trillion means first of all — solidarity. Europe is in a deep recession, in a health crisis, and with this approach, we show that together we can overcome this. Nowhere else in the world are 27 countries combining their strengths and their forces to overcome the crisis. Even the rich countries understood that they can recover only if we do it together.  EUR 1.8 trillion means a clear commitment to the young generation. No second lost generation. This money creates a future; this creates new products, new services, and new markets. Jobs jobs jobs. EUR 1.8 trillion means protecting our environment, creating a digital Europe. We are the front-runner in implementing the Paris Agreement. Yes, but now we are providing the necessary means, the necessary money.  Yes we lost the first wave of the digital revolution, but we are committed to winning the second one, about industrial data. EUR 1.8 trillion means certainty for the final beneficiaries of the EU money in the MFF, the mayors in rural areas, the farmers that can count on us in a globalised world, the researchers — yes go for innovation — we now have the money for you and for the students in Erasmus. Please look how beautiful Europe is. EUR 1.8 trillion means more money for a strong Europe, on a European level. The big deficit of the outcome in July and the Council conclusions on the MFF was that this was dominated by national egoism and we added again the European added value, and it was about Erasmus, when it was about research, when it was about Frontex, and about the health money. In the middle of the corona crisis the Council had cut the expenditures in the fight for a health union dramatically and we, as Parliament, we healed this. EUR 1.8 trillion means for us also, fairness towards the young generation, because if you borrow money, you have to tell people the truth about how to pay it back, and that’s why the decision on own resources is so fundamental — to be honest.  This EUR 1.8 trillion is then finally also linked to an historic achievement. To link for the first time money to the basic principles we believe in: the rule of law mechanism. It was a red line for us in the European Parliament, that we will not allow the trilogue outcome to be changed and this red line is now respected. For me and for my group, this is a game changer. In the last 20, 30 years we saw the process of strengthening the rule of law in the European Union, especially with the enlargement process and then we saw a process of weakening the rule of law in today’s European Union. This mechanism is now again a strong base for defending this rule of law. The last days gave us proof that the Plan B, to link the money to the rule of law, really works, because the COVID 25 consideration was then a powerful tool to create a readiness to find a conclusion on the Council side. We now need an independent Commission that is ready to use the new tool from the first day on and I thank Ursula, the Commission President, for the clear commitment in this regard. This mechanism is not against the country. This mechanism is in favour of Europe. I also want to underline that with this new mechanism, we now have a fact-based and an independent assessment. Not let me say a party political one. In the future, the European Parliament will no longer play a role in this process and it’s up to the Commission, and then finally up to the courts to decide on these things. I think that is important. If we want to have credibility for the process we need a fact-based assessment and independent activity from the Commission. So, Madam Commission President, if you use the new tool independently, I think that is the best service you can do to defend the European way of life in tomorrow’s world.  This agreement is a compromise and Charles Michel was referring to this. It’s not about winners and losers in today’s European Union. I am happy that we have the agreement now on the table, but I also respect other considerations, other views on the subject on the table and they have to be accepted. ‘Europe’ is that we all can live with an outcome. Again the message is that the red lines from the European Parliament were respected, but all countries are on board and that is good. I finally want to thank, first of all, Ursula von der Leyen, for the innovative idea of the Next Generation EU fund based on the Lisbon Treaty, for the Plan B consideration — EU commitment to defend the rule of law. I want to thank the German Presidency especially Angela Merkel, in my group colleagues called her the mother of compromises, I think that is a great title for her, I thank her for this. I thank our NEGO team, all colleagues who contributed to this big outcome, to this great success. The European Parliament showed that we are the parliament of the citizens. We defend their interests, that they can count on their parliament and the European People’s Party may tomorrow support all related dossiers.  Let’s now start to implement it.

name: Iratxe García Pérez
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have had a very special year. I'm sure no one would have imagined the situation that all European citizenship has had to go through. The COVID pandemic found us unprepared and forced us to reinvent ourselves, to be able to continue working and to deal with this crisis more intelligently, and that intelligent way is to be united. I want to believe that citizens have been aware of the work and effort the European Union has made to be useful in their lives and to solve problems. It has been a year of intense, and sometimes difficult, work for distance and confinement. Now all that effort pays off. And I would like to thank the German Presidency for its efforts to close the most important issues. It's been frantic weeks to close agreements and end trilogs. With motherhood and shared fatherhood, many Members have worked for hours and hours together with the German Presidency, together with the Commission, to achieve what we are going to be able to determine between all of us today. This Parliament has always been open to cooperation and work, also intensely, and to fulfill what was our responsibility. And we will do the same if an agreement finally comes along with regard to future relations with the UK. As I say, a frantic year that we are prepared to assume whenever we can fulfil our obligation for the good of Europe and for the good of the public. I would therefore like to vindicate the role of Parliament. Over the past few months, the main political groups have remained united in pushing the Commission and the Council, and we have achieved unprecedented achievements, historic achievements. For example, a Union budget for the next seven years which for the first time we have managed to increase by more than EUR 16 billion compared to the initial proposal by the Council. We have achieved a legislative mechanism linking the budget with the rule of law. That makes us stronger as Europeans, because it makes our values stronger. We have taken another important step: the European Union has in October made its first issuance of bonds, putting more than EUR 17 billion into circulation in social bonds. And there will be more debt issuance to fund the European Recovery Fund. This is a major step forward in the Union's economic soundness. We have learned a lot from the 2008 crisis: that austerity cannot be the answer, that we cannot set aside those who need us most. It's not about cutting, it's about investing. Because we are investing in the future, in a more sustainable future, that takes into account the need to protect the planet. We are pleased that the Council has accepted the reduction of 55% of emissions by 2030, but we need more ambition if we really want to achieve neutrality, and I remind you that this Parliament has adopted 60% of the reduction in emissions. But we are also laying the foundations for a Europe that is betting on people, with social investment, with a democratic digital strategy that reduces inequalities and does not increase them. And the same is online teaching, which must be the same for everyone and for everyone. I am sure that we are aware of the difficulties that many families have faced during this stage of confinement when they could not cope with the situation of online teaching because they did not have computers, because they did not have internet to be able to do so that their children had equal access to education. This is also Europe, we also have to move forward on this. And we've done everything without having to give up our values. I have insisted many times: we cannot be made to choose between economic recovery, values and the rule of law, because then we will be losing the essence of what the European Union really entails. It cannot be yielded in fundamental values. President Von der Leyen said so, and she deserves our trust, President. The Commission shall be guarantor of the Treaties and not a single case of violation of the rule of law which occurs from 1 January shall be lost. We must be proud, colleagues, of the work we have done in this Parliament. A year ago, Mrs Von der Leyen and her European Commission were president, and we couldn't imagine what was going to happen. It was a roller coaster, and we arrived at the end of 2020 with sadness and concern because many families will not be able to gather at these parties and others will also be remembering those they have lost. We must be aware of so many workers who also face these parties with the uncertainty of their jobs; of so many entrepreneurs, freelancers, small businesses, who have the uncertainty right now of what's going to happen from now on. We know that prudence needs to be maintained, but we can be optimistic about 2021. We have a vaccination strategy that will facilitate democratic, equal and fair access to all people living in the European Union and opens a horizon of hope and recovery in the coming months. All this is true, but we must also escape complacency, we must continue. We can't speed up the pace only when we're hit by a crisis and then have to improvise. In these months we have seen that our Union has shortcomings: now we know, let us continue to work. The Resilience and Resilience Mechanism needs to be approved. The Socialists and Democrats have been calling for a rate of financial transactions for years, and there are possibilities: we have ideas, only political will is lacking in order to succeed them. Because the fundamental question is why are we here, if not to change people's lives and to be on the side of those who need it most. We have already seen that the single market works and we have taken great care of it. All this is fine, but Jacques Delors had been warning for three decades that there can be no single market without the counterweight of a social Europe. That is why we now have six months ahead of us which we cannot waste on Portugal's leadership in the Presidency on the Council's shift. It is a great opportunity to give impetus to this social reform, social Europe, the Europe of rights. And I also hope that we will finally be able to finish the negotiations and begin the Conference on the Future of Europe precisely to listen, to listen to the public and to be able to continue to transform this Europe on which we want to work.

name: Dacian Cioloş
text: au nom du groupe Renew. – Monsieur le Président, 2020 a été une année à part, dont il sera difficile de retenir autre chose que la pandémie. Elle a mis à rude épreuve nos systèmes de santé, nos systèmes sociaux, politiques et économiques. Et il faut le dire et le reconnaître: au début de l’année, la crise a montré les faiblesses du système européen et du projet européen, notamment avec le manque de coordination face à la première vague. On se souvient encore de la fermeture désordonnée des frontières. Mais cette année a aussi montré la capacité de rebond et a donné de réelles perspectives pour approfondir notre Union. Le travail de coordination pour la recherche et l’achat de vaccins en est un exemple, de même que le plan de relance qui vient de renforcer le budget pluriannuel. Nous allons reconstruire, mais aussi transformer autour de priorités véritablement européennes, comme le numérique et le pacte vert. Non seulement nous avons travaillé pour réagir à la crise, mais avec ces paquets de mesures, nous prenons aussi des décisions qui vont durablement marquer le projet européen. Je pense en particulier aux nouvelles ressources propres et à la conditionnalité liée à l’état de droit. Cela prouve que, sous la pression de réalités difficiles, nous pouvons progresser en Europe. But before adopting these measures, I want to tell you, Madam President, that both myself and my group listened carefully to your words and I welcome your statement that law prevails over political declaration, because the European Commission must fully respect the treaties. Indeed, its primary function is to do just that and apply the text as decided by co—legislators as soon as it enters into force and without any further constraint. This is extremely important for my group. We are very happy that we have this rule of law mechanism, it should be enforced at the beginning of the year, and in full, as the text provides. I would also like to point out that most of these measures were born here in this hemicycle and that they were able to see the light of day because we were able to build a solid majority to carry them through to the end. I would like to thank my colleagues. We have proved that Parliament can be united when it comes to reinforcing the European Union. This is something that we have to keep in mind, because the work is not finished yet –far from it.  Over and above the many legislative dossiers that are in the pipeline, we must make Europe more responsive. Its decisions must be faster and clearer, and to do that we should use the opportunity of the Conference on the Future of Europe that we have been pushing for since the beginning of this mandate.  This crisis has shown us the structural problem caused by the question of unanimity in the Council, which blocks a lot of important decisions concerning the European Union. This is not about not giving each Member State the possibility to be part of a decision. But if the objective of some Member States is only to block decisions without any strong arguments, then this is not the way to develop Europe.  So let’s not be afraid to debate this and find the right solution. Above all, let us never forget that Europe is most effective when it is united, determined and puts its citizens at the heart of its decisions and ambitions. (Applause)

name: Marco Zanni
text: On behalf of the ID Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I seem to notice a certain euphoria among colleagues in this House about an ambiguous agreement, which came after months of exhausting negotiations and political positions that have shown the rifts and contradictions between the European institutions. The majority resolution that we are about to vote on today is, in my view, contemptuous in tone and dangerous in method, it seems that, for those who live this European dimension as absolute, there is no legitimacy in the body that brings together the Heads of State or Government of the Union – the European Council – which, in my opinion, is precisely the greatest expression of our countries.  Let us not forget that the European Union exists because of the willingness of the Member States to share sovereignty and objectives and that it is the Member States that legitimise the Union and not the other way round. I find it frankly offensive and arrogant that the Council's statements are described as superfluous, as in the resolution, and that we even go so far as to threaten the European Commission and the other institutions if they do not follow the dictates of this Parliament.  I believe that this delirium of omnipotence must be stopped, and that is why – contrary to what Mr Cioloş said – I would like to reaffirm here an indispensable principle, that of the fact that important decisions must be taken unanimously, because this is the only truly democratic method, in my opinion, that protects those who think differently, which allows European democracies to defend themselves against the political and arbitrary use of certain rules.  There is no point in them always defending the rights of minorities in words and in constant resolutions if we then want to impose a dictatorship of one thought and delegitimize those who do not align themselves with it. With today's vote, we have not closed anything, but we are guaranteeing ourselves a future of legal and constitutional uncertainty with an ambiguous role given to the European Court of Justice, always waiting for the hundreds of billions promised, which I fear we will not see until several months.  This muscular test between the institutions, in my opinion, has no winners, but certainly the citizens, our businesses and our territories, who were counting on rapid and concrete support from the Union to emerge from this very serious crisis as soon as possible, will have to be satisfied instead with the adoption of the rule of law regulation, an instrument of political blackmail that has become a top priority for this European majority. , which is celebrating today, the victim of its short-sightedness and political and institutional arrogance, for which we will sooner or later be called to account.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, dear colleagues, it is good to see that, finally, at the 11th hour, the European Council has given its green light so that support for citizens and economies hit hard by the pandemic can finally start. Neither the European citizens and the economies which have been hard hit, nor the climate, could have waited any longer. But while it’s really good that those agreements have been reached, there are quite some worrying trends attached to each of the decisions, and the past weeks have seen a sad show of obstruction by the governments of Hungary and Poland, which have wanted to take the Recovery Fund hostage for their own anti—democratic agenda.  Mr Orbán and Mr Kaczyński, you neither serve your citizens nor our common European future, and in the light of such blackmail we all need to stay and stand strong. And therefore it is really worrying to see the European Council’s attempt to interpret the political agreement and the law agreed by the European Parliament and the Council. That is highly problematic.  Probably even more worrying is the Commission’s role in this affair. The Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, must reaffirm that its intention is to apply the legislation to the latter as agreed by the co—legislators and without any delay, and that also means not waiting for some judgments until some guidelines are drawn up. We have a law  in place. It needs to be applied without delay – that is crucial.  Coupled with the Presidency’s failure to organise a hearing on the Article 7 proceedings on Hungary, this really makes for a poor track record for the European Union in its tackling of systemic democratic regressions in the middle of our common Union.  I want to stress again that the only law agreed is what Parliament and Council as co—legislators have decided previously. Nothing of that law has changed, nothing of that law will change, and it needs to be enforced as of 1 January 2021 for both the current and the upcoming MFF. On Climate Action, I welcome the fact that the governments managed to strengthen the European 2030 emission reduction targets, though a net decrease of at least -55% is still far short of the scientific consensus which is needed (-65%). Parliament has made a strong mandate of a greenhouse gas emission of -60%, which we will continue to fight for in the upcoming weeks and months because, again, the law has been made according to the normal legislative procedure. However, the target agreed by the Council of a 55% reduction is not an absolute but a net target, which is extremely worrying. And yes, of course we must protect and restore land, forests and other ecosystems in our fight to reverse climate change, but this should never be compensation for lessening efforts by the biggest emitters. If the European Union is to be a global leader in fighting climate change, we will need to do more than just come up with some creative calculations.  It’s regrettable that the European Council gave in to pressure from the usual suspects, I have to say, to endorse in its conclusions gas as a transitional fuel, which it is simply not. If we are to overcome the climate crisis, the future has to be completely fossil fuel-free. The exclusion of all fossil fuels from the Just Transition Fund was a clear signal and the European Council should have followed suit. We expect and we need more ambition to tackle the problems at hand and we need fewer double standards from the Heads of State and Government. I hope this will improve in the future and I count on our common normal legal proceedings in order to draw up a good climate law. (Applause)

name: Johan Van Overtveldt
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – As chairman of the Committee on Budgets and head of delegation of the MFK negotiating team, I am very pleased with the agreement we have reached. From that mandate, I, together with colleagues, have consistently and actively defended the consensus within Parliament.  Parliament has succeeded in putting its own emphasis on safeguarding and even strengthening the resources for forward-looking programmes aimed at training, innovation, technological innovation and development. These are the programmes in which the EU can create real added value and make a difference.  However, within the multiannual budget, there are still a number of stalled policy choices that continue to demand attention and resources. As far as I am concerned, the shift towards the future could have been even more pronounced. The EU seems to have a bit of a problem with finding the right level of ambition, and so does climate policy.  Europe can and must pull the cart for sustainable transition. Nevertheless, the new target of 55% CO2 reduction by 2030 raises a number of questions. Take the impact assessment of this 55%. No serious analysis at Member State and sector level is yet available. In my opinion, the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic has also been not sufficiently taken into account, as has the impact on carbon leakage and SMEs.  Moreover, most of these concerns that I have just expressed are also very clearly present in the critical analysis of Parliament's own research centre, the EPRS. I think it would be particularly useful to have a debate on this study.  Furthermore, it must be clear that each region has different opportunities and opportunities to reduce emissions cost-effectively. Flanders, for example, is a small and densely populated region with limited open space and with important energy-intensive industrial clusters. Europe must take this type of diversity into account.

name: Manon Aubry
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, winter has begun, and as Europe prepares to celebrate the end of the year, European leaders have decided to tell us a beautiful Christmas tale. Once upon a time there was a historic multi-year budget and recovery plan that, with a magic wand, would save Europe, put the climate catastrophe on hold, protect human rights and put an end to the crisis. So, as it's almost Christmas, you'd want to believe it. But your fable unfortunately distorts reality and knowingly deceives citizens. A beautiful story that ignores a reality that must be restored.  On democracy, first. You are running as human rights knights protecting Europe from the forces of evil. But while our Parliament had demanded an indispensable mechanism to enforce the rule of law, you gave ground in the face of the blackmail of the extreme right by agreeing to push it back and weaken it. The Little Red Riding Hood was eaten by the wolf Orban. The respite granted to Hungary and Poland will set precedents for all those who embark on the path of an authoritarian drift, such as Macron's France, which organises impunity for police violence and brutally challenges freedoms of religion, association and information with its laws on global security and separatism. On the social crisis, then. Once upon a time, the Three Wise Men, Emmanuel Macron and Angela Merkel, were presently covering the grateful European peoples. But frankly, what disappointment will they have when the gifts open at the foot of the tree? The 16 billion euro hide-and-seek will do nothing: the multi-year budget loses more than 200 billion compared to the demands of our Parliament and even falls well short of the Commission's original proposal. So many new investments less for agriculture, education, research, ecology, health. The recovery plan, on the other hand, is conditional on the implementation of the austere and neo-liberal recommendations of the European Semester. The financial transaction tax, like any initiative to make crisis profiteers pay, is sent to the Greek calendars. In short, the colorful packaging mostly hides poisoned gifts from Father Fouettard.  But the fable doesn't end there. On climate, you tell us about the extraordinary adventure of a European Union at the forefront of a noble quest to save the planet. But your target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 55% by 2030 is already below what Parliament had adopted. Worse, it is also incompatible with the Paris agreements, which scientists say require a target of at least 65%. Not to mention, of course, your accounting hacks to deduce carbon sinks, such as forests, while ignoring the climate footprint of our imports. In short, a beautiful magic trick. On human rights, on the social crisis, on the climate, it was once the European Union dreaming of a heroine, ambitious and progressive, proudly fighting in the camp of the good guys in the face of the wicked. But frankly, no one wants to fall asleep by the European sand merchant with this pretty tale, even at Christmas. And I have a scoop for you: we haven't believed in liberal Santa Claus for a long time. So yes, stop treating us like children.

name: Sabrina Pignedoli (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the 5-Star Movement today says three 'yeses'. Yes to the Recovery Fund, a symbol of a new Europe that bets on the future and makes amends for the mistakes of the past: goodbye austerity. For the first time, European securities are issued and non-lost resources are transferred to the countries most in difficulty.  Yes to the multiannual budget: it is not perfect, but let us increase the appropriations for the Horizon, Erasmus and InvestEU programmes, which are very important for young people and businesses, and the own resources construction site is finally opening up.  Yes to the defence of the rule of law: values are not negotiated, we will always defend the independence of the judiciary and freedom of the press.  With these three convinced 'yeses', we will be changing the lives of European citizens for the better, while the sovereignists are beating the retreat and hiding behind orbán's vetoes, which have no political project at all. However, there is still much to be done. We must prevent the Mafia and organised crime from getting our hands on these European funds and we must restart the economy after the nightmare of the virus. But today it is certain: the Europe of fairness, solidarity and justice wins.

name: Jan Olbrycht
text: Rapporteur. – President of the Commission, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Schwab, Mr President of the European Council, I would like to begin by thanking mr First of all, I would like to emphasise that the debate on the budget package this year is quite different from the normal debate before any financial perspective. At the moment, this debate is about the future of Europe. We can say that the budget debate has started a conference on the future of Europe. We are not just talking about how to save the economy, but also how to help the people. We are talking about what the European Union should look like in the years to come.  We remember that we started this work two years ago, and then Commissioner Oettinger showed us the financial consequences of Brexit. We also counted the financial consequences of the new tasks. And then the European Parliament presented its very ambitious programme, stating that the European Union should maintain its level of ambition despite Brexit, which is why our 2018 proposal was decidedly clear and understandable. We should defend the European Union, and that is why new measures will have to be found.  Then there were 2 years of very difficult discussion and a pandemic that completely changed the situation. The pandemic has led to discussions about a completely different way of financing. Therefore, a smaller budget, because let us remember that the multiannual financial perspective is smaller. We can't hide it. This financial perspective needs to be strengthened by the Reconstruction Fund, and we are counting on this – we hoped at the beginning – that this fund will compensate for some of the constraints from the budget. He did not really compensate in the proposal, and that is why Parliament has fought to increase the budget itself. We have succeeded in this after many difficult conversations. As you know, we have managed to increase by 16 billion the budget for important programmes on the future of Europe, including research, but also on the Health Fund, on Erasmus, also – which is very necessary today – border protection. That's what we've been able to do. That is why we believe that this must be treated as one package: a budget plus a fund. Let us repeat once again: the budget without this fund, however, is too small. We must make this clear, and that is why we very much hope that now the Member States, and precisely the national parliaments, will ratify their own revenue decisions very quickly, because that is what the mobilisation of the future fund depends on. We hope that, following the Council's decision this week, this whole process will start very, really quickly. We need this because we need to treat this package as a whole. The introduction of the package as a whole also – if we can say so – forces a change in the way we are financed, and that is why we will absolutely need a new own revenue package, which Parliament has also worked on, because this loan will indeed have to be repaid, but a new system of financing for the European Union will have to be built for the future. It was not easy, it was not easy either between The Member States in the Council or it was not easy in Parliament. I would like to make it clear here that if, during the negotiations, the Representative of the Council told us that it was difficult to find an agreement between the 27 governments, we said: imagine how difficult it is to find an agreement in Parliament, where there are Members from different countries, with different political options, with different political sensitivities. We succeeded. Parliament is united, at least almost entirely united, and this is our huge victory, and this is important for the future.  I would like to stress very warmly here, first of all, the role played by the entire European Parliament in this whole matter, and I would like to thank the entire negotiating group, which has been working for two years – it has changed, but it has been working for two years. I would like to thank the European Commission very much for this constructive approach, but I would also like to draw attention to the extremely difficult task of the German Presidency. As negotiators, we have seen that this Presidency is still agreeing everything with the other members of the Council. That is why it was not so easy to reach a final compromise. Therefore, if you allow, I would also like to draw attention to the role of the German Presidency.  For us as Parliament, a new period begins – from 1 January we start a new financial perspective. From the first to 1 January, we can guarantee stability and certainty for all those who are waiting for this money, from 1 January we can already start some activities that do not require long preparation and preparation of projects. We can already start work on Erasmus, we can guarantee farmers that the money will flow, we can also talk about the need to start with scientific programmes.  We are very much looking forward to the decision on the Reconstruction Fund. We ask once again – all those who have worked on this process: a quick decision on own revenue is needed, ratification and, ultimately, the establishment of a fund. All citizens of the European Union care about this. I would like to thank my colleagues with whom I have negotiated very much. I would like to thank the heads of all political groups, including my political group in particular, for their political support, because this has been a two-year political process. We worked, but together we achieved good success.

name: Margarida Marques
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Presidents, Minister Roth, the European Parliament is preparing to give its consent to the Plurianul Financial Framework 21/27 at a time when the response to the economic crisis is more necessary than ever. Yes, it was a long and hard job. Because the European Parliament has not dispensed with its ambitions, its political flags. We put first those who elected us, the citizens we represent. We don't betray your interests, your urgencies. We are well aware of the global challenges, the challenges of Europe. From the outhem of people's lives, the protection of jobs, the recovery for a greener, more digital, more social economy.  But also because the agreement at the European Council was slow and difficult. Because some Member States are vocal in their contribution to the EU budget, but they silence what they collect for their membership of the EU, for their membership of the internal market.  Fortunately, the European Commission has released these figures in due course and this has helped in the negotiation.  Because Member States think they are above the law and have made their non-commitment to respect for the rule of law too visible. But by joining the EU, they have taken on respect for European values and therefore respect for the rule of law and fundamental rights. And the European Parliament has not given up its capacity to create the mechanisms that require respect for European values. The European Parliament does not accept that european citizens' money should be used against European values. As we demand transparency in the use of public money and we will do everything against fraud and corruption. We. And this result is a victory for the EP. And it's an EU victory. We succeeded because we were able to mobilise a number of political families, from the outset, in a difficult negotiation process - within our own house, and the EP unit, led by President Sassoli, was decisive (thank you to my co-rapporteur, Jan Olbrycht, and to our teams, the nego-team and the tireless secretariat of the Committee on Budgets) - in a hard negotiation process with the Council, which finally took a safe step in difficult circumstances. We know that the agreement at the European Council was not made in half an hour. And all this because we had a clear mandate and the certainty of the urgency of our ambitions. We succeeded because we have had the European Commission committed to finding the political and technical solutions to embody our proposals. Thank you, Commissioner Hahn and his team also for confirming that the European Commission is the honest brocker in these negotiation processes.  We have managed to maintain the scale of cohesion and CAP policies by paving the way for a new generation of policies that contribute decisively to reaching the objectives we have set ourselves by 2030: a 55% reduction in CO2 emissions; enhancing sectors where the European dimension brings added value such as research, health or the Erasmus programme; support programmes in areas particularly devastated by the crisis, such as culture or rights and values; support investment and give the EU more means to act in the global context by valuing its geostrategic capacity.  But we have also succeeded in introducing new own resources to finance the EU budget - aligned with European political priorities - strengthening the powers of the European Parliament - the debate to be followed on the Interinstitutional Agreement is therefore required - and must respect horizontal principles such as gender equality, the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals, 30% climate spending, 10% biodiversity.   Finally, we have created the necessary conditions for the Multiannual Financial Framework to be the "anchor" of economic and social recovery, the anchor of the Next Generation EU, and at the same time does not compromise the future EU budget, because the FfM will have the consent of the EP - key to creating the Next Generation EU - there is a debt budget line in the EU budget, we are guaranteed that the fund's costs will not be paid at the expense of European policies, we have strengthened the European Parliament's ability to ensure more transparency and democratic accountability in the NEXT GENERATION EU and introduce new own resources for the payment of the Fund, interest and capital. But the MFF would not enter into force (it would not be effective) without the Regulations of the programmes that integrate it, which are fundamental for good democratic and sound management in the use of European public money. And once again, the EP is committed to the timely completion of all these regulations. Thank you very much to all the rapporteurs of the sectoral regulations. Without them the MFF would exist, but citizens, governments at all levels - local, regional and national - businesses, local authorities, schools, research centres, NGOs still did not benefit from European programmes and funds.

name: Esteban González Pons
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Madam President of the Commission, Mr President of the European Council, I would like to begin by thanking my colleagues in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs and the Committee on Budgets, as well as for the work of Parliament's negotiators. There are still obstacles to be resolved, but now it is up to the national parliaments: it is up to them now to do their part. By voting on this Interinstitutional Agreement, Parliament endorses the commitment between the three institutions to provide the next financial framework and the Recovery Plan with necessary legislation to ensure its implementation and proper implementation. A commitment which, I would like to recall, is binding on the three institutions. I would like to briefly highlight some relevant aspects of this report. First, the agreement establishes a roadmap for the introduction of new own resources over the next seven years. This has been a demand of Parliament for a long time and, finally, after more than three decades, we have succeeded. Secondly, these own resources are guaranteed to be sufficient to cover the reimbursement and interest of the recovery instrument, so that we minimize the burden on future generations. Third, greater budgetary control of the financing expenditure of the recovery instrument is ensured. Fourthly, cooperation between the institutions is ensured to ensure Parliament's correct participation as a budgetary authority in the management of external revenue linked to the Next Generation EU, as well as full transparency and visibility of all funds. Fifth, the flexibility of the instruments is improved in order to have full capacity to respond to urgent needs, or unexpected crises such as the present one. Sixth, specific provisions for cooperation between institutions are included for the first time during the negotiation of the budgetary framework. In other words, we do what the Treaties say. And seventhly, within the framework of the Resilience and Resilience Mechanism, we clearly point out the need for an objective, fair and transparent legal framework for the selection of projects to be financed. And I would like to highlight the role that local and regional entities must play in making recovery symmetrical, not only between States, but also between regions. In short, ladies and gentlemen, we are faced with a very good agreement. But an agreement which is not understood if it is not within the compromise and solidarity package, i.e. the multiannual financial framework, the Recovery Plan, the Own Resources Decision and the rule of law mechanism. And I want to talk about this mechanism, I want to make two considerations. First, it is born with the confidence and hope of not being used: it seeks not to punish anyone, but to protect everyone. Second, this mechanism also serves to send a message to the world: the economy is important, but without democracy and the rule of law we are no different from Russia or China. This mechanism of the rule of law is the European differential fact. President Michel, President Von der Leyen, I end by expressing a fear to you. The Recovery Plan will be financed with money to be borrowed by the European Union, but which Member States will spend as if it were part of their own national budget. The Next Generation EU is not going to be spent by the European Commission, nor will the European Parliament control its spending. There is something that does not end up working in this formula: things get complicated when the person who spends the money is a different person from the one who borrows it. The least we can demand is that this money serves more than just funding national programmes without regard to European interests and priorities. We have a common plan, not twenty-seven plans, and we should have a common goal, not twenty-seven objectives. Otherwise, we will have opened the door not to the founding of the European Treasury, but to the decapitalisation of the European project itself. Member States may have found in the Recovery Plan an extraordinary means of financing which does not require them to raise taxes or issue national debt. We may be opening the door to an unwanted return to intergovernmental Europe. Listen to what I say: European debt must finance European policy; European debt must finance the European Union. To finance with European debt Member States is to deconstruct the European project. I hope that this time we are not wrong, that Parliament will have its rightful place and the Commission too, because without Parliament and without Commission there is a common market, but not the European Union.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, President Von der Leyen, Minister Roth, President Michel, it has been two and a half years since we have the proposal for a financial framework and the Regulation on the conditionality of the budget to the rule of law on the table, and we almost did not reach an agreement in time. We have touched the line and, of course, this delay has not been for Parliament, because we have been waiting two years for the Council to start negotiating. Rushing deadlines to the maximum is not good, and I hope that these last months of tension and stress will remain in everyone's retina, so that when we have to deal with the next negotiations, we can do so in optimal conditions.  But in any case, at last, and now I do, I hardly believe it, we have a comprehensive agreement, an agreement which I value very positively and, as far as we are hearing here, the majority of this Parliament too. It is positive because we have managed to negotiate crucial points which were essential conditions for Parliament to adopt this package.  The first thing has been not to take for a closed party, not to take for non-negotiable the Position of the Council in July. This has made us able to improve the budget by EUR 16 billion over the next seven years. This is not just figures: it is money that will go to programmes such as health, Erasmus, research, such as Creative Europe, the cooperation instrument that we managed to close yesterday or humanitarian aid, among others. And here's what's important about budgets: getting the programs funded.  The second thing is to have a calendar of own resources. I said it in a previous plenary session. There are many reasons why this agreement could not succeed without a compromise on how we will finance not only the European budget, but also the Recovery Plan.  It's a matter of tax justice. It cannot be that the usual ones are the ones who keep public policies with their taxes and it is also the usual ones who escape from contributing. It is a matter of efficiency, because the establishment of certain taxes only makes sense at European level, under the umbrella of the single market. It is a matter of climate policy, because those who pollute the most must pay more and thus contribute to the right transition. And I do not want to forget anything important that Parliament managed to negotiate in this financial framework. Finally, another historic demand from Parliament: the money from the fines, or at least one part, imposed by the European Union is going to stay in the budget and allow us to improve the financing of European programmes. And thirdly, a point which we have agreed, which is essential for Parliament, and which as rapporteur I am especially excited about: the mechanism which links budgets to respect for the rule of law. Much has been written and talked about the agreement, the vetoes and the Council statement. On the latter, I will say only one thing: the Council's statement is legally irrelevant. Because when we talk about laws, all that matters is the Rules. And this Regulation contains exactly what Parliament had asked for and what we have fought so hard for. We are a community based on common values and must defend and respect them as citizens and as Member States of the Union. This is not an a la carte Europe, as many would like. In this Europe we cannot be left alone with rights and not with obligations. How have we managed to improve the Commission's proposal? We envisage a broader definition of the scope. Not only do we talk about the rule of law in its strict sense, but we link the rights referred to in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union. We have introduced preventive status into the mechanism, added a list of examples to clarify and even managed to include tax evasion and evasion among the objectives. And something this Parliament was very much about: protecting the final beneficiaries. We wanted a very scrupulous mechanism with control and make sure that it will be those who commit the violation of the rule of law that will be sanctioned and not the final beneficiaries, neither students, nor researchers, nor companies, nor NGOs. That was our goal. And with these modifications we have managed to provide a safety net to these final beneficiaries. In short, the Rule of Law Regulation, which has had a hard time getting ahead of us, is a big step for Europe. In addition, we know that it will be adopted, because no amendment has been tabled and will therefore be taken for approval without even having to go to a vote.  I am not going to go much further, especially given that, in addition, in another of these intensive negotiations we have ended up at six in the morning in the Council, so we have almost had to come straight here because we still have to close the Recovery Plan, but we're on our way. These marathon negotiations are exhausting and often very frustrating. But we always have to try to keep the best, with the positive, when we get that deal. Because in the end this is our task and we have to be very clear about this: to negotiate, agree, build and define with the regulations the Europe that we want to build among all. So, for my part, I just want to thank the whole team, because it has been a very broad team (financial framework, own resources, Rule of Law Regulation and everyone who is now negotiating the Recovery Plan). Of course to the Commission, the Council and all the teams of the Secretariat and our groups, because one person cannot do only this, neither two nor three. This is a joint work, in which, if we have reached a good agreement and if we have achieved something historic for the European Union - and I will not tire of saying that this is historic - it was because this Parliament has worked as a team and we have had good negotiations with the German Presidency and with the help of the European Commission.

name: Petri Sarvamaa
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, we about to achieve something historic today. For the first time in the Union’s history, we will have a functioning rule of law mechanism that does not need unanimity to work. This is a big victory for us, the co—legislators, but even more importantly it is a big and important victory for all European citizens.  We started this process years ago. Some of you might remember from the previous mandate when the Commission published its proposal for this regulation. We in the Parliament processed it fairly fast, but then we got stuck in the mud waiting for the Member States to form their position. Back then, many thought that the original proposal and the Parliament’s mandate were too bold.  Some thought that this legislation would actually never even see the light of day, but we in the European Parliament were vigilant. We really took the dangers posed to the rule of law seriously because we had noticed the deterioration of our values early. Authoritarianism and disrespect for our basic values had already been on the rise in Europe for years. Considering this, it was high time for us to act. It was high time for a change of pace.  However, the Parliament does not of course have the means to stop this sad process alone. We need the Member States to come along in this change, and a majority of them did. A majority of Europeans were clearly backing their governments in this. There was scepticism along the way and I have to say that at times we were worried – some of us more than others – about some of the turns that took place. For example, the European Council conclusions from July gave some room for speculation and even seemed a blow to our ambitious goals.  However, this past October and November presented another turn of events. We had fruitful and serious negotiations with the German Presidency, who managed to bring to the table the Council’s proposal. Extremely quickly, in about four weeks, we managed to reach a deal that respected the original ideas of the Commission proposal as well as Parliament’s mandate and, most importantly, our values enshrined in Article 2 of the Treaty.  I want to thank wholeheartedly everyone involved in this process, my co—rapporteur, Ms Gardiazabal Rubial, Ambassador Clauss from the German Presidency, and our whole European Parliament negotiation team, as well as Commissioner Hahn. I also want specifically to thank the Chair of the EPP Group, Manfred Weber, for his support throughout these difficult negotiations. Now we, as co—legislators, are finally about to adopt this legislation, along with other important budgetary files, Here I want to emphasise the word ‘co—legislators’. The Council and the Parliament are the ones who have adopted this legislation. There has been a lot of a chatter about the European Council conclusions. Let me remind you that the European Council shall not, and does not, exercise legislative functions and therefore any political declaration of the European Council cannot be deemed to represent an interpretation of legislation. Equally importantly, the Treaty is very clear on the role of the Commission. The Commission is bound by the Treaty to adopt the legislation and to implement it, and it will be done as of 1 January 2021. Let me also thank the Commission President for her extremely clear words on this. This is of the utmost importance.  What actually is the rule of law that we are talking about here? It’s quite simply the cornerstone of our democratic existence in Europe, so therefore it is the most important thing that we have. That’s why this step is very important for us. It will not end everything, but it will be the first step on our way.  I hope we can reach a vast majority in this House for this historic law and I want to wish our independent Commission and the guardian of the Treaties wisdom and vigilance in its application of this law as of 1 January 2021.  (Applause)

name: Terry Reintke
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. – Madam President, the louder the victory-screaming of the Hungarian Government gets, the more it is actually meant to cover up the actual facts. First of all, no agreement was reopened. Secondly, none of the legal texts were changed. And thirdly, and most importantly, the rule of law conditionality is going to come. Viktor Orbán cannot cover that up no matter how loud he actually screams. But politically the question remains, and I personally don’t think that this is something that came out just last week, but it has been there all along.  Is this European Commission, the guardian of the Treaties, ready to stand up for the rule of law and fundamental rights even when it gets difficult? Will you apply a fully functional applicable regulation that after its adoption will enter into force on 1 January 2021, or is this Commission afraid of the noise of the autocrats and authoritarians in this Union? I can tell you – and I have to repeat myself here – the European Parliament is not afraid. With hundreds of millions of EU citizens we stand up for rule of law and democracy. Listen to us. Listen to these citizens, not to the noise coming from the autocrats and authoritarians.  And lastly, dear colleagues in the EPP – and I say this as someone who has worked closely and constructively with many of you over the years – it does not need another debate however intense it is going to be about where Orbán and Fidesz are heading. This party is set to undermine the rule of law, fundamental rights and democracy. The facts are clear. What else has to happen for you to finally take action? The time for complacency is over. Dear colleagues in the EPP, act now.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE).
text: " Ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, I begin with a request. Monsieur Charles Michel, don't make any more excuses, hurry up. It's urgent. We're in an emergency situation. It is necessary to ratify the Recovery Fund, it is urgent that it reaches the economy. Don't make up any more obstacles, let there be no more blackmail. This is an urgency, and it is a request, and also do not look at the European Union budget as an expense. The European Union budget is investment. The European Union budget benefits everyone. End "net contributors" and "net beneficiaries". Everyone benefits from the European Union. We have a positive and historic agreement.
