Thank you, Mrs von der Leyen, and thank you also Mrs Merkel who proposed, and also dragged the Council, into this historic decision.  We have a recovery fund of EUR 750 billion for the first time, a multiannual financial framework in a reasonable amount, a binding roadmap for the decision of own resources. But we will need to pay off the debt of EUR 750 billion and we cannot burden the citizens. The principle is simple: those who do not pay must pay. And we also have to try to combat fraud, tax avoidance, and that is resources that would be sufficient to pay for the Multiannual Financial Framework in just one year. We've reached a binding agreement. It is now urgent that this binding agreement for the introduction of new own resources be respected, put into practice. We'll be vigilant. We will continue, as we have been monitoring and working for a strong Europe, a united Europe, a sustainable and supportive Europe, and the Multiannual Financial Framework and these resources now, as I said at the beginning, must reach the economy quickly. It is up to the Member States to make good use of these resources in a fair and transparent manner, so that Europe and all Member States are economically and territorially competitive and cohesive.

name: Elisabetta Gualmini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, today it is the time of pride. We are at the end of the most dramatic year in the history of the European Union and the pandemic is still not over. Yes, people are still suffering a lot and some of them are even dying, but we have done our job, and we have to claim this and tell this with all our voice and our passion. Today we can say we have finally closed up the agreement on the whole financial strategy, the Recovery Fund, the MFF, the revision of own resources and together with the other programmes we can count almost EUR 2 400 billion for fighting the crisis.  We have to be proud of this European renaissance. We have to be proud of this huge mobilisation of resources never before put in place for our citizens, and we have to be proud to have strengthened the rule of law. No relativism on democratic values is acceptable.  We have done our job and it is a good job. We have been united, notwithstanding our work differences. We have been determined, not withstanding our uncertainties. We have been efficient, notwithstanding what were long and sometimes incomprehensible procedures. We have been ambitious, notwithstanding our fears.  I am on my first mandate. I am proud of having entered the European institutions in such a moment of change and historic commitment and for those who still do not believe in Europe, who think that alone we could face dramatic challenges, let them come to Brussels. For those who think that Europe is only a giant of hype and bureaucracy, very far from people, let them come to Brussels. For those who have to use a credit card before entering into a hospital, let them come to Brussels. Dear colleagues, we have done a huge and terrific job. We just have to go on.

name: Valérie Hayer (Renew).
text: Madam President, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, unlike Mrs Aubry, I am confident that Europe will move in fiscal power while this recovery takes place. Let us be proud of it, because it is the result of the will of those who believe in it, it is the result of the will of the pro-Europeans. It is also our result, this budget, this calendar for own resources: Johan, José Manuel, Jan, Margarida, Rasmus, thank you. However, dear friends, we must remain lucid. Europe is torn from within. It is torn from the inside because of those who want to break the common rules, but who willingly accept our money - that is no problem. I'm going to be very clear about the rule of law. I hear the far right and the purveyors of fake news tell us that to refuse the rule of law is to refuse quotas for the reception of migrants. But finally, it has absolutely nothing to do with migration and you know it perfectly! You are hiding behind this unfounded claim to advance your hidden agenda, which is to undermine our democracies. Because, yes, this is our democratic values enshrined in our treaties: human dignity, freedom, justice, equality, democracy, plurality, non-discrimination. Those who are against this mechanism for the rule of law are against all these values. And I say that those who are against these values do not have to receive money from the European Union to get rid of them, either in their country or in this Parliament.

name: Jörg Meuthen (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The German chancellor proudly said after last week's EU Council summit that it was worth not sleeping. If I look at the results of that inglorious night, All I can do is shout to her: "Mrs. Merkel, would you have been better off going to bed early!" The countries of Europe are suffering from the pandemic, but at least as much from the crisis management, which is catastrophic in many places. Europe's economy is groaning. Millions of jobs are acutely threatened or already lost. But the Heads of Government have no other answer than to indiscriminately pulverize taxpayers' money – as always. Does anyone seriously believe that the incredible EUR 1.8 trillion from the MFF and the reconstruction plan – this unprecedented redistributive – will be able to defuse anything about this crisis?  Nationalization and socialism have never been a working solution, and this debt socialism will not be. I deeply regret that the EU has managed, with a lazy compromise, to persuade Poland and Hungary to vote 'yes' to this aberration. With the so-called rule of law mechanism, the EU's centralists now have the ultimate instrument to get all those with harsh penalties on track who do not support Brussels' left-green agenda. Concern, Mr Roth, but first of all, before you regulate Hungary and Poland, there is a lot to do. And, Mrs von der Leyen, perhaps first of all, try to comply with the European Treaties. I would particularly like to call out Article 125 TFEU.  And as if all this were not enough of the bad, the summit imposes new, completely absurd climate targets on Europeans by 2030. Basically, the summit decided on the deindustrialisation of Europe. Especially in Germany, this will very soon be felt. The winners will be the United States and, above all, China. You know, it may have been a sleepless night for the Heads of State or Government, but millions of Europeans, who are more than ever afraid of their future, their existence, face many sleepless nights in the face of these disastrous decisions.

name: Rasmus Andresen (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Budgetary policy often has a reputation for being dry and boring, and I believe that the last few weeks have shown us all that the opposite is true. We MEPs have fought for European values and clear priorities. It wasn't boring. And the result is a good basis for the next few years. Instead of budget cuts, we are responding to the economic crisis for the first time in the history of the European Union with joint investments and bonds. For the first time, 30% of the budget will be invested in climate. Nature conservation will become a binding budgetary target and the entire EU budget will be put to the climate test bench. The fine-thinking of climate targets will stop. Research, health, culture – the European Parliament has pushed through many investments for the future. Most importantly, by doubling the democracy and human rights programme, we are supporting organisations that are committed to democracy and diversity in all European states. And we stand by our European democracy and the rule of law mechanism. Now it is up to you, Mrs von der Leyen! Do not listen to non-binding Council declarations and destroyers of democracy, such as Viktor Orban, but implement the laws that we are adopting today from 1 January. Ensure that climate and biodiversity quotas become concrete projects. Today, for the first time, we Greens agree with the multiannual budget. This is also a vote of confidence, and that is the belief that it can become something good. Let us now work together to ensure that we are right.

name: Bogdan Rzońca (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Everyone heard such a cry that everyone won. He won reason, won justice. This was the case after the European Union summit, but then it got worse. I heard from one of my lawyers last Monday that only the Rule of Law Regulation matters, that if the European Commission does not implement this regulation, the European Parliament can revoke it (after all, this is blackmail!) that the Conclusions of the European Council are not binding. I therefore hope that the findings of the European Council were not theatre under the baton of the German Presidency.  I ask whether the European Commission will refrain from applying the unlawful regulation until the Court of Justice of the European Union has its say. I ask whether lawyers who once were able to justify a fascist and communist regime will now decide on justice in the European Union. After all, we cannot allow this to happen. Poles suffered a lot during the partitions of World War I and II and during communism. We have fought for the freedom of many peoples and we continue to believe that the Union makes sense as long as it is a just Union and goes down the path of free nations with free and equal peoples.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, the EUR 750 billion Recovery Fund is an important positive step and must therefore start without further delay. The European Parliament is even asking for twice as much pre-financing as 20% rather than 10%, with a plan, transparency, honest management and full respect for the rule of law. The multiannual budget, however, despite the increase of EUR 16 billion that we have achieved as the European Parliament, remains inadequate. It is impossible for the European Union to achieve its objectives with a budget of 1% of European GDP. That is why we are calling for the transaction tax, as well as the taxation of digital giants, to be changed, for the rules of the Stability Pact and the debt arrangements to be changed, in order to avoid a new round of tough one-sided austerity.  Mr Michel, in the face of Turkish provocation, the Summit was a Waterloo. You continue to caress Erdogan, who rightly celebrates your decisions. You continue to reject the overwhelming resolution of the European Parliament, which, by 631 votes in favour and just 3 against, calls for tough sanctions against the Erdogan regime. Because that is the only way Erdogan can be forced to respect international law and good neighbourliness.  Mr Michel and Mrs von der Leyen, the fierce second wave of the pandemic and the Great Recession do not allow for self-inditation and embellishment. More and faster steps are needed to protect public health, economic recovery and reduce dangerous social inequalities.

name: Márton Gyöngyösi (NI).
text: – Madam President, colleagues, let me help to resolve a dilemma for all those here who might follow Angela Merkel’s advice and think that a policy of appeasement will make Viktor Orbán retreat, consider the rule of law and accept European values. Clearly he won’t because his illiberal agenda is based on eternal conflict, corruption financed by EU funds, and demolishing democratic norms in Hungary. Orbán will continue to do so even if the price is Hungary ultimately leaving the European Union. Concession is a sign of weakness which will only bolster the confidence of all those who want to tear the European Union apart. A compromise might save face for a German EU Presidency and the retiring German Chancellor, but it will certainly have long-lasting and damaging implications for the European project. Thus, given the current circumstances, I suggest that the European Parliament turn without delay to the European Court of Justice for an express ruling on the Rule of Law mechanism so that it can be effective from the very beginning of 2021.

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which A terrible year for many people is coming to an end. This year, however, Europe has outgrown itself. We still remember the terrible situation at the beginning of the year, with closed borders and national solo operations. Now we have the situation: Europe is capable of action, we have set the budget for the future, we have adopted the Corona construction package, and the first vaccine developed has been developed in the European Union, also with European support. You, Mrs von der Leyen, have made a significant contribution with the Commission. We in Parliament, but also the Council and the Presidency of the Council, have been very active. Some people – including here in this House – have said before the German Presidency that Angela Merkel, who is tired, is only one year in office and is a kind of lame duck. What we've seen in the last six months was world class, it wasn't a lame duck, it was a high-flying eagle - bright awake - acting at the right moment. I hope that all the forthcoming presidencies will bring this pro-European momentum and willingness to act and that we will be able to develop Europe further over the next few years. But I have one concern: this year has been a completely lost year, especially for children and young people. The schools are partly cancelled, almost no sport in the club, no music lessons, social contacts restricted. As far as I know, only one vaccine manufacturer is in the process of carrying out studies on children. I therefore appeal to all those responsible: please do not forget the young generation and help to help ensure that the young generation can return to normality as quickly as possible.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D).
text: Madam President, Mr President, I would first like to express my satisfaction on the question of maintaining the rule of law mechanism. And thank you for tying it to the budget issue, it has been said and repeated several times. It would have been inappropriate and unacceptable for two heads of state and government, whether Polish or Hungarian, to weaken the heart of the European edifice on its values, on our common values. Thank you, Madam President, for making your introductory remarks earlier, in which you said that you were enforcing the rules of the rule of law from 1 January 2021. This is important and we needed to hear it today, because this release allowed the budget package to be adopted.  On the multi-year financial framework, as I know, I have spoken several times, I would have hoped for an even larger budget to address climate issues. And this budget is going in the right direction: 30% directed towards climate, 10% ultimately directed towards biodiversity. I hope here that the Portuguese Presidency can reorient the common agricultural policy in this direction, that of climate and biodiversity, and that it will take into account the environmental and social issues of this common agricultural policy.  And then there is the stimulus package: 750 billion euros. See precisely what is happening with its mechanism, which illustrates European solidarity. The mechanism is different for the allocation of funds and for the repayment of funds. Again, this is at the heart of the European project.  And finally, say how happy I am to see that the door opens for own resources. Of course, the goal is not achieved as we hoped. But the fight over own resources, and in particular the fight over the financial transaction tax, must continue. There is the future of the European Union. It is the Europe of tomorrow that will illustrate this through the question of own resources.

name: Moritz Körner (Renew).
text: Madam President, Madam President of the Commission, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has It is a great success for the European Parliament that there is finally a rule of law mechanism, that the European Union finally has the principle that EU values go hand in hand with EU funds and that this can no longer be exploited. I would also like to make it quite clear that it is this legislative text that we, as the European Parliament, have negotiated with the Council, that matters, and not any conclusions of the summit. And to the GUE Group, which has just criticised the fact that this mechanism of the rule of law is not good enough: where were you in the negotiations with the Council? We did not see for a minute that any representative of the Left faction would have been involved in negotiations, would have fought along. This was an achievement of the European Parliament, but certainly not of the Left Group – at this point. However, Mr Roth, I do not share your optimism that a Judgment on the European Court of Justice will actually resolve these tensions. Poland and Hungary are already ignoring rulings by the European Court of Justice.  Mrs von der Leyen, I am very grateful for the clear positioning that you have taken here, that you said that the rule of law mechanism will be set up immediately. But it is not just the rule of law mechanism that matters. We are at a new historic low of breaches or referrals before the ECJ. It is up to the European Commission. The rule of law in Europe is on fire. Take that into your own hands! We are counting on you, and we will hold you to account.

name: Jaak Madison (ID).
text: – I speak Estonian in my own language. Mr President, Mr President, Mr President, I am very pleased to hear the praise and beautiful speeches of how successful the European Council was. I only have a minute and a half left, so I'm going to take two things together briefly. Firstly, EUR 750 billion then into a recovery fund: of course, this is now an absurd theatre, where everyone still praises the fact that this is the right idea, should have borrowed even more. But no one wants to talk about the fact that there have been repeated periods in history where we know what happens with mindless money printing, printing – and it never ends well. Perhaps no one has yet solved the question of how we will pay back this money within 30 years, and the fact is that it requires the introduction of new taxes. Perhaps in order to print the money today as if for a so-called good cause, we are creating a situation where we have to impose new taxes on the citizens of the European Union in a Union-wide way, and that also means reopening and amending the Treaties again. And that, in turn, leads to a wide range of legal and legal questions about whether it is legal at all. For example, in Estonia – in my country – the opening of the Treaties would mean a new referendum. It is the decision of the Supreme Court of Estonia since 2012 that the opening of the treaties, which would need to be done to introduce new taxes across the European Union, would mean a referendum. And I am the first to campaign in my own country for people to say, no, we do not want more federalisation or a concentration of tax policy in the hands of the European Commission. Finally, as far as Hungary and Poland are concerned, I would say that, you know, it is an economic union, not a political, social federation, where we go and teach the Poles and the Hungarians what they have to do there. So, my time is up, thank you, and i guess every alliance will fall apart eventually. Thank you!

name: David Cormand (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the negotiations have resulted in this proposal for an agreement, which it is up to us to validate or not. For me, there are two lessons. The first is that the European Parliament has taken the measure of its responsibilities by reflecting on a budget that is powerful, with powerful own resources and with democratic control. So Parliament has done its job. The second is that the Council, that is, the States, has not lived up to this ambition that MEPs carried. But without a powerful budget, financed by fair taxation - the financial transaction tax, the GAFAM tax, the carbon tax with sufficient volume - Europe will remain a giant with feet of clay and its future will be threatened. In the coming times, it will be time for Parliament to take full measure of its power and for the Council and its member states to cease to be obstacles to the fulfilment of the Union.

name: Derk Jan Eppink (ECR).
text: Mr President, we will have a corona assistance fund of EUR 750 billion. Actually, that fund is illegal, because where is the legal authority? It is based on Article 122, which is intended for disasters such as forest fires and floods, not for the mega transfer of funds, without preconditions. What do recipient countries do? They spend the money on tax cuts in Italy, a basic income in Spain, a postponement of pension reforms in France. What does that have to do with corona?  The treaty prohibits the European Commission from borrowing money on the capital market, see Article 311. But the Commission is doing it anyway. If it is short of powers, the Commission's legal service will come up with a narrative that it is allowed to do so. What does this mean for the Netherlands? In order to keep the euro afloat, the Netherlands guarantees 245 billion euros. €245 billion in various funds, according to the Dutch General Audit Office. That is EUR 32 000 per household and few can afford it. But the Dutch government prefers to conceal that amount, as if nothing is wrong. But there is something going on and it is time that the citizens of the Netherlands know which financial sword of Damocles hangs over their heads.

name: Silvia Modig (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the Council took important decisions from a climate point of view. European climate policy is often portrayed as saying that the EU is doing more now than ever before. This is true, but that does not mean that we are still doing enough. The President of the Commission, Mr von der Leyen, said in his speech that it is easy to set a target, the challenge itself comes from the work to achieve it. Unfortunately, it now seems that the objective set for a climate-adequate level is very difficult for the Commission and the Council. The Council decided its position on the key elements of the Climate Act. The emission reduction target for 2030 was set at 55 per cent. When it comes to the net figure, it means that the actual emission reduction will be much lower than this, 3-10% lower, according to various estimates. It is difficult to understand how decisions are still being taken that are below scientific advice. This is bad news for the climate, but also bad news for business and business. The Climate Act sets us the goal of being carbon neutral in 2050. This objective is also in favour of the Council. If we do not now set the milestone at an adequate level, we will have to repair the target forcefully upwards in the coming years, and this will be much more expensive and much more difficult than setting it at an adequate level now, thereby guaranteeing a stable operating investment environment for businesses, businesses and industry for the coming years, thereby protecting jobs. Finally, Mr President, both the long financial framework and the stimulus package contain earmarked climate money. A very good decision, but the next step is to prepare that this money will be spent genuinely and effectively. We can't afford any greenwashing.

name: Clara Ponsatí Obiols (NI).
text: – Madam President, this agreement is a good step, but on the rule of law, it can easily turn out empty, because the rule of law is at risk in Europe not only because of Hungary, Poland or Spain. What undermines the rule of law are double standards and a lack of political courage in the Council and the Commission. Member States like Spain know how to take the money and get away with abuses of human rights. Spain has a delinquent Supreme Court that engages in politics and openly defies the European Court of Human Rights. But the EU is blind to it. On Monday, the Supreme Court decided to take Arnaldo Otegi and other leaders in the Basque country to a second trial for the same accusations. They have already been convicted, they have already served six years in jail. The Strasbourg court ruled that they did not have a fair trial. So what’s the response? Another trial. If Spain can behave like Turkey, it’s because the EU – you the Council, the Commission – allow it. Double standards in Brussels. Your double standards are destroying the rule of law in Europe.

name: Andrzej Halicki (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Madam President of the Commission, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Sch Mr President of the European Council, I would like to begin by thanking mr Today I wanted Polish to speak on behalf of the majority of Polish society, because the name of my homeland, which has been mentioned here many times in the best context, tells me that this government has not recently represented the will of the majority of Polish society. Polish society welcomes the conclusions and decisions that give us some hope for this coming year. Hope to defend the fundamental values with which we are associated and to defend democracy, because the rule of law mechanism is a very important instrument and judicial independence and media freedom are important for every citizen. The protection and mobilisation of EU funds really gives hope.  The vast majority, because more than 80% of Polish society has its hope, is linked to a stronger and not weaker European Union and to the integration process that we should support. On behalf of polish society, I wanted to thank all the negotiators very warmly. Thank you and wish you success next year, because Polish society is pro-European.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, President von der Leyen, Mr Michel, at the middle of the second pandemic wave throughout Europe, today's vote gives a signal of hope to the citizens of Europe.  With the green light for the multiannual budget, next generation EU and the rule of law regulation, we can build the recovery of economies from new, more environmentally and socially sustainable foundations. There is a European response to this economic and social crisis, where many taboos have finally been broken, such as the one on common indebtedness, supported by new union own resources, which are not new taxes for citizens, but the possibility of putting our tax system back on track.  This is the victory of the house of European citizens, Parliament, which has never failed to take stock of an ambitious budget, adapted to the times we live in and the conditionality of European funds and respect for the rule of law, because we are together when we share the same values of freedom and democracy. Above all, however, this is the victory of those who believe in Europe and not of those who, even in here, wanted to destroy it and today applaud the result. Only if we can respond more forcefully to the global challenges we face.

name: Katalin Cseh (Renew).
text: – Madam President, to understand what it means to have a rule of law mechanism, let me describe this special Groundhog Day in which we are stuck in Hungary. You open the news and there is a corruption scandal. EU funds never arrived to our poorest communities, but ended up with a spouse of a Fidesz politician or maybe even the son—in—law of Mr Orbán. But as Hungary’s top public prosecutor is a former member of Fidesz, there was no investigation. It’s been going on for 10 years. Since the beginning of our mandate we raised these cases in letters, at hearings, at the plenary, and the answer we got was always the same: the EU is deeply concerned but we don’t have the tools to take action. Come next January and the rule of law mechanism, this excuse is gone, and this is a victory for this Parliament. We fought for this with unity and resolve and, yes, many of us are disappointed with the Council, which yet again failed to send a clear message.  Maybe it’s my optimism as a new lawmaker but I still believe this time is different and the difference is this Parliament – what we have achieved together and our commitment to keep going. If the Commission fails to act, we will call out their dereliction of duty. If court challenges are used to delay the procedure, we will request an expedited procedure. We have the tools in our hands and we will use them. This is the message of our resolution. (Applause)

name: Gilles Lebreton (ID).
text: Ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, the European recovery plan will inject hundreds of billions of euros into the economies of the Member States of the Union, but this is not magic money: the borrowed money will have to be repaid. To finance this huge loan, the Union has therefore decided to use its own resources, i.e. taxes whose products will fall directly into its coffers, without going through state budgets. Beyond its purely financial aspect, the operation therefore pursues a very political goal: to make the Union more autonomous, less dependent on the budgetary decisions of the States. This is therefore a very important step forward towards the transformation of the Union into a federal state. European sovereignty, dear to President Macron, is on the march. I strongly condemn this drift, because I am in favour of a democratic Europe, respectful of the identities and sovereignty of nations, and not of this strange technocratic model of a state without a nation and of sovereignty without people. I believe in this case that I am the spokesperson for the majority of the French people, whose draft European Constitution I recall in a referendum in 2005. Finally, I regret that two good ideas are being spoiled, that of the creation of a GAFA tax on the digital giants, and that of a carbon tax levied on imports of polluting goods. I would have supported these taxes if their products had fallen into the budgets of the Member States in line with my vision of Europe.

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, a lot has been said on the Council conclusions – and I wish to thank you, President von der Leyen, for saying you will implement the law right away – but we still have questions.  On the Commission statement that went together with the Council’s, the Commission says that it is committed to the elements referred to in paragraph 2 of the Council conclusions. Part of those Council conclusions state very clearly that the guidelines can only be finalised after an ECJ ruling, and that until the guidelines are finalised the Commission will not propose measures under the regulation.  If you say ‘I am committed to those conclusions’ then how should we interpret these Council conclusions. A clear answer is needed – not just saying ‘I’m going to implement it’. What are you going to do with paragraph 2(c) of the Council conclusions on the guidelines? (Applause) This is also to the Council thinking they are a co—legislator. Again, if we look at the climate conclusions, you will come back. You say ‘we are going to give guidelines on climate in the spring before the Commission comes with its package’. Do you know that the Council is not allowed to do co—legislation? Will you refrain from that?  And Commission, will you please not say again that you will commit to those guidelines? Because it is here where co—legislation is done. (Applause)

name: Peter Lundgren (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Today is a day of mourning. The vast majority of you in this house are fanatics, and you will not rest until you have crushed all self-determination and created a United States of Europe. Today you are here and proud of the budget and the corona package when you should in fact be ashamed – ashamed that you are blaming our children and grandchildren for a very long time to come by lending money in direct violation of the Treaty to the budget and then giving it away without any requirement of how they are used or that they are repaid. We are approaching Christmas, and this is what you intend to give for Christmas to our children and grandchildren. Santa Claus is ashamed of you as you now hand out these packages filled with pieces of coal to our future generations. Merry Christmas.

name: Λευτέρης Νικολάου-Αλαβάνος (NI).
text: Madam President, the expectations of the New Democracy Government and the other urban parties for a strong response by the European Union to the aggression of the Turkish bourgeoisie have been strongly contradicted. In the context of the intra-urban confrontations and compromises expressed with the Recovery Fund and the multiannual financial framework, and due to the deep capitalist crisis, the table of co-exploitation is also set in the Aegean and the eastern Mediterranean, under the responsibility of both the Greek bourgeoisie and a Euro-Nato umbrella.  This dangerous strategy for the people and sovereign rights of the country is determined by the Economic, Military and Political Relations of the European Union with Turkey and ensuring NATO cohesion in competition with Russia. In this context, US sanctions on Turkey, with which they maintain strategic relations, are also moving, and on the basis of these they are firmly raising issues of at risky borders and waters in the Aegean and the Cypriot EEZ. The interventions of the US, NATO and the European Union are exacerbating the situation in the region and peoples are being asked to trust their own struggle to disengage from the planning of capital and imperialist centres.

name: Dolors Montserrat (PPE).
text: – Madam President, President Von der Leyen, President Michel, ladies and gentlemen, we have complied with the Europeans. There is already agreement to increase recovery plan funds with a firm commitment to the defence of the rule of law. Now it is up to the different governments to react and live up to it.  These aids belong to all Europeans and must serve to create jobs, grow and overcome this health crisis. Don't let anyone get confused! These funds are not for any government or any ideology. It is necessary to require transparency, more parliamentary control and independent management of these aids. Otherwise, we can again suffer the waste of public money, such as the Socialist Government's 'Plan E' which unfortunately did not serve to remove Spain from the 2008 crisis, but quite the opposite.  European aid shows, once again, that the European Union is a success story, as confirmed by the COVID vaccine, a vaccine for all Europeans.  Europe must successfully complete the challenge of the virus, which has also taught us that, in the face of populism, such as the one that has provoked Brexit, the best recipe is the unity of all Europeans.  We must also face challenges such as immigration. That is why I regret that this House has refused to discuss the dramatic situation in the Canary Islands. We don't want it to become a new Lesbos. This Parliament cannot look the other way. This Union was not built to ignore serious challenges, such as the drama of immigration, but, on the contrary, to confront them together from unity, coordination and the firm defence of the values that have enabled the European Union to be built and kept alive.

name: Kati Piri (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I am proud of my own S&D group and proud of this Parliament, because – let’s be honest – without us there would not have been any rule of law conditionality, and despite enormous pressure we have remained united in this principle. And by creating a real measure against their autocratic leaders, we have given hope again to the people of Hungary and Poland for a democratic future. We have demonstrated that we do not give in to blackmail attempts. The text of our agreement stays intact, despite Angela Merkel’s ugly search for a compromise with her fellow EPP member Orbán, and despite the willingness of you, President von der Leyen, to accommodate the Council rather than to safeguard the Commission’s independence. I am confident that the European Court of Justice will confirm Parliament’s position on this regulation as soon as possible, and I expect the European Commission to use all instruments at its disposal to clamp down on Europe’s autocrats as of now. And that should not be a political choice; it should be the only legal option.

name: Luis Garicano (Renew).
text: – Madam President, Mrs Von der Leyen, Mr Michel, this year which concludes has been brutal. The virus has claimed the lives of tens of thousands, the livelihood of millions and the freedom of all our fellow citizens. During the worst weeks of March and April we feared that the virus would also be brought ahead to Europe. In those terrible spring weeks each nation was acting on its own. Never before has our Union faced such a threat.  Today we can proudly say that the European Union has risen to the challenge. We entered 2021 closer than ever. This Parliament can be proud of its work on the Recovery Plan, the multiannual budget and the rule of law defence mechanism. We must now ensure that Europeans' resources are invested well, that states meet European conditions: respect the rule of law, make reforms and invest in a cleaner and more digital future. Mrs. Von der Leyen, let our work not be in vain. I ask you , no, I demand — that the Commission should have the courage and determination to defend our values against the governments that challenge them. Millions of Europeans depend on this recovery package. And Europe depends on these values. Don't let us down.

name: Tom Vandendriessche (ID).
text: Mr President, the European Union is totally derailing. What once began as an economic cooperation to achieve peace and prosperity is developing into a political superstate that wants more and more power and thus leads us from one conflict to another.  The European values on which this cooperation was once based are being systematically transformed: centralism replaces subsidiarity, uniformity replaces diversity, bureaucracy replaces democracy. The European dream is going to be a nightmare. However, the brutality and arrogance with which the euro-fanatic elite wants to subjugate free nation states and citizens is not a sign of strength, but of impotence, because nothing can break the will of a people to be free. A war with that reality cannot be won.  Brexit and the veto of Hungary and Poland are alarm signals. They want to govern themselves, but face intimidation, blackmail and threats. Eurofederalism makes us sleepwalk to the trenches. What they call populism is a cry for help from a people who do not want to be replaced, who cherish their freedom and want to govern themselves.  It is high time we listened and we returned to the original foundations and values of the European Union. This is voluntary economic cooperation between free and democratic nation states.

name: Daniel Freund (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very Just four days after the European summit, Viktor Orban continues to create facts. He now writes the systematic plundering of EU funds directly into the Hungarian Constitution. That is precisely what this rule of law mechanism is supposed to prevent. But instead of ensuring that it comes as quickly as possible and that we can use it, the European Council has put it on hold for another while: two years, perhaps three, in doubt until after the next elections in Hungary. Dear Michael Roth: At the July Summit, you clearly raised the hurdle to triggering this mechanism. Then you made this compromise proposal, in which you reduced the scope, and you even deleted the word 'rule of law' from the text. And now the Commission is being forced to wait again for sanctions. I have to say that I have problems in really recognising a great success for the European constitutional state through the German Presidency. Mrs von der Leyen: We agreed in the trialogue that this law would enter into force on 1 January. That is what the law says, as the Treaties stipulate – whether Poland or Hungary are suing against it. That is exactly what must happen now, because the rule of law cannot wait. We must use all the tools at its disposal to defend the European rule of law.

name: Hermann Tertsch (ECR).
text: – Madam President, really the arrogance seen here: 'Rechtsstaat, Rule of Law'... But nowhere is there any treaty that says that this Parliament or the Commission is going to dictate the national policy of Hungary or Poland. He doesn't put it anywhere! And here he is insisting on wanting to do it.  Of course, the Council taught us a good lesson, because the Member States have neutralised attempts to instrumentalise politically the implementation of the agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework. All this immense money, which is going to be used in large part for social engineering, was also wanted to be used for political blackmail, and that, in part, has been neutralized. But I see you insist on it, you still want to do it.  If you are really concerned about the rule of law, go to Spain, where there is a communist penetration from Ibero-America of drug trafficking that is undermining, breaking and destroying Spanish democracy every day, liquidating the rule of law there, without anyone saying anything here.  A little more respect, please, to the truth.

name: François-Xavier Bellamy (PPE).
text: Madam President, the Council's conclusions leave the bitter taste of some unresolved issues. We are faced with a stimulus package, but there are also a lot of problems with this stimulus package. First, an economic problem, because we are creating a new debt in an unstable environment. Secondly, a problem of justice for future generations, because this agreement does not set the terms of the repayment - and, Mr President of the Council, it is not insulting to consider that, in seven years, you are unlikely to be there again. Is it really generosity to agree on a debt that we leave to our successors to pay?  Finally, a major democratic problem, because I hear the Members of the Liberal Group in front of us, Mr Macron's group, who were at the initiative and who are delighted and applaud that this additional budgetary integration is paving the way for a European federal state. But are European citizens aware of this? Do they hear your applause? In fact, this is a major problem because all of this is not democratically assumed in front of the citizens of our countries. Unfortunately, it is likely that instead of creating a form of solution to the economic crisis, this stimulus package will help to open up the new field of a democratic problem. We have before us a major task, which is to ensure that at least some economic, industrial rationality is allocated to this plan. Madam President of the Commission, we are counting on your work to ensure that this money is invested with the concern for the future prosperity it will generate, so that those who follow us tomorrow can at least make this stimulus package an opportunity to strengthen the savings they will need to shoulder the additional burden that we are in the process of , once again, to transfer them.

name: Heléne Fritzon (S&D).
text: Madam President, Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on his excellent We are in the midst of a pandemic and people are suffering. It is therefore very gratifying that we now have an agreement on the whole package, both on the financial perspective and – of course most importantly – on the principles of the rule of law. It is a new and historic decision. The message is clear: when Member States choose not to respect the fundamental values of the European Union, then there should be consequences. It is time for Hungary and Poland to follow eu principles. Otherwise, there will be no money.  The new package will contribute to a more equal and equal Europe, with green transition, jobs and social rights having an impact. The tightening of the climate target by 2030 is good, but it is not enough. My wish is that we achieve higher ambitions and goals for future generations, for our children and grandchildren.

name: Guy Verhofstadt (Renew).
text: – Madam President, all those here from the Eurosceptic side who have criticised this package are completely right. Indeed, this is a huge step in European integration, a historic step in European integration – EUR 750 billion in recovery funds paid with the EU’s own resources, financed by eurobonds, and that linked to the rule of law.  But, let’s also be honest. There is one shadow cast over this and that is the way, naturally, Ms von der Leyen and the European Council have to ‘molest’ European treaties and principles to get over this blackmail by Hungary and Poland. I have here this fantastic opinion from the Legal Service – four paragraphs, no mention of one article of the Treaty, no mention of one court case, and saying exactly the opposite. The reality is that what the European Council did is not a coup d’état, but nearly a coup d’état. I think that the European Parliament anyway has to examine whether or not we go to court over this because there is one thing and I will conclude with that. You cannot save the rule of law in a Member State if you in fact ruin the rule of law of the Union itself. (Applause)

name: Antonio Maria Rinaldi (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, since its presentation, Next Generation EU, according to what is claimed not only by the media, would have found its greatest beneficiary in Italy in terms of both grants and loans, but it has nevertheless pointed out that the accounts can only actually be done in a few weeks' time, with the final text on own resources, with the criteria and items concerning how the Member States will actually contribute to the budget.  However, we can already say that, taking into account the financial flows already known for the period 2021-2027 for Italy, at best, the entire and complex Next Generation will be zero balance, and this always if you become aware of all the details, conditions, rates and methods of application of the various instruments, among which the most important and complex is the RRF , and not as is happening with SURE, the details of which we have been waiting for incredibly since 2 November last year, despite an urgent question put by colleagues from my party to the Commission.  We therefore call loudly for transparency on all the instruments put in place by the Commission, because Parliament and its Members are the ultimate expression of the representation of democracy in the Union.

name: Tineke Strik (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, the EU is a union of and for the citizens. They have entrusted the Institutions to protect their rights against discrimination, arbitrariness and abuse of power, but the institutions do not deliver. The Council doesn’t apply Article 7, Member States don’t speak up.  We therefore supported the Commission proposal to link the budget with the rule of law. It would place the Commission in the driver’s seat as a guardian of our core values.  Now the Council has tried to hijack the instrument and control the enforcement.  It’s good to hear your firm statement of this morning, Ms von der Leyen, but your written statement connected to the conclusions are the opposite.  Therefore, could you confirm that the Commission will trigger the mechanism if the criteria are met, even if an annulment procedure is still pending? I don’t mean interpreting, monitoring, or covering – but really undertaking action before we have an ECJ judgment?  Being the guardian of the Treaties comes with heavy responsibilities. Our citizens count on you.

name: Carlo Fidanza (ECR).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, you have been telling you all morning that the compromise on the rule of law will not change anything. You have forced the treaties, you want to ignore a Council agreement, now you also want to force the Court of Justice to destabilise governments of sovereign nations that do not bow to the dictatorship of political correctness. You did not succeed, but you have given us a more divided Europe. You have reached an agreement on climate, chasing ultra-environmental ideology. The recovery fund's green funds and the carbon border tax will arrive later. In the meantime, however, the timetable provides for the plastic tax from 1 January and a series of other limits and charges that will affect our European companies and make them less competitive.  You have stammered over Turkey with the proposal of mild individual sanctions, while Sultan Erdogan dominates the Mediterranean, the Caucasus and the Middle East. You are filling your mouths with words as the rule of law and you do not have the courage to withdraw Turkey's status as a candidate country. This is not the Europe we want.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Madam President, Madam President of the European Commission, I would like to thank the President-in-The-European President for the For me, this package has three messages. On the one hand, the European Union delivers. EUR 1 800 billion budget for investment against the crisis and in our common future. EUR 750 billion will be added to the capital market for the first time in this quantity. The NextGenerationEU Pact makes the European Union greener, more digital, more social, more independent. The Rule of Law Mechanism strengthens the earmarking of the allocation of funds. Reducing CO2 emissions by 55% by 2030 is a contribution to the EU's climate targets. These facts bear the hallmarks of the European Parliament. The second message is that the unanimity, nationalism, insincerity and duplicity of some Heads of State or Government are destroying these facts in public opinion. They are blackmailing, they are weakening, they are blocking the future of Europe.  That is why my third message is that we must remove the weaknesses in the debate on the future of Europe. Unanimity must fall. Wherever we have European tasks, Community law must be the basis, and we have to make it clear that the European Council is not a legislator, and it cannot therefore interpret legal texts. The final declaration is a distraction. We are the legislator with the Council.

name: Pedro Marques (S&D).
text: – Presidents, Colleagues, Citizens of Europe, at the end of last week Europe breathed a sigh of relief. The blackmail carried out by two Member States has not paid and on 1 January the new Multiannual Financial Framework will enter into force together with the rule of law mechanism.  The recovery plan could go its way fuelling Europeans' hope that by the end of this winter better days will come. But the decisions of the European Council are also important because they increase their ambition to combat climate change. This responsibility, the responsibility of this challenge, rests on all of us. And it is this responsibility that the Union assumes when it devote 30% of the budget to the fight against climate change and 10% to biodiversity, or when it increases the emissions reduction target by 2030.  We are on the right track, and I would like to welcome that, Mr President-in-Office, with the certainty that we can and must go further than the Council has now proposed. Europeans, particularly the younger ones, expect this from us. The planet can't wait.

name: Malik Azmani (Renew).
text: – Madam President, we will witness the historic moment shared in a profound way by this Parliament and by Renew Europe. As of next year, European money will be linked to respect for our common values, including the rule of law. Some Member States see these core values of the EU as negotiable, as a bargaining chip, something to put on line to see who blinks first. Let me state is very clear, they did not succeed. We stood our ground and I’m proud that because of the efforts of our group and this House, our fundamental values are now more strongly protect than before and only when our foundations are strong can we focus on getting Europe out of this crisis stronger. Therefore, we call on the Commission to set the rule of law mechanism in motion without delay. Some things needs to be renewed, but our basic common values merely need to be protected.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab A very difficult compromise has been reached. On the one hand, the mobilisation of the budget and programmes to mitigate the effects of the pandemic is so much awaited by the citizens of the Member States, and on the other hand, the package includes a regulation on the conditionality mechanism which is not compatible with the Treaties. Member States must have a sovereign right to act within their remit in accordance with their own constitutional order. The Court of Justice should therefore confirm its objections to the conditionality mechanism.  It is high time that the European Parliament respected the decisions and conclusions of the leaders of the Member States and stopped putting political pressure on the European Commission to regulate regulations incompatible with the Treaties. It is high time that the rule of law was respected by the EU institutions. The President has made a commitment, in agreement with the Council, to be courageous in implementing it.

name: Antonio Tajani (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, ten months have passed since, on a proposal from the Italian delegation, the GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats began to fight for a common European response to the pandemic.  It was February 18th, then few imagined the consequences of the health crisis. After some initially timid reactions, however, the Union has been able to rediscover the spirit of solidarity that is at its root. The multiannual financial framework and the Recovery Fund must shake up our economy. We have achieved important results: investments of EUR 1 840 billion; the decision to move towards a debt shared with recovery bonds, the common fight against Covid-19 mark the turning point between the Europe of austerity and that of solidarity. Citizens, families and businesses have been waiting for concrete answers for months. We have achieved important goals, but not yet enough. In order to avoid further imbalances and to ensure social justice, we need to do more.  If we want a strong Europe, we cannot have a budget worth just over 1 % of our GDP. We must harmonise the system of own resources – I am thinking of the plastic tax – distortions in the internal market must be avoided, but we must propose fair taxation. The giants of the web must not be legibus soluti. Like Robin Hood, we must ensure that the powerful Chinese and Americans pay more to make our citizens pay less.  Since we have also managed to achieve a good result on the rule of law, the German Presidency is doing well and I would like to conclude, Mr President, by pointing out that the rule of law has been violated in Europe, including with the complicity of certain governments, I would remind you of the murders of Ján Kuciak and Daphne Caruana Galizia, two things that we absolutely cannot forget if we want to defend the rule of law in our Union.

name: Eero Heinäluoma (S&D).
text: – Mr President, this is indeed an historic day and an historic whole that we are dealing with. A major stimulus package can now make a difference and safeguard economic activity in Europe, create new jobs and safeguard old jobs. The next important thing is that these funds are used correctly. The Member States are very responsible. The Commission must also be prepared to take this matter forward, ensuring the correct use of the money.  I am particularly pleased about the rule of law. Finally, and finally, we have reached a solution in which compliance with fundamental EU standards is tied to the use of budgetary resources. The solution wasn't perfect, but it's a head opener. The most important thing is that, from the beginning of the year onwards, the Commission will start to apply this principle. That is what the public expects. Parliament must contribute to ensuring that the Commission does its own work so that European values are present in the lives of all Europeans.

name: Sophia in 't Veld (Renew).
text: – Madam President, we have reasons to celebrate the many achievements in the MFF and the Recovery Fund – mainly thanks to the Parliament, I have to say, and our excellent negotiators.  But I have to say that the Council conclusions, with the complicity of the Commission, are unacceptable because they are a violation of the constitutional order of the European Union. We are on a very slippery slope here, and I think it’s been said by many colleagues. The Commission is the custodian of the Treaties and the Commission accepting instructions from the Council is a blatant violation of Article 17.3 of the Treaty.  The EU Treaty is a constitutional treaty, it’s not a political text that is up for negotiation. As to the rule of law regulation, that is a law passed by both legislators. It must be applied in full, including the date of entry into force. That is not optional. The Commission has no discretion to delay application, or apply only partially, or only after a court ruling. That’s simply not at the discretion of the Commission. President von der Leyen, we voted a year and a half ago to give our confidence to the Commission, doing so expecting that it would operate as the custodian of the Treaties, so I count on you to apply the law from 1 January. (Applause)

name: Monika Hohlmeier (PPE).
text: Madam President, Madam President of the Commission, Mr President, Minister of State Michael Roth, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work he has all said. The conditionality mechanism for protecting our financial resources, but ultimately to protect our rule of law, is a historic step, and it is a huge political success for this Parliament.  Without us, this conditionality mechanism would not exist. I really rely on the Commission to apply it directly, and I also believe that it will be. I would ask the Council to take a look at such developments for as long as they have been, monitored for as long and as long as they have been doing so. But I would like to make it clear today that it is a great step and it is a right step. I expect the ECJ to make a swift judgment, as it did on Brexit, so that we can get it straight into practice. However, I would like to add something: the Commission must be able to trace how funds are used, how they are used, where there are problems, where perhaps people do not have the protection of the rule of law, where a unilateral decision is made, where money is misused, where people cannot find neutral state administration, where there are no independent judges, where there are no legal remedies, etc. In these cases, we finally need the digital age and we need to get out of the stagecoach age. We finally need digital monitoring and an appropriate IT system or a digital way of tracing funds for the Commission, so that we finally know who is abusing, who is cheating, so that we can also use artificial intelligence and so that we also know who the economic beneficiaries are, who actually gets the money, what concentrations are going on where something may be abusive. We know that it is billions of dollars that are being partly misused. I would ask the Council to go within itself and finally get away from the stagecoach age. They are still rejecting the digital system or digitalisation itself. This is completely anachronistic. I would ask that the Council finally agree to our proposals.

name: Jens Geier (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Michel, President-in-Office of the Council, Minister of State, Mr Michael, Madam President von der Leyen, I would like to thank the President of the Council for his excellent work on this report. Well, that just went well. On 16 December, 15 days before the end of the current Multiannual Financial Framework, we will adopt the new one. But what a! I have watched rather desperately as a Presidency of the Council has thrown this hot potato at the following, without any substantial progress. The divisions that ran between the Member States and between them and the European institutions were deep. But now we have an MFF full of premiers: for the first time, debt is being taken up, the own resources base is being expanded, the Council's first financial compromise has been drilled by this Parliament, and all this has been done with a German Presidency in which Social Democrats set the tone. Or can anyone here imagine that a Wolfgang Schäuble would have acted in this way? I can't do this. Therefore, a heartfelt thank you to Olaf Scholz and also personally to you, dear Michael Roth.  One more sentence to you, Mrs von der Leyen: this House expects – as you have heard several times this morning – that you will apply the rule of law mechanism without delay. Finally, you are responsible for the implementation of the budget and also for its security. In the spring, the Commission wants to be relieved of its financial management. Let us hope that your authority will then also be accident-free.

name: Sandro Gozi (Renew).
text: Madam President, last May, the President of the Commission said that sooner or later our scientists will find a vaccine against coronavirus, but that against climate change there is no vaccine. Is there a vaccine against these diseases of authoritarianism and populism? I do not know, but I am convinced that democracy and the rule of law are as vital as the air we breathe. Because there is also a democratic emergency within our Union.  Let us then implement the rule of law regulation without delay. Let us be proud of this major step forward for which we have all fought hard for months — all but Mr Bellamy, if I have heard it.  You have been very clear this morning, Mrs von der Leyen: it is your duty to implement the European law without reference, without suspension, without any other guidelines, other than to protect the freedoms of the 447 million European citizens.  And, finally, ladies and gentlemen, let us stop with the veto threats. This is one more reason to start the conference on the future of Europe as soon as possible.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Madam President of the Commission, we are really facing a unique moment in the history of the European Union when we have been able, on the one hand, to launch a fund in which there is a common debt and, at the same time, we have a mechanism for monitoring the rule of law. But now, with the Recovery Fund and the Multiannual Financial Framework, Ms von der Leyen, it is very important to ensure that the funds are well spent.  Its Commissioner, Elisa Ferreira, said this week in the Portuguese press that despite the massive support of State funds from Portugal in the last 25 years, in which the Socialists were government in 18 of these, Portugal is a backward country. Now this is the last opportunity for many countries to stop being backward countries and we need to monitor how governments will spend the money: if they are going to spend it in favour of the digital transition, if they are going to spend it in favour of the climate transition. It's critical to know that. And then it is also very important, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, to be aware, together with the Commission, of the question of the rule of law because there are many leaders who, despite swearing in love with the rule of law, are more concerned with the funds that come than with the fulfilment of values, and it is essential that we have economic support, financial support , but that it is not done at the expense of those who are the principles and pillars of an increasingly integrated Union.  That is what we have achieved with this Next Generation EU, which is really a huge step forward, but which can only be progress if, instead of being a way of financing national budgets, it is a way of integrating into policies, but also in values, all the peoples of Europe, all the Member States.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D).
text: Mr President, I think it is our moral obligation to end the year 2020 optimistically and therefore to welcome the agreement to the Council, although I share the scepticism of some of my colleagues on a number of matters concerning the rule of law. But let us assume that we have nevertheless laid the foundations for recovery and for strong democracies in the European Union.  I also welcome the agreement on climate change at around 55%. I think that is important, even though this Parliament voted 60%, and that should immediately mean that we will continue to set the bar high. Above all, I would like to make the link between the recovery fund and our climate ambitions because the recovery is not just the restoration of our economy. We had already agreed before the pandemic that we need a very different economy and a very different society, and this recovery fund should be the guarantee for that. My last words are for the new generation. Because we've all been apart the last year. Many people have had a hard time, but we have not paid enough attention to the young people in our society. Let us dedicate this perspective to them and make sure that that democracy and that this new society will be climate-resilient, that we have really agreed this for them in this European Union.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, over the years I have heard many times the words that Europe is at a crossroads. Finally, in a year when we have a Member State leaving the Union and a historic agreement where Europe is raising debt together and we have rule of law conditionality for the EU budget and the Recovery and Resilience Facility, I think this statement rings true. Yes, we are at a crossroads, but it is a road we are crossing together.  The House has stood firm in a legally—binding mechanism that ties EU money to respect of the rule of law in Member States. This is born from a simple and irrefutable logic. Member States that want EU money must stick to the basic values of democracy and the Union. In a community of values, adherence to them in order to reap benefits should not be controversial. In total up to EUR 1.8 trillion will be spent by 2027 to make European economies more sustainable and digital, thanks to the EUR 750 billion Recovery Fund. I think great credit is due to the German Presidency, and particularly Angela Merkel. At  an EPP Group meeting some months ago, when the frugal four or five were in full voice, I remember saying to her that if she couldn’t get it over the line, no one could. Well, she has, but she is probably too modest and mature to look for kudos.  Also, I am sick of listening to Prime Ministers and Ministers around Europe saying that they are allocating x millions for this and y millions for that without giving credit to the European Union, where the money is coming from. I would ask Ursula von der Leyen and the Commission to ensure that doesn’t happen in the next seven years.  They might also give credit to the European Parliament for the EUR 16 billion extra we got for European programmes. Don’t hold your breath though.

name: Robert Biedroń (S&D).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab When Orbán and Kaczynski fought windmills, people lost their jobs, feared for their health and financial security, got sick and died. It is a pity that, through the obstruction of two governments – Polish Hungary, defending the interests of the parties, not the people – we have lost so much time. But we have united against absurd blackmail, we have shown that the rule of law is the unnegotiable foundation of our community, that no country is above the law. Through our unity and solidarity, we have created a mechanism that obliges everyone, without exception, to respect it. Grotesque fiction from Cervantes' novel became a reality at some point – Don Kiszot and his faithful slouch Sancho Pansa set off for a losing battle in advance. Fortunately, the party's selfishness was lost, fortunately the European community won. Thank you for that.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE).
text: – Madam President, it is said that the most important thing is always the last European summit. That's double the price of the last one. I am very pleased with the agreement on the European budget and, in particular, on the recovery fund, because we know that we can only overcome the current crisis with joint European forces. The summit agreement means that there will be enough money, and it depends very much on their proper investment. Since jobs must always be a priority in the first place, we must always think of those who make up the most, and these are small entrepreneurs. The summit's conclusions make clear the date of January 1, 2021, when European funds will be linked to respect for the rule of law. This is very good news for all those who are fighting for transparency and against the misuse of European funds. At the same time, I would like to stress that permanent cultural and family legislation remains the responsibility of the Member States and will always have to remain so. No sanctions will be imposed on such legislation, nor will funds be able to be cut. Ladies and gentlemen, this summit was an important milestone for the fight against the pandemic, for economic recovery and for climate protection. I would like to thank all those who have contributed to this, especially Ursula von der Leyen and Angela Merkel.

name: Ursula von der Leyen
text: President of the Commission. – Madam President, I want to reinforce my message to the honourable Members on the conditionality mechanism.  Indeed, the regulation will apply from 1 January 2021 onwards. No breach will go uncovered, no case will be lost. We will start the monitoring immediately and we will use all the additional instruments too, to defend the rule of law.  Monika Hohlmeier has said it, and very rightly so: we need to digitalise. We have additional instruments now on top of the other ones. This is against corruption, against fraud, to find out and to dismantle the end beneficiary. This is important, that’s where the music plays. Those who breach the rule of law will be held accountable. You can count on me and I know that I can count on you. In sum, allow me to thank you for this very rich debate at the end of this momentous year for Europe. It brings back to me so many memories of the debates we have had this year. I remember coming to this House in the early months of the coronavirus crisis. We all know the picture often looked bleak. The numbers of infections were rising constantly. There was a feeling of control being lost, division between Member States. We remember, in the spring, the doubts about the European Union.  Well today we should take a moment to reflect on how far we have come. Of course we still have work to do, of course we still have challenges and yes, we do have to focus on every detail to make sure that we get it right.  Whether it’s on the economy, the recovery, climate health, vaccination, Brexit – all these topics are there. But we should also pause very briefly and look at the big picture, look at how far we have travelled together.  Thanks to our collective work, Europe is moving forward faster than it has in decades. I want to pay tribute to this House for its ambition, for its dedication – you could feel it today, all day long again – and its real European leadership. This year we have shown that Europe is not only united in diversity, but it is united in adversity too. It is always easier to tear things down, but instead we chose to build something new and stronger. In the face of an unprecedented crisis, Europe stepped up with a massive recovery plan worth EUR 1.8 trillion, Next Generation EU, the European Green Deal with ambitious goals and building our digital decade. This is history in the making, and it is still a big moment here, with a vote that is history in the making. 2020 will be a year to forget certainly, for so many, and for so many reasons, but it will also be a year to remember for the European Union – the year we came together and moved forward together. The beginning of Next Generation EU, the beginning of Europe raising capital on the market to reform and invest together, the beginning of shaping our European future after the pandemic. Having said that, with pride and with confidence I say long live Europe!  (Applause)

name: Charles Michel
text: President of the European Council. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for the broad support expressed on the comprehensive compromise that is being proposed today. This has been said by many of you: the beginning of 2020 was marked by a crisis unprecedented for many decades. But it is true, it must be admitted, the first days, the first weeks, it is rather in scattered order, on the basis of rather national reflexes, that Europe has behaved. Very quickly, however, because there was this common will in the European Parliament and the Council, with the support of the Commission, we managed to ensure that supply chains were guaranteed. Member States have been successful in taking steps to limit the spread of the virus. And above all, in a few weeks, we managed to mobilize an international conference so that, very quickly, more than 16 billion euros would be committed to support research and probably to enable, in just a few months, probably less than a year, whereas usually it takes eight to ten years, to develop a vaccine to deal with a disease that , until a year ago, was largely unknown to scientists all over the world. In 2020, we have also faced economic recovery and the necessary transformation. As early as July, thanks to proposals from Member States, issued by the European Parliament, and a commission proposal, unprecedented decisions were taken. Never in its history has the European Union had at its disposal a budgetary firepower as is the case today, with 1,800 billion euros that can be mobilised. Not just any way, not to do anything, because we have clear ideas about our visionary role at the international level and on this climate ambition that was anchored in December 2019, with our ambition to achieve climate neutrality by 2050. And then, a few days ago, there was the decision to increase our efforts by 2030, which makes this ambition credible and reinforces the European Union's position as a global leader in the field of climate change. This European Green Pact is more than a project of prosperity, it is also a social project to mobilise all European actors, citizens, young people, businesses, small, medium and large, governments, municipalities... To be together, to stand together, to roll up their sleeves to progress, with this goal, which is so important. And it is true that in the coming months we will also be very mobilized to ensure that we can anchor these values that have founded the European project since its creation, for the dignity of every human being. This dignity goes through the rule of law, it goes through non-discrimination, it goes through respect for fundamental freedoms, it goes through the guarantees of fairness when we are faced with differences or questions. That is what I want to support today and which is probably one of the essential elements of this decision taken at the European Council: not a hair of the legal text of the conditionality mechanism has been affected by the decision. So, of course, I want to say this solemnly and forcefully, the European Council fully respects the division of responsibilities provided for by the treaties. In this context, we also assume our political role because this assembly, which brings together not only the Commission but also the 27 heads of state or government, has the responsibility to give political direction. And when we face difficulties, as is the case today, it is also our duty to take decisions to ensure that we can engage the European Union on the budgetary path, on the path of values and on the path to climate. Believe me that my wish, after a year of modest but exciting experience of working in cooperation, also with Parliament, is to remain committed throughout 2021 to full cooperation with all legitimate democratic institutions and, of course, also with the European Parliament to move Europe in the right direction. I conclude without triumphalism: we know the many challenges that are still before us - COVID-19, climate, digital agenda, social transition - and the implications for our fellow citizens who are also linked to these subjects. But more than ever I believe that, compared to a few months ago, in relation to this COVID-19 threat that has shaken us, which has shaken us, the European Union is standing. The European Union wants to be a quiet force, determined to act. The European Union is in the order and wants to be up to the task.
