name: Andrus Ansip (Renew)
text: Writing. – The use of EUROPEAN taxpayers' money in the Member States must be strictly targeted. The rule of law should be a prerequisite for the use of money. Procurement must be fair and transparent, investigation and judicial review must be independent. In order to repay the eu's joint loan, it is possible to increase member states' contributions to the joint budget, to cut budget expenditure in the post-crisis period, or to use additional own funds, or to use a combination of just three options. I consider it necessary to include additional own funds even without the obligation to repay the joint loan. I believe that the introduction of certain taxes, such as the introduction of a border tax on carbon, is necessary for the European Union as a whole and for the Member States individually, but it can only be effective as a common tax.

name: Άννα-Μισέλ Ασημακοπούλου (PPE)
text: Writing. – The recent Summit condemned another unilateral action by Turkey, in Varosia, which is added to the long list of provocative actions that violate the sovereign rights of Greece and Cyprus, as well as international law. The EU is proving timid and inadequate in extending sanctions immediately. By extending until March 2021 to assess our overall relationship with Turkey, the EU risks its geopolitical credibility. As the Greek Prime Minister, Kyriakos Mitsotakis, pointed out, sanctions are not "an end in itself." Their threat is a tool for Turkey to change its behaviour. Following us sanctions, Mr Erdogan asked Mr Michel to open a "new page" with the EU and resume talks on the basis of common interests. I would remind you, Mr Borrell, that, on the basis of the conclusions, a condition of a "positive agenda" with Turkey is its readiness "to resolve disputes through dialogue, in accordance with international law." If Turkey does not refrain from similar activities, then the EU's response can only be one: No dialogue with Turkey until March.

name: Marek Belka (S&D)
text: in writing. – The discussion we are having today is about three topics. First, we are not only speaking about the multiannual financial framework, which can be described as the roadmap for European social, green and pro-growth policies for the years. Second, it is not only about the rule of law conditionality which I have supported relentlessly for a very long time not only in speeches and interviews, but also in my work on various files, sometime resulting in strong criticism of my words and efforts. Yet the EU cannot be an ATM that one uses but is surprised if it does not want to work if one does not stick to the instructions. Third, a crucial point is that in front of our eyes we see the European Union becoming a true fiscal entity, with its own resources and a debt that might give a great stimulus for our economies after the COVID-19 crisis. These three main topics – socially friendly growth, the rule of law and unity should be the pillars of what we need to fight for in this House. A small victory happened during the last summit. Still, many more fights are to come. Long live Europe!

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – Dear President, President of the Commission, colleagues, a number of important agreements were adopted at the European Council. I would like to welcome all the agreement that has been found on the future multiannual perspective . The European Parliament has worked very hard to prepare mff-related documents for adoption once consensus on MFF is found. I myself am Parliament's rapporteur on the European Globalisation Fund and we will have the final multilateral negotiations on this Fund tonight. I am very pleased that Member States see a common interest in better coordination in this difficult period. Indeed, we all need more clarity and concerted action on how we will continue to live, what restrictions we can expect, what the requirements for travelers will be . So far, we see only the actions of individual Member States, which are caused by confusion and uncertainty. We must have more or less uniform rules and more information. I fully agree that COVID vaccines must be regarded as a public good and accessible to all without exception. I congratulate those Member States that have already declared free vaccination and this is a very responsible approach. In this difficult situation, we must remain focused and united and ensure the safety of our people so that we can return to normal life as soon as possible.

name: Marc Botenga (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Thank you so much. This new seven-year budget, if we were to assess it in the light of what the most right-wing parties wanted or what the European Council proposal was, we could say that this is a half-full glass. The health budget is less drugged. Research is less destitute. Unfortunately, that is not how a budget is assessed. The question cannot be: is this budget less worse than another? No. The question must be: does this budget respond to the social and climate emergency? Is this budget learning all the lessons from the health crisis? However, on the social side, we have no guarantee that the new European tax will not be borne by workers or break with the market. On the climate front, the targets have been raised, very well, but the means do not follow. And, from a health point of view, in the midst of a pandemic, we are facing a budget where the military side receives more than the health program. Really, is this the budget that people need for the next seven years? I don't believe it.

name: Joachim Stanisław Brudziński (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – We are meeting today to discuss in the EP the conclusions after the European Union Summit of 10 and 11 December, but also on very important issues that are closely linked to the findings of this summit: the Multiannual Financial Framework, the rule of law conditionality and own resources under the common budget.  And it is particularly worrying that once again in this House, instead of a constructive discussion, we hear a rebuke, especially to two independent and free nations. Instead of building on the compromise reached by the Council countries and using this agreement to tackle the challenges facing the whole Community at the end of 2020, last week's Council findings are openly undermined or even blackmailed by the EC, threatening to revoke it if it does not implement the Rule of Law Regulation!  Left-wing groups in this House unjustifiably accuse Poland of violating the rule of law and do not themselves respect the provisions of the treaties that underpin the EU. I will repeat: the EU is based on treaties and the Treaties state that each of the countries that make up the EU has the same value and dignity. There can therefore be no place for the terror of left-wing correctness, which at all costs is trying to impose Poland. Agreement, agreement and compromise are the cornerstones of the support and remedial action that EU citizens are waiting for more than sterily ideological disputes over time.

name: Sara Cerdas (S&D)
text: in writing. – Last week, the European Council reached an agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2021-2027. The European Parliament has spared no effort to secure a robust agreement, not only to respond to the crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, but also to ensure European cohesion and thus ensure that no region is left behind in the next 7 years.  The next MFF will play a key role for all regions, but I would like to point out the role it will play for the outermost regions, whether in mitigating the economic and social impacts of COVID-19 or in the dimension of support for policies in the most diverse sectors. A large percentage of the budget will be invested in cohesion and natural resources and the environment.  This clearly reflects the EU's priorities, not only in the willingness to recover and promote the development of the regions, but also in the willingness to move forward, focusing on the objectives of the European Ecological Pact and the development of additional efforts to tackle climate change, protect biodiversity, focus on the circular economy and boost renewable energy. In total, €1.8 billion will meet the needs of European citizens.

name: Josianne Cutajar (S&D)
text: in writing. – The agreement on the next MFF 2021-2027 by the European Parliament and the Council is crucial to the immediate start of our economy’s recovery phase, while taking into account the long-term perspective of the environmental and the digital transition. The amounts earmarked to Cohesion Policy as well as the financial resources for research, innovation and digital priorities will ensure, on the one side, the enhancement of the economic competitiveness of Europe in the global arena and, on the other side, the strengthening of the social dimension. The new MFF and the initiatives under the recovery instrument Next Generation Europe will be beneficial to workers and SMEs all over Europe, not least in Malta and Gozo. Many crucial sectors of our economy, including tourism and hospitality, need to heal from the wounds of the COVID19 crisis and to look forward towards taking the full potential of upcoming opportunities.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The Hungary won, Polish-Hungarian cooperation won, and the whole of Europe won. Thanks to the agreement reached at last week's European Council summit and the European Parliament's decision to strengthen the framework budget, Hungary defended the EU's financial resources for Hungarians. The agreement also confirmed that no political conditions can be made for the allocation and use of funding for Hungarians under EU treaties. With the agreement, we defended Hungary sovereignty. The right to decide for itself on all matters which fall within national competence. There can't be a single ideological or political issue in which anyone can impose their will on us. We can decide our own fate. On the issue of immigration, who we want to live with, or even the legislation on family affairs. The agreement also Hungary the honour of the Hungarians, since it is not possible to make accusations on the basis of any new legal norm without any basis. It is not possible for the political accusations made by the left to be reflected in the EU institutions. The Hungarian left has mobilised all its energy during the budget negotiations to work on how it can harm Hungary. He worked to take away and reduce subsidies in order to gain Hungary political advantage for himself at the expense of the hungarian parliament elections in 2022. The hungarian left's attempt was unsuccessful. By strengthening the agreement, Central Europe has gained a decisive influence in the development of important solutions.

name: Robert Hajšel (S&D)
text: Writing. – It is good that, before Christmas, we are going to approve not only the EU's seven-year budget, but also the Rescue Recovery Fund. In total, this amounts to more than EUR 1.8 trillion, an unprecedented amount that EU Member States could ever use to overcome the crisis period and develop their own. Thanks to the seven-year budget, Slovakia can also continue to build and rebuild infrastructure, be it the construction of motorways, the completion of sewers and the warming of buildings, but also investment in new technologies, science and research. However, the Slovak Government will also be able to invest in these areas from the newly created Recovery Fund. Its resources must be used mainly to kick-start a crisis-stricched economy, to support businesses shaken by the corona crisis, but also to modernise society as a whole thanks to the green and digital transformation. All these measures should aim to improve the quality of life of our citizens and strengthen the resilience of our industry and energy. Now it all depends on the Slovak Government how effectively it will use this money. I also consider it sensible to link the absorption of European money to respect for the rule of law and democracy under conditions approved by European leaders. European funds that come from the taxes of our citizens cannot be exploited for corruption or undermining democratic principles, but all states must be treated equally fairly.

name: Patryk Jaki (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The attempt to impose on Poland and Hungary, and in practice all NON-SUPERPOWER EU countries, a system for assessing their 'rule of law', in the absence of specific criteria, leads to the conclusion that these will be discretionary criteria, always adapted to the interests of the EU core powers Germany and France. This consent has given these powers the ability to punish governments opposed to their will to withdraw EU funds from them.  An instrument has been created to incite the public to punish countries against their governments with the intention of overthrowing them. Today, such actions are being carried out against two countries, but in the future they may also be directed against Greece, Spain, Italy and others. In principle, a regulation introducing legal conditionality changes the european Union's system out of treaty, which cannot be accepted.

name: Julie Lechanteux (ID)
text: In writing. This morning's debate, the 'common discussion on the conclusions of the European Council of 10 and 11 December 2020', looks like a catch-all containing the most diverse ideas to finally dodge important issues. And subjects that annoy, there would be many: 1) the complacency of the European Union in the face of Turkish arrogance; 2) contracts drawn up by the European Commission for the purchase of vaccines and of which no one is aware of the negotiated price or the exonerate liability clauses that pharmaceutical companies would benefit from; 3) the issue of the mutualisation of the European Union's debt in the stimulus package and a method of financing explicitly excluded by Articles 310 and 311 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and Article 17 of the Financial Regulation. On the other hand, we prefer to draw public attention to the alleged violations of the rule of law in Poland and Hungary, while we turn a blind eye to the fact that the President of the so-called Republic of Kosovo, the privileged interlocutor of the European Union for decades, has just been indicted and imprisoned for crimes against humanity! Double standards?

name: Benoît Lutgen (PPE)
text: In writing. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the saga of this regulation introducing a conditionality linked to the rule of law in access to European budgetary resources is finally over.  I am not alone in saying that the European Union is not an ATM. It is a club with strict rules, especially and above all for the respect of a base of values: the rule of law, i.e. an independent and effective judiciary, objective administrations, free media that are not subject to the dictates of power and an effective fight against corruption, especially when it concerns the most high-ranking people, are essential bases of European democracy. If these pillars are in danger, the European citizen cannot understand that the financial means can feed the policies of leaders who do not fight against, who are at the origin, or even, who benefit politically and financially from these practices.  The veto of the Polish and Hungarian governments, whose countries are now strongly challenged in these areas, was certainly just as revealing of their practices as any in-depth report on them. I am satisfied that the compromise reached, while regrettable, keeps the heart of the settlement intact.

name: Leszek Miller (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – It is good that Poland and Hungary have waived the explicit blackmail against their partners in the Union and have withdrawn their veto against the multiannual budget 2021-27 and the Reconstruction Fund. This was the only fair and loyal path for Member States to get out of the crisis. All the more so since it was clear from the outset that a veto on budgetary matters would not block the entry into force of the conditionality mechanism, which results from a regulation of the EP and the Council adopted by qualified majority.  Unfortunately, the Conclusions of the European Council go well beyond its mandate as provided for in the Treaties. I believe that attempting to interfere with the independence of the European Commission by obliging it not to propose measures under the budgetary conditionality mechanism until a possible ruling by the CJEU (therefore not applying EU law by then) and narrowing the scope of this regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council of the EU clearly violates the principle of institutional balance.  The legal text cannot be amended by the Conclusions of the European Council or by a unilateral declaration by the Commission. However, concerns remain as to whether certain obligations under the European Council conclusions will not affect the Commission's application of the Regulation in a full and effective manner. We should do everything to ensure that the Commission does not renry its obligations as guardian of the Treaties. In this context, it should be recalled that the Commission is subject to political scrutiny before the Parliament which appoints it and may ultimately dismiss it.

name: Andżelika Anna Możdżanowska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Last week we reached a compromise, thus concluding difficult negotiations on the European Union budget for the next seven years. This agreement not only gives Europeans a guarantee of further economic and economic development in Europe, but also an additional €750 billion package for reconstruction after the COVID-19 pandemic in next generation EU.  The conclusions of the last European Council also respect treaty law in the spirit of the sovereignty of EU Member States. The right for us to decide for ourselves what the future of our homelands should look like without subjecting them to unfair mechanisms based on discretionary and political criteria.  I would like to stress that Poland is not opposed and has never been against the use of the EU budget effectively and effectively, without fraud or irregularities, as reflected in the conclusions adopted. I therefore believe that the European Parliament and the European Commission should fully respect the arrangements between the Heads of State, withholding the application of the Conditionality Regulation until the Court of Justice of the European Union has taken a position and the European Commission has developed guidelines in consultation with the Member States. I believe that this is a huge step towards further building a Europe not only strong and economically competitive, but also a Europe of equality and mutual respect.

name: Urmas Paet (Renew)
text: Writing. – The long negotiations on the EU 2021-2027 financial framework have reached an overall compromise. A solution was found to go forward with the adoption of a framework starting next year, despite the manipulative behaviour of Poland and Hungary, which has hampered the adoption and implementation of financial measures. The total multiannual financial framework (MFF) was set at EUR 1 074.3 billion, with a budget of EUR 1 464.3 billion with the Recovery Facility. The main years of the MMF will focus on resolving the health crisis arising from the COVID-19 pandemic and improving the economic situation of the Member States. It should be noted, however, that funding for the crisis does not come at the expense of later years. The political compromise includes not only the financial framework but also the future own resources system and the new EU Recovery Facility (NextGenerationEU). Health, agriculture, climate, innovation, social affairs and education remain at the heart of the finals; in addition, the EU Neighbourhood Policy, the Instrument for Development and International Cooperation and the External Dimension of the Solidarity and Emergency Assistance Reserve were also increased.

name: Manuel Pizarro (S&D)
text: in writing. – I welcome vice-president Schinas' statements in presenting the COVID-19 strategy by the Commission. The principles of equal access, ensuring financial conditions to ensure that no one is left behind, as well as the safety of vaccines to be used, are of crucial importance. The speed required in the approval of vaccines can never neglect safety. The defense of health has to be guaranteed. I also welcome the EU's effort to provide less developed countries outside the EU with pandemic vaccines. The pandemic knows no borders and the EU must remain a pillar of solidarity.

name: Guido Reil (ID)
text: Writing. At this sitting, Parliament called for a strong social Europe. How far is Parliament actually from reality? The tightened climate measures approved by the European Council will further undermine our prosperity, on which our social benefits are based. This policy is taking the energy-intensive industries into the fore and accelerating deindustrialisation. According to a study presented by the German Chamber of Commerce and Industry in September 2020, these new requirements will lead to a further tightening of the European emissions trading system. The high CO2 prices have a major impact on industrial companies, which are, after all, part of this emissions trading scheme. If only companies within the European Union have to bear these costs, there is a very high risk that these companies will relocate their activities. So there is a risk of losing these companies to Germany and Europe, and greenhouse gas emissions will not be reduced, they will only be relocated. The CO2 target as a driver, the one-sided focus on electric vehicles with the war against the internal combustion engine has serious consequences for our employment. The imposed change to an electric motor can only be financed with drastic austerity programs and fewer staff. EU climate policy is responsible for cutting thousands of jobs in industry. This is an anti-social policy.

name: Domènec Ruiz Devesa (S&D)
text: in writing. – The agreement reached on 10 and 11 December 2020 at the European Council confirms an important milestone in the EU in approving the MFF, the Recovery Plan and the timetable for the introduction of new own resources together with the conditionality mechanism for respect for democratic values and the rule of law. Although the last obstacle has been overcome on 10 and 11 December, as the Hungarian-Polish veto withdrew to the multi-year budget, this has been achieved through a clear overreach of the European Council. Paragraph I.2.c) of the Opinion instructs the Commission that the regulation which makes the disbursement of European funding conditional on respect for the rule of law does not apply until the Court is given a possible appeal. Such an instruction constitutes a clear violation of Articles 15 (prohibition on the Commission from receiving instructions from other institutions), and 17 (non-legislative function of the European Council), to which the European Parliament must take appropriate measures. The Conference on the Future of Europe will have to examine how to re-translate the intergovernmental excesses seen since the euro crisis.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – One notes with satisfaction the conclusion of the MFF negotiations. We now have a seven—year budgetary framework for the EU. An extra recovery investment programme will enable Member States to counter the coronavirus recession. A rule—of—law procedure prevents the allocation of EU funds for purposes that contradict the Union’s fundamental values.  However, the underlying realities must also be highlighted. These are that: EU decision—making structures are not delivering timely responses to crisis situations; masked by the recovery programme, targets initially set by the European Commission and the European Parliament as resources needed to carry out the EU’s programme have by far not been reached; the European Council and the European Parliament diverge totally on how to seek solutions to Union challenges, such as on own resources; the European Parliament is fuelling the perception that it wants more taxation on citizens – does this improve its political standing?; there has been little real progress in designing rule—of—law evaluative processes that minimise politicisation.  Rather than a Conference on the Future of Europe, we need an intergovernmental conference to first identify the priorities by which to unlock the most important institutional issues.

name: Sylwia Spurek (Verts/ALE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Let us clarify two points. Firstly, the European Council does not have legislative powers. Therefore, no political declaration, no statement or promise has legal force, is a source of law, nor can it be regarded as an interpretation of the law. It is for the European Court of Justice to interpret the law solely.  Secondly, the European Council, the European Commission and Parliament must always exercise special care and integrity in public statements on human rights and the rule of law. Unfortunately, the Council's position adopted last week has undermined the long-standing work of the EU authorities to strengthen the Community legal system in order for Member State governments to uphold EU values. The signal that the conditionality mechanism could be frozen until the CJEU's decision was received as a capitulation to the Governments Polish And Hungarian Governments. The Council is well aware that such a decision, assuming it is legally binding at all, would result in the protection of the rights of EU citizens and citizens and the possibility of effectively enforcing compliance with EU values from Community governments by up to two or three years.  Particularly importantly and severely, this View of the Council was presented at a time when the governments of Polish and Hungary have not only drew from previous decisions against judicial freedom, the independence of civil society or those affecting the dignity of LGBT+ people, but are taking further political and legal decisions which constitute or are likely to constitute significant violations of our values.

name: Mihai Tudose (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted for the Multiannual Financial Framework, with the hope that EU funds, amounting to EUR 1 074.3 billion for the period 2021-2027, will reach where they are urgently needed as soon as possible: to those most affected by the pandemic crisis. The essence of the European budgetary effort must be to limit the proportions of the economic and social disaster triggered this year and to help Member States to relaunch their growth.  It is very important that the European Parliament is involved, together with the Council, in monitoring the management of recovery funds – EUR 750 billion, of which 390 billion are grants, which will complement the budget over the next seven years. In view of the debt to be contracted by the European Commission for the Recovery Fund, the EU's own resources become essential so that Member States, in their repayment effort, do not suffer burdensome increases in contributions to the Union budget.  This roadmap is therefore required for the introduction of new sources of EU direct revenue, such as the digital tax and the financial transaction tax. I also support the important supplementation, which the European Parliament forum now decides, for the budgets of the EU's landmark health, research and education programmes.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. Our community was attacked by the coronavirus at the same time and infected by illiberal populism. We have already demonstrated that global challenges such as epidemics and climate change cannot be individually responded to, and can only be solved jointly and in cooperation. We haven't found a cure for the illiberal mafia government, we've only found temporary treatment, but in time, we'll have an antidote to that. With the adoption of the budget and the entry into force of the rule of law mechanism, a new time will begin. I am proud that our European community has put together a budget and reconstruction package of historic importance that will provide meaningful assistance to the Member States and ensure development. This crisis is also an opportunity. As one of the initiators of the European Health Union, I consider it a priority that the amount of the budget for health programmes has been increased many times. An important achievement is the protection of the Erasmus+ budget, including, for example, the support of discovereu, the free Interrail rental programme I mentored. While Fidesz is at the height of its anti-EU propaganda campaign, over the next seven years more than FIFTEEN THOUSAND-BILLION FORINTS will arrive in Hungary, only 7,000-billion from cohesion funds alone. Agricultural policy will receive more than 4,200-billion EU subsidies, more than 80-billion for climate neutrality, but a significant amount will also be made available from the reconstruction package: more than 2,600-billion HUF of non-refundable aid. Orban and his mafia government risked that with a veto.

name: Bettina Vollath (S&D)
text: Writing. – By joining the EU, all Member States have committed themselves to respecting the rule of law as a fundamental principle. The EU is not just an economic community, it is a community of the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights. It was clear to all Member States when they joined the EU that there are not only perks, but also obligations and responsibilities. For example, when governments attack the independence of people whose job it is to verify the proper use of EU funds, such as prosecutors or fraud investigators, that becomes a problem. Because we have no interest in money leaking into corrupt structures. What we want is for the money to be used in the best possible way for people. For the receipt of EU funds, Member States have to ensure just that. The rule of law mechanism will not automatically bring democracy back to Hungary, Poland and other countries in Europe, but it will ensure that our funds can no longer be used unrestrainedly for the erosion of democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law. The rule of law mechanism is a great success for the citizens of Europe. We expect the EU Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, to start fully and consistently implementing this regulation from 1 January 2021.

name: Roberts Zīle (ECR)
text: Writing. – Honourable Mr President, this agreement on the multiannual budget proved to be a complex process, and its preparation and coordination took a long time and patience. At the same time, in the context of the difficulties caused by the Covid-19 pandemic, the agreement on the specific lines of the budget was more complex than ever. We have indeed faced unprecedented challenges this year, and I am pleased that we can expect 2021 with some clarity on this issue. Budget implementation will create its own difficulties, but during the negotiations it was excellent to find an opportunity to provide additional funding for some Union programmes. In particular, for Erasmus+ and Horizon projects, both of which are largely in the interests of Latvia. Moreover, the budget will also have a positive impact on the Rail Baltica project, which will connect Latvia with its Baltic neighbours. I call on my colleagues to support the implementation and rapid implementation of this budget.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. – The agreement between the European Council and the European Parliament to adopt a powerful recovery package with a solidarity dimension of the European Union in the face of the impact of the pandemic is a sign of the vitality of the European project.  In this agreement, I would point out the overall volume of EUR 1.8 billion allocated to the various programmes, the EUR 16 billion with which Parliament was able to strengthen flagship programmes in the last round of negotiations, the inclusion of a formal and mandatory plan for the introduction of own resources as a key tool of the solidarity financing model, the establishment of ambitious cross-cutting targets for allocated funds to climate and biodiversity policies , strengthening the european Parliament's monitoring and action capacity as a budgetary authority and the adoption of a mechanism to guarantee the rule of law. A rapid and effective implementation process is now essential, enabling, through energy transition, digital transition and modernisation of the economy, to combat inequalities, create wealth and jobs and position the European Union as a positive benchmark in the new global geopolitical framework.

name: Presidente. –
text: The sitting is resumed. We are opening the award ceremony for the Sakharov Prize 2020, which this year is awarded to the democratic opposition in Belarus. We can see a video right away, all together. (dissemination in the Hemicycle of a presentation video) Ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, Presidents of the institutions, authorities, I am truly honoured and pleased to welcome the winners of the European Parliament's Sakharov Prize, who represent the democratic opposition in Belarus.  I welcome Sviatlana Tsikanouskaya and Veronika Tsepkala, who are with me in the gallery. I also welcome Siarhei Dyleuski, Ales Bialiatski and Stisapan Putsila. I would also like to extend a warm welcome to Svetlana Alexievich, who is following the ceremony at a distance, as so many Members of the European Parliament are doing. Unfortunately, not everyone was able to be present. Sergei Tikhanovsky is still in prison for the sole crime of wanting to exercise his right to stand for election, as is Mikola Statkevich and Maria Kalesnikava, who are represented by their family members – Maria Adamovic and Tatiana Khomich.  I invite you to reflect on this award. I am very honoured to have you with me in the European Parliament today. In the last six months you have shown the world, dear ladies and gentlemen, what it really means not to give up. You have defended your rights and do not give up fighting, despite pain, suffering and fear. As Nelson Mandela said: courage is not the absence of fear, but the triumph over fear. Your courage and the strength of your spirit paved the way for the revolution that took power in the country in 2020. We honour you, we pay tribute to you today for your endurance and perseverance. For us, the sakharov prize ceremony is an important moment. Human rights defenders and democracy activists are our role models and, as a sign of the utmost respect we have for them, we have organised this Prize, despite the current difficulties. Members of Parliament from all 27 countries of the Union are partly connected to us at a distance and partly present in the Chamber to congratulate you on your testimony. In the age of social media, it is difficult to keep information hidden and I would like to convey to you, but also to all citizens of Belarus, the message that we, as well as the whole world, are fully aware of what is happening in your country. We see your courage, the courage of women. We see the suffering of your people. Let's see the unspeakable abuses. Let's see the violence. Your aspiration and determination to live in a democratic country, in freedom, and all this inspires us. We support you in your struggle. I would like to pay a special tribute to our winners and the strength you have shown.  However brutal and ruthless the methods of government are and how strong the fear they are of instilling, this cannot resist the prolonged protests of citizens of the whole people of Belarus. "We woke up and we will not fall asleep again" you said during the Unity Marches. It's true. Belarus is no longer afraid. The authorities, the government, have also understood this. The people of Belarus have shown that no authoritarianism can block change and the opening of a new chapter in the history of your country.  Ladies and gentlemen, your fight is our struggle and this is not the first time that we have awarded a collective prize to Sakharov Prize winners. In 2004, the European Parliament awarded the Sakharov Prize to the Belarusian Association of Journalists for defending press freedom. I would also like to congratulate them on their constant commitment and the spirit of sacrifice to inform and inform us and on the spirit of sacrifice they have shown over the last few months. In 2006, we awarded the prize to Aliaksandr Milinkevich, who was the leader of the united democratic opposition forces in Belarus at the time, and we remember him fondly. The European Union's message is clear: Belarusian citizens must fully enjoy their democratic rights and live in freedom. We in the European Union have a moral duty to support them. We also have a duty to support all those around the world who are fighting your own struggle.  Before giving the floor to Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya, I would also like to congratulate and send a message of support to this year's finalists: the environmental activists of Guapinol and Berta Cáceres of Honduras and Monsignor Najeeb Michaeel, Archbishop of Mosul. I cannot finish without mentioning our Sakharov Prize finalists who are still in prison and demanding their release: Ilham Tothi, Raif Badawi, Nasrin Sotoudeh, who has just been imprisoned again by the Iranian authorities, despite its fragile, very fragile health conditions. We greet them all and we are always and constantly close to them. (Applause) Thank you for your attention and your participation and I now give the floor to Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya for her speech.

name: Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya
text: Winner of the 2020 Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought. – Mr President, Members of the European Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, this year the world has seen Belarus awakening. We stood for our freedom, dignity, national identity, but we faced the brutal nature of the regime. Two realities confronted. Peaceful bright people with flags and flowers against armed men in black hiding their faces behind balaclavas. We feel humbled that our story of resistance touched so many people across the globe. On your way to the European Parliament, you could see a shocking photo on the façade of the building. A woman in white falling down to her knees before the riot police. It’s not a wartime movie scene, it’s a ‘peaceful’ Belarus in 2020. People locked inside a cathedral by special forces. It’s a ‘peaceful’ Belarus. Detainees marked with different colours to determine how severely they should be beaten by the police officers, and it is a ‘peaceful’ Belarus. Deliberately infecting prisoners with COVID—19. It is a ‘peaceful’ Belarus – in the heart of Europe. Fear is what one feels hearing those stories. I am one of the thousands of Belarusians who used to be afraid. An invisible wall of fear was built around us. This wall of fear held us back for almost three decades. But this year everything has changed. This year we united in our aspiration for change. United, we believed that this wall of fear can be taken down, brick by brick. United, we overcome our fear on the way to freedom, day by day, week by week, month by month. The photo on the façade of the European Parliament is not a story of fear, it is a story of hope, courage and freedom. For the third time in 20 years, Belarusians have been honoured with the Sakharov Freedom of Thought Prize. What is better recognition that we are freethinkers? What is better motivation for us to keep going? We are bound to win, and we will win. A simple wish to walk freely in the streets of our cities and towns keeps us going. Desire to celebrate holidays with our families keeps us going. The dream of a better future for Belarus keeps us going. A Belarus where justice and truth prevail. A Belarus that our children can be proud of. I am endlessly honoured to speak in front of you. We receive this prize together with the brave Belarusians Maria Kalesnikava, Veranika Tsapkala, Sviatlana Aleksievich, Volha Kavalkova, Ales Bialiatski, Mikola Statkevich, Siarhei Tsikhanouski, Siarhei Dyleuski, Stsiapan Putsila and all the members of the Coordination Council. (Applause) But we are not alone here today. Beside us are thousands of Belarusians who inspire us, give us strength and hope. Many of them are not here today. Our courageous women, workers, students, doctors, teachers, lawyers, writers, journalists and activists – all of them are in Belarus fighting for our freedom. It is to them that this prize belongs. (Applause) Last Sunday, I met with our distinguished Belarusian writer Sviatlana Aleksievich, who is with us remotely today. Sviatlana received the Nobel Prize for telling the stories of a ‘little big man’ in the light of historic events. This is how she created ‘a monument to suffering and courage in our time’. For me, such a ‘little big man’ is each and every Belarusian who takes part in this peaceful protest against violence and lawlessness. Each of them is a hero. Each of them is an example of courage, compassion, and dignity to me.  Freedom is made of simple things and often requires fearless resistance. For Aliaksandr Taraikouski it was protesting against the falsified election. He stood raising his bare hands in front of men with rifles and he was shot dead. Fearless he was. For the artist Raman Bandarenka it was going out to protect the national symbols in the courtyard where neighbours gather. He was kidnapped and beaten to death in the police office. Fearless he was. The journalist Katsiaryna Barysevich and the doctor Artsiom Sarokin dared to unveil the truth about this murder by the regime cronies. This bravery cost their freedom. Fearless they are. Natalia Hershe could not stay on the sidelines and came back to Belarus after living abroad for many years. Out of solidarity, she participated in peaceful protests and was sentenced to two and a half years in prison for taking the mask off the police. Fearless she is. Freedom is victory over fear. Seventy-three-year-old Nina Baginskaya … (Applause)  … has become a symbol of our struggle. Despite countless detentions and intimidation, she has been protesting against injustice for 30 years already, often alone. Truly free she is. Mikola Statkevich … (Applause) … was a presidential candidate in the 2010 election. He has been imprisoned and recognised as a political prisoner for the third time in 15 years. His commitment to the values of freedom is something that no prison sentence can take away. Truly free he is. My friend Maria Kalesnikava tore up her passport and chose prison over exile to remain in Belarus, with our people. Truly free she is. My thoughts are with her every day.  My husband Siarhei Tsikhanouski decided to tell the truth no matter the cost. For that, he was thrown in jail on trumped—up charges. He has not seen his family for seven months already. But these are only some of the courageous people our European nation is extremely proud of. Freedom is also universal. Belarusians have been marching every week since the 9 August election. They march for their future and the future of those who cannot be there. They march for the freedom and dignity of Belarusians, of Europeans – yours, and ours. Without a free Belarus, Europe is not fully free either. We ask Europe and the whole world to stand with Belarus. We call on Europe to be braver in their decisions and support the people of Belarus now, not tomorrow, and not sometime in the future. Standing for human rights and democracy is not interference but is the duty of each self—respecting country. Your solidarity and your voice are important but it is actions that matter. Please, be there for the Belarusians and be assured that Belarusians will do the same for you in the future. I have only one wish this year. I want every Belarusian who is now in jail or was forced to live in exile to return home. The third Sakharov Prize will mark a new beginning for Belarus. Nelson Mandela, who received the prize in 1988 together with the Soviet dissident Anatoly Marchenko, said: ‘I learned that courage was not the absence of fear, but the triumph over it’. He believed that brave are those who conquer their fear. Only united we can fully conquer fear on our long path to freedom and build a new Belarus. Every country has its own path to democracy, and this is ours. Long live Europe! Long live Belarus! Zhiv’e Bielarus! (Sustained applause)

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is a statement by the Council and the Commission on the preparation of the EU strategy for the Covid19 vaccine, including its external dimension (2020/2911(RSP)).
