And because of the viral situation, I'd like to ask anyone who wants to speak without a mask to come to the pulpit in advance.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We are currently experiencing a health crisis of enormous proportions worldwide, especially in Europe. This morning in the debate, we have sent out a clear signal that we want to come out of this crisis in solidarity and together, that we are also trying to mitigate the serious social and economic consequences of the pandemic as best we can, with a large programme, with a multiannual financial framework – that is, with a lot of money, but also with a great deal of commitment. We all know, of course, that this is not enough. In these days and weeks, we are witnessing a second, sometimes even a third wave, in many Member States of the European Union. In my own country, Germany, we have more deaths than ever before. Today a sad climax: 950 people. Several hundred thousand people have already died, millions of people have been infected, some of them seriously ill. We have introduced restrictive measures in our Member States to protect citizens as best we can. But hopefully one remedy will soon help us say that we have contained this pandemic – and that is a vaccine. Only with a vaccine can we defeat the virus.  But there is still a great deal to be done. Since this virus does not have a passport, as this virus does not care about national borders, it was necessary from the outset to develop European strategies. We have achieved this in the area of the vaccine. First of all, my great respect and gratitude to researchers, but also to companies and companies from Europe, who have helped us to develop such a vaccine in the shortest possible time. Two vaccines will soon be approved in the EU. We know that only the development, production and introduction of safe and effective vaccines will be a lasting and sustainable solution to the fight against this serious health crisis. And we have opted for a common approach.  I know that there has been a great deal of unrest in our people, given that some countries – the United Kingdom, Israel, but also the United States of America – have already been approved. However, we did not focus on national strategies, but we said that we are going down a common European path through the EMA. We do not want us to enter into competition between the Member States, but we want the vaccine to be made available to all citizens of the European Union at the same time.  This will not be easy, because, of course, at the beginning of the authorisation – which I hope will take place very soon, possibly as early as 21 December – there are not yet so many vaccines that all the people who need it can be vaccinated immediately. This is also disputed. There are discussions in all Member States about who should be vaccinated first. And there are also states that are discussing whether to introduce a vaccination obligation. Vaccination plans always focus on: the elderly, medical professionals, people with pre-existing conditions. These are the main target groups that are given priority in Member States' vaccination strategies. I am extremely grateful to the Commission for having managed to generate an option for almost two billion doses of vaccines. It is therefore clear that, no matter where people live in the European Union, with our joint effort, coordinated by the Commission, they will really be given the protection to which they are entitled. I hope that these accesses will also be made available as free of charge as possible. Let me mention another important point, which is already a bit upside down when it comes to the question of who is the first and who is the fastest: communication. I do not know how you are doing, honourable Members. I am sometimes stunned by campaigns – including social media – about how people are scared because they should be vaccinated. The disease itself is certainly far more dangerous than any vaccination. However, we must be careful not to give the impression that the appropriate authorisation procedures and authorisation procedures are subject to political influence. We must trust citizens. We must convince them that as many people as possible who get vaccinated – 60 to 70 per cent – will only provide a guarantee that an entire society can be protected. Finally, the collection of post-authorisation and post-authorisation monitoring data Formal monitoring studies are key elements of a vaccination programme so that all people know what can happen in the event of side effects, and so that new fears do not arise there. We have to take this very, very seriously.  Honourable Members, but we have not only taken care of the security and protection of our own citizens in the EU, but we have, of course, also looked at the global dimension of this crisis, and I am grateful for that too. The Commission has joined the so-called COVAX facility and has contributed to this. In other words, we are showing international solidarity. We know that only if, in our neighbourhood, in the states with which we cooperate, where there is an exchange, this serious pandemic can be combated just as successfully. It should therefore also be in our interest that we help, both financially and organisationally, with those states that do not have the financial capacity that the European Union is grateful to have. So it is our overarching common goal to accelerate the development, production, and delivery of vaccines so that everyone – everywhere – has access to vaccines at affordable prices. Yes, vaccinations are not a miracle weapon either, allowing us to return to a normal life immediately. The old normal will no longer exist – there will have to be a new normal. We must continue to work together for the common good and continue to abide by the rules we have agreed in our daily lives: wear a mask, keep their distance, comply with hygiene rules and, above all, take responsibility for our neighbours, for our loved ones, even now during the Christmas holidays, even if we find it difficult. As politicians, we should also lead by example.

name: Margaritis Schinas
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, we are living in turbulent times. The health situation across Europe is extremely uncertain. The impact of the pandemic on our economies and societies is unprecedented and the threat unfortunately remains very real. As we approach this end-of-year holiday season, it is only natural that families and friends wish to travel and spend time together. But make no mistake. We are still very much in the middle of this pandemic and we cannot afford to be complacent. Yet the prospect of a COVID—19 vaccine provides some light at the end of the tunnel. Allow me to stress once again the three golden principles that are guiding the Commission’s work in this field, namely equal access, affordability and safety. In recent months, the Commission has been negotiating intensively to build a diversified portfolio of vaccines at fair prices and is working at full speed to review their safety and make them available.  As you know, in Europe the decision on the authorisation of these vaccines is not in the hands of politicians nor the hands of institutions, but in the hands of independent regulatory agencies, in our case the European Medicines Agency (EMA). As I think you know by now, we are aiming to authorise the Pfizer—BioNTech vaccine by the end of the year. The EMA has already announced its intention to provide for an authorisation next Monday. If this is the case, the Commission is ready to provide the formal authorisation and placing on the market in supersonic fast procedures. In two days we can do the formal authorisation that normally, for this type of authorisation for placing on the market, can take two months. This means that this vaccine will be the Christmas gift for all Europeans if everything goes well. We also know that, before mid—January, we will also have an opinion from EMA on the other vaccine by Moderna. EMA is also now currently conducting rolling reviews on the vaccines produced by AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson. Once authorised, we will secure access to these vaccines for all EU citizens at the same time. But, for this to happen, Member States need to have all preparations in place and activate their national vaccination plans. We already provided guidance in October in that respect and this is being done in a coordinated manner. All our Member States are making great efforts to put in place robust vaccination plans. These include identification of priority groups to be vaccinated first, ensuring solid supply chains, logistics and infrastructure, training staff or developing electronic vaccination registries. There is still much to do and certainly many challenges to overcome, but the Commission stands ready and committed to help.  We are also providing support to Member States on communication around COVID—19 vaccines. As someone who fought against the virus, not only as a Member of the College, but also from a hospital bed, I wish to say that nobody should underestimate or negate the threat we are facing nor the usefulness of the vaccines. It is important that our citizens understand that we have not cut corners on safety and the vaccines do not pose a risk. Europe will only authorise vaccines for our citizens under the sole condition that they are safe. Building trust is of course key to ensure a high vaccination uptake and everybody knows by now that this is, and should be, our collective priority, because at the end of the day vaccines in themselves do not save lives. Vaccination does.  We must also remember that the European Union has a duty to the world. We know that no one is safe until everyone is safe and that is why we aim to ensure universal and equitable access not only to vaccines, but also to diagnostics and therapeutics for all, including the most vulnerable populations living in the poorest and most fragile countries. No one should and no one will be left behind. Europe has been leading the international solidarity efforts to establish the COVAX Facility. Team Europe, our institutions and our Member States, is now the largest contributor to COVAX to purchase and deliver vaccines to low-income countries as part of a collective objective to buy two billion vaccine doses by the end of next year. The European Union is deeply and firmly committed to multilateralism and joint coordination with multilateral institutions.  We are the European Union and in our values we are guided by the principles of solidarity and unity of purpose. As such, we will donate under the Team Europe approach – we and our Member States – a proportion of our vaccines to our Western Balkan partners in our neighbourhood, as well as for humanitarian assistance and to frontline health workers in the poorest countries. This is a temporary solution to bridge the time gap until vaccines from COVAX are broadly available and we are currently working on a methodology to make this happen.  We will also ensure – and I know that this is an issue of interest to many of you – that intellectual property rights are not an obstacle to universal access to vaccines, including in developing countries that have no production capacity or have limited financial resources. Last but not least, as the European Union, we need to advance rapidly on getting our own European health union off the ground. Several proposals are already on the table. Others will follow. I am grateful to this House for your consistent support for all these initiatives from the Commission.  I wish to emphasise the importance of remaining vigilant. Whilst we advance our work on vaccines – and we are now getting to the later stage – it is essential to keep reducing transmission of the virus through effective testing, contact tracing and isolation until the immediate danger is behind us. Responsibility, both collective and individual, remains essential to get our lives and businesses restarted, but also to reduce the pressure on our heroic healthcare workers, whose immense efforts in the last months need to be not only acknowledged, but compensated. Our European way of life has been severely tested in these eight months, but it did not collapse. It resisted. Our resilient societies, our resilient health systems and the universality of our schools and education proved that, although we are tested we can manage, and we did manage because we are in this together.  (Applause)

name: Peter Liese
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has done so. I am very angry today, but also very grateful. I am very grateful to the intensive care workers who are fighting for the lives of people with COVID-19 and other diseases throughout Europe and who are really at the limit, physically and mentally. They deserve our solidarity, and we owe it to them that we all follow the rules and that we, as politicians, make rules that help. And we should certainly not look to the United Kingdom, but to Ireland. Ireland has managed to have the lowest numbers in Europe and that some patients have not died of COVID-19 at all on some days. I am very angry with the people who are still trivialising Corona and saying that there is no need for a vaccine at all. However, I am also angry at some politicians and, unfortunately, some journalists who are discrediting the process of admission in Europe, mostly without any knowledge of the facts – unfortunately not only tabloid media, but also actually serious media. And I am grateful to those who really work day and night at companies such as BioNTech or the European Medicines Agency, so that we can get a safe vaccine as soon as possible. On the night of Monday to Tuesday, people worked through to get this done, and slander against the Brussels bureaucrats or the European agencies is out of place here. Keep going! Help us! We support you, dear companies and dear employees at the European Medicines Agency!

name: Iratxe García Pérez
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Mr Vice-President, the second wave of the pandemic has already led to more deaths than the first. Since 1 August, the virus has mewed the lives of more than 152,000 people in Europe, above 136,000 in the first wave. Our memory will always be with the victims and their families.  After months of suffering and pain we see the light at the end of the tunnel. Thanks to the Commission's concerted action and the support of the Member States, we have achieved equitable access to vaccine doses. This achievement demonstrates what we are able to do when we speak and work with one voice.  We must now articulate a common vaccination process. And as we continue to fight the virus, we must provide an equally ambitious response in the field of international cooperation. If we want to be effective, vaccines must be produced at scale, distributed equally around the world, and affordable for all. Ensuring that all people can be immunized at the same time is a humanitarian imperative and a precondition for ensuring well-being.  The European Union's support for the global CONSORTIUM COVAX, which is promoted by the World Health Organization, is essential for vaccinating in the most vulnerable countries. As long as the disease resists somewhere, it will remain a threat to other places. The implementation of strong and inclusive health systems should be a priority of the Health Union, but also a fundamental pillar of our development cooperation programmes. Now, more than at any other time in the last seventy years, we need to draw inspiration from the principles of solidarity and international cooperation.  Let us make it possible for the history of the European Union vaccine to be the story of a success that will bring hope back to European citizens and also to the rest of humanity.

name: María Soraya Rodríguez Ramos
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, it has indeed been vaccines that has enabled us to fight infections and prevent millions of deaths, and it will be the vaccine or COVID-19 vaccines that can actually end this pandemic.  That is why I would like to tell the Commission that the common vaccination strategy is the story of success, because thanks to this strategy we have been able to make pre-contacts, we have been able to make joint purchases; I hope that we will be able to do joint vaccinations in that week of the vaccination discussed in the Council.  And this has been the case because never in history have we known public-private funding of such magnitude to accelerate the discovery of a drug. We have invested a lot of public money to accelerate technical knowledge that already existed, and it is important that European citizens know this, because the best vaccination strategy is for citizens to be vaccinated and, for citizens to be vaccinated, they have to have confidence.  And the European Union has been away from the 'marketing coup'. We have not made any political careers, because we have not eliminated any safety requirements for vaccines to be approved. That is why the European Medicines Agency works with scientific and technical criteria, out of pressure or any other political time. Where the European vaccine is authorised in the Member States, it shall be a safe vaccine. No one will be safe as long as we're not all safe. That is why, Commissioner, COVAX is good, but it is not enough. When there is so much public money, we can really make this vaccine a public, global, universal good for all.

name: Silvia Sardone
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, have vaccination campaigns started in the United Kingdom, the United States, Russia and China and the European Union? Late, again, waiting for a green disk from the European Medicines Agency. As with the management of the pandemic, the European Union has acted badly, without coordination and with little transparency. Each country acts independently, for example, Italy because of a bad government will probably come last in the administration of vaccines due to lack of needles, syringes and nurses.  Returning to Europe, we would like clarity and seriousness. What are the agreements with pharmaceutical companies? What are the conditions of purchase? What is the price? Who is to blame if unforeseen side effects emerge? How long will the virus cover last? And how much the degree of protection for our elderly? In short, as I said, we need clarity, we need seriousness. The citizens, in general, cannot suffer yet another failure of the European Union.

name: Tilly Metz
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, I have several questions for you today. The first is Europe. When are you going to allow Members to consult the contracts signed with the industry so that we can at least see the liability clauses before the vaccination of citizens begins?  As for the external dimension of the strategy, by denying within the WTO the possibility for some countries to lift the intellectual property rights of medical products linked to COVID-19, the Union has reneged on its commitment to help countries with the lowest incomes.  So I ask the Commission to justify this position and, to avoid any pretences when the Commission advocates voluntary mechanisms, can it tell us whether any of the companies that have signed early purchase contracts for the production of the vaccine, and therefore have benefited from European funds, have committed to support the Union's initiative for non-exclusive licences?

name: Joanna Kopcińska
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Vaccination against COVID-19 is due to start as early as January in many European Union countries, including my country, Poland. On the one hand, Member States will face logistical problems and, on the other hand, the European Commission, through the work of the executive agencies, should ensure the safety, quality and effectiveness of the vaccine. I agree that the development, authorisation and provision of vaccines can be accelerated, but that quality, safety and efficacy standards must remain at the highest level. I wanted to ask how the European Commission intends to support the Member States m.in. in organising and facilitating the logistics of the anaddressive infrastructure in the cold chain, chilled transport and the storage capacity of vaccines. As part of the fight against widespread disinformation, does the Commission plan to launch a campaign immediately before the announcement of national coronavirus vaccination plans on the benefits and importance of these vaccinations in building public confidence?

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: for the GUE/NGL group. – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, let me thank you from the outset. To thank all the health workers, social services in crises, firefighters, police officers who kept us afloat for three quarters of the year and managed this pandemic in Europe for three quarters of a year. It wasn't because of the politicians. It was thanks to every single individual who got involved in the fight against COVID and helped us survive it. Secondly, let me ask the Commissioner for answers. I, like my colleague, would like to ask: how is it possible that the European Union did not support an amendment to the TRIPS Agreement, which will allow cheap and massive production of the vaccine? Are we just thinking about ourselves? Are we thinking only of the citizens of the European Union? In May, you announced how you wanted patent rights to be universal, so that they would not be charged, so that they could be used. And you just didn't do that in a particular vote. And thirdly, when we're talking about a vaccine campaign. If you want to campaign and inform citizens about the positives of vaccination, you need to give all the information. The Commission does not do this, it is not transparent. We don't know what's going to happen with the hidden flaws. And these are all things that discredit all your campaigns. Please correct this decision, because that is the only way we can give serious information to citizens and they will trust us.

name: Κώστας Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Madam President, the start of vaccinations does not balance the huge shortcomings in public health systems and inadequate government measures. The European Union and governments, in the context of health-goods, see the vaccine as another source of profitability for monopolies. Safe pharmaceutical companies were subsidised for all stages, from research, manufacturing, pre-purchase to the disposal of the vaccine. They hide the research results from each other, preventing interdisciplinary cooperation that does not fit into capitalist competition.  A question mark is why the issue of treatments and medicines that appear to be contributing against the virus is not being promoted. Questions arise that the Commission is evading the request to deposit documents of the European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece in order to give the contracts concluded by the European Union with the companies, in particular so that the people know responsibly what has been agreed with their own money.  Vaccines should be safe and free. Against conspiracy theories, they must be a conscious act and a requirement of the people to protect their health according to the recommendations of scientists and at the suggestion of doctors.

name: Bartosz Arłukowicz (PPE).
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa Every day Europe mourns thousands of deaths. In each of our countries, we mourn hundreds of new deaths every day, and we are all waiting for this vaccine as a light in the tunnel, but in reality this vaccine is only the first stage, because the real effects of COVID-19 will be observed all over Europe in the coming months. In the coming months, we will see an increasing number of deaths due to delayed cancer diagnosis, delayed preventive examinations, lack of access.  Europe's health systems have stood up and we have to face this challenge today. The Union's priorities are changing drastically rapidly and we are facing global health challenges. We need to build a European Health Union, a common mechanism for responding rapidly to crises, buying medicines and vaccines, building procedures, dealing with the real problems that we face. COVID-19 de facto laid bare the fact that without close cooperation and joint action Poland, Europe, the world are helpless. The sooner we understand that we need to act together, the safer we will survive.

name: Udo Bullmann (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The vaccines are coming – that's the good news! But will they also be available for every man and woman? Will they be distributed anywhere? Will we be able to create the medical and practical conditions all over the world? The question marks behind these sentences – that's the negative message that we can't answer yet. And let me underline one thing: yes, we can overcome this virus! And we are full of gratitude to all those who help us to do this in our home countries, to do it in Europe. But we will only succeed if we do it globally, if we manage to achieve a global strategy, a global vaccination policy. And to do that, we need an additional USD 5 billion next year so that we can get our foot in the Global South and help the people there. No, patents must not fail! We urgently need agreements with companies – yes – and, where necessary, exceptional rules so that vaccines can be made available everywhere. And for the European Commission, Commissioner, it is a huge opportunity to include a global health policy as a core element in next year's work programme and to make this crisis, with the guidance and active help of the European Union, a huge opportunity for a global health policy in the interests of all of us. That is the moral, that is the medical imperative.

name: José Ramón Bauzá Díaz (Renew).
text: – Madam President, let me address you in this debate not as a politician, but as a pharmacist, who since the first minute of the pandemic has been at the front line precisely in the fight against coronavirus.  These months have been a real nightmare. Perhaps from the walls of this Chamber we have only had to endure that the restaurants are locked up and wear these masks, but in the real world we have suffered a real hell.  Hundreds of absolutely terrified patients have passed through my pharmacy because they did not know if, depending on their pathology, they could have, if they were infected, the possibility or misfortune of death. There have been thousands of toilets who have been on the front line of fire without the right necessary protective equipment, and many of my colleagues have passed away.  And in the meantime, we were in this Chamber debating supposed emergencies that, from a reality point of view, have only once been, the best, worrying. Coronavirus is an emergency. That's why, ladies and gentlemen, the vaccine is the end of the nightmare. The logistical challenge of transport and conservation has been unprecedented on our continent since World War II. So that, precisely, is the real test of fire for the European project. Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, it is time for us all to live up to it.

name: Jean-Lin Lacapelle (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe has been suffering the consequences of coronavirus for almost a year. To put an end to this disease, we need a health policy that is protective, effective and transparent: the opposite of what the Commission is proposing.  Firstly, while Europeans have never been so opposed to vaccination, you have decided to make negotiations with laboratories opaque and not to make public the clauses that absolve them of liability for side effects. You have prevented us from consulting these many contracts other than in a room without a telephone, paper or pen. I am still waiting for an access permit to date. This decision prevents us from carrying out our mandate as parliamentarians, we, who are democratically elected, who are not.  Second, you are ready to validate the commercialization of messenger RNA vaccines, which have never been used in a mass vaccination campaign, after only a few weeks of testing. In view of the urgency of the situation and the precautionary principle, we should, like the Chinese and the Russians, favour more conventional vaccines, similar to the flu vaccine, for example, in order to protect the health of Europeans, in order also to avoid any conflict of interest. I hope, Madam President, that we will not be the turkey of farce, by being the last to receive and deploy the vaccine against coronavirus.

name: Anna Cavazzini (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, we are indeed facing a global pandemic and it is in all our interests to get the vaccine as fast as possible in all corners of the world. While I really welcome the Commission’s effort with ACT-A and with COVAX, there is a much faster and more just solution that the Commission is blocking at the moment. A high numbers of countries from the global south want the WTO to temporarily waive intellectual property rights for the COVID-19 vaccine and medicine because they fear for the lives of their citizens. And yet the Commission has been firm in upholding this, saying this would put in question ongoing investments by the pharma companies, but this ludicrous argument ignores that so much public money has been put into developing a vaccine.  I urge the Commission to rethink their position and to show the world that saving lives is more important than saving an outdated model of intellectual property rights. Access to medicine for all is a human right.

name: Marc Botenga (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, there are pivotal moments that define us and today is one of them. No company, we know, has the means to provide a vaccine, to produce enough vaccines for everyone. Around 100 countries are asking the European Union to be able to produce the vaccine themselves, in order to avoid unnecessary victims, in order to prevent second-class, second-class citizens from entering the disease. And what is the response of the European Union, the European Commission? "No." Coldly, dryly, we will leave these vaccines in the hands of multinational pharmaceutical companies. That, to me, is unacceptable. To the protection of all, we prefer to defend the profits of a few. Yet there is a way to do it. Because if not, this selfish decision, which prefers profit, will forever be a stain on the coat of arms of your Europe. We need a different Europe, the citizens are asking us to do so. Let's defend the vaccine as a common public good. We are all entitled to it, we are all entitled to protection and we will fight for it. Dear European Commission, please listen to us.

name: Cindy Franssen (PPE).
text: Mr President, this crisis is the seeds of enhanced cooperation in the field of public health. We've come a long way in the last few months, but we're not there yet. It is now up to the European Medicines Agency to take the time needed to deliver proper work.  Safety and quality of the vaccine go before speed. It is also very important that we pay due attention to vulnerable groups and do additional research into the effects. I would also call on the Member States to follow the EU's guidelines for further roll-out as much as possible. We can miss a new patchwork of national strategies and certain nationalist strategies as a toothache.  We also need to look beyond our own borders, because the virus does not stop at our border. I am very pleased that the European Union is playing a strong role in the WTO's partnership to also give the poorest countries access to the vaccine. As the Director of the World Health Organization put it: the real question is not whether the world can afford to share, but whether the world can afford not to.  The EU vaccination strategy has worked. Let us be positive: in less than a year's time we will have workable, safe and high-quality vaccines at an affordable price. We must take this positive boost into a stronger cooperation towards a European health union. I think we need to build trust now and everything will be fine.

name: Heléne Fritzon (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on his excellent We are in the midst of a pandemic, and it affects us all. The situation is very serious not only in europe but also in the rest of the world. It is therefore very gratifying that we now actually have – as it was described – a light in the tunnel, and that we now have good news about effective vaccines against covid-19.  Without a doubt, EU cooperation has been absolutely crucial in giving all EUROPEAN citizens access to a vaccine so quickly. Eu-wide procurement is a good example of cooperation within the EU. We are now moving quickly into a phase where allocation and distribution are important for the work on member states' national vaccination plans. It is a national competence to carry out vaccinations. However, it is quite clear that the Commission's proposal for a new EU vaccine strategy for covid-19 is of great value so that vaccinations are both equal and fair. We have clearly experienced that the virus knows no borders whatsoever. That is why it is so important that the vaccine is not hindered by any limits either. The vaccine should benefit everyone.

name: Charles Goerens (Renew).
text: Madam President, I come here first to share the anger expressed earlier by our colleague Peter Liese, when he rebelled against the avalanche of untruths, semi-truths and, quite frankly, lies about the new vaccine, which is a moment of hope at the end of the year when all the other indicators are in the red. That's finally good news. Secondly, I believe that we must remain true to our principles of solidarity and that we must also remain committed to the imperatives of multilateralism, which has been put to a severe test over the past four years. It is time for Europe to also show its willingness to share this new acquisition against the virus by developing countries. I would like to end - in response to those who will tell us that, from this point of view, Europe would be called upon to squander its money around the world - with a quote from Louis Michel, former Development Commissioner: "If you do not do it out of solidarity, at least do it out of interest", because everything we invest in access to vaccines for developing countries , it is also in our interest that we do so.

name: Luisa Regimenti (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the EMA would be ready to grant authorisation to the Pfizer vaccine as early as 23 December and start vaccinations immediately after Christmas. The news gives us a sigh of relief, but at the same time there is an urgent need to reassure citizens about the safety conditions of the vaccine. In Britain, where the vaccine is already in use, allergic reactions have been found and the Director of the EMA has also admitted that the effects and risks on pregnancy, lactation, fertility and children are not known. Despite the assurances of the producers, it is clear that an in-service trial has been carried out and we would not like to be faced with unexpected events once the vaccine has been inoculated. We therefore wish, for optimal and voluntary vaccination coverage, to be able to express a conscious consensus, matured with accurate, transparent and consistent information. Let us remember that the lives of our citizens and the socio-economic future of our society are at stake.

name: Anne-Sophie Pelletier (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, a few months ago the Commission informed us that a vaccine would be put in place within 12 to 18 months. Congratulations, record broken. Between speed and haste, I believe that European citizens deserve better. If your strategy is in line with that of remdesivir, a treatment deemed ineffective by WHO, let me have some questions.  However, it is not a question of being the spokesperson for anti-vaccines. These qualifications also undermine the substantive debate and objectivity that is due to us when the health of our fellow citizens is involved. But everywhere, professionals and scientists rightly question themselves. The Commission does not provide any guarantees for the order of vaccines from pharmaceutical groups such as Pfizer, no in-depth studies have been issued, and our fellow citizens are not guinea pigs.  For people at risk, who are a priority, cases of side effects raise concerns about the liability of pharmaceutical groups. You would say that the early purchase contracts provide for Member States to compensate the manufacturer for liability incurred under certain conditions. But what are they, Commissioner?  For all these reasons, while your strategy requires trust, we would like to see more transparency.

name: David McAllister (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I remember in June, when we were discussing the external dimension of COVID-19 in this House for the first time, many colleagues emphasised this virus knows no borders, and we have heard similar statements today. And indeed, this is still valid today, and it is in particular valid for the EU’s strategy on the COVID-19 vaccination. This pandemic constitutes a challenge around the world. Consequently, it has to be tackled globally and by international cooperation. Most crucial is that we follow a systematic and coordinated global approach that focuses on international cooperation with like-minded partners to ensure universal and timely access to a vaccine and also focuses on solidarity with the most vulnerable countries to facilitate access to vaccines in a fair manner for all people across the world. The COVID-19 pandemic is a wake-up call for the need for a strong and more united EU foreign security policy. It is high time for us as the European Union to promote more decisively our values and our interests worldwide. Our COVID-19 vaccination strategy will be an important component on the way to this goal.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, you yourself have used the words that President Von der Leyen has already used: Europe will only be safe when the world is safe. Let that be just the point where the European Commission – I think – is now making a mark and is not ambitious enough.  Recent studies show that two-thirds of the world's population will not have access to a vaccine by 2022. That is frankly unacceptable. Above all, we should not make ourselves dependent on a revenue model of a few pharmaceutical companies and offer the medicines every opportunity to ensure that there is more production. Because that is the problem, of course. Covax is good but insufficient. What we need is more production.  So I only have one message today. Commissioner, make sure that you look openly at that question of that waiver from those different countries in the world and make sure that we start negotiations to see under what conditions such a waiver should allow everyone in the world access to the vaccines next year.

name: Vlad Gheorghe (Renew).
text: – Madam President, the COVID-19 pandemic has put us to the test, but at the same time it has also reminded us of what the European Union really means. It means the power that comes from solidarity, it means the power of "together."  The vaccine that will save millions of lives is the best evidence of cooperation between the Member States and the European institutions, and its distribution will be the best proof of what the European Union does for every citizen.  Now, more than ever, europeans need to have confidence in joint construction. That is why I have suggested further measures to secure vaccine doses to combat and prevent criminal activity and, together with my colleagues, have called for a joint communication plan. It is essential that the correct and complete information about the vaccine reaches every European citizen. It is our responsibility to respond to legitimate concerns from the outset, because we need every citizen, together with the European Union, to rebuild together.

name: Roman Haider (ID).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Obviously, the principle of hope alone, neither the EU nor the vast majority of Member States have had a sensible strategy to deal with COVID-19. Economies are going down the drain, and Europe is stumbling from one lockdown to the next. So now we have the vaccine – the miracle cure in which our political failures see their only hope. We can only really hope for a reasonably effective vaccine before Europe is finally bankrupt.  But Corona is not just a time of political failure. Corona is also a time of resurgence of authoritarian politics. Unfortunately, the curtailment of fundamental civil rights is already part of the good tone in Europe. That is why there are already initial calls for a vaccination obligation. I strongly disagree with that. Vaccinations are an excellent medical achievement. I therefore really hope for a safe and effective vaccine. However, the decision-making power over one's own body and one's own health must remain untouched. An obligation to vaccinate, whether directly or indirectly, is incompatible with this fundamental right of every human being.

name: Pernille Weiss (PPE).
text: Madam. President! 2020 has been a tough year and it has been a long year. The global pandemic has been and is a dark chapter in recent European history. But there's light at the end of the tunnel. We are very close to the EMA approving the various covid-19 vaccines for us Europeans. Throughout the crisis, the Commission has led the way, working closely with the Member States to negotiate the vaccines. It's a health sign of our ability to take good care of each other. Cooperation when it really matters. Vaccines are an important part of our security policy, in line with defence budgets, foreign policy and protection against cyberattacks. It is therefore worrying that certain Member States are in contact with third countries with which we do not normally cooperate, especially for safety reasons. Countries such as China and Russia are joking in the wings, and they are serious candidates for supplying vaccines to countries in the European Union that do not hold out too well to signal a particular mix of disloyalty, mistrust and double standards towards the health and safety interests of the Community. I would therefore like to ask whether, in the Commission's opinion, this is a good priority? How does the Commission view the potential security risk and the risk that this could have a negative impact on the will and courage of Europeans and citizens to be vaccinated?

name: Jytte Guteland (S&D).
text: – Madam President, dear Commissioner, we welcome the positive news that the first Covid vaccine might be approved earlier than expected, just in a few days. That’s really great. Europe has been one of the first and most hit regions in the world by COVID-19. Now that a functioning vaccine might be at hand, the whole world is looking at Europe to look at the level of transparency, accuracy and fairness that we will be able to apply during this very sensitive phase of distributing the vaccine. We are entering a new phase in the health crisis. However, there is no doubt that we are still in a health crisis, that we really need solutions urgently. We can be proud that the process to authorise the vaccine has been in record time, but without any compromising on the safety of the vaccine. The decision will be taken off the back of rigorous scientific process with adequate and sufficient data, to ensure that patients will have access to vaccines which are safe, effective and of good quality. But now we need to guarantee sufficient transparency as well in the next step to come, to ensure full confidence that the EU citizens are protected as a whole.

name: Edina Tóth (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support We are going through extremely difficult months and we need a little more patience until the coronavirus vaccine is available to all citizens of the European Union. But we can see the light at the end of the tunnel. Researchers, pharmaceutical manufacturers and the European Medicines Agency are working to develop and authorise effective and safe vaccination against the coronavirus. However, this raises old-new questions, namely the increase in anti-vaccine and anti-vaccination, and the questioning of the effectiveness and safety of the future vaccine. I believe that anti-vaccination movements can greatly influence and hinder the success of future vaccination. The solution would still be effective education, evidence-based health education, but unfortunately we do not have enough time, so I consider it of the utmost importance to prepare the EU strategy for the coronavirus vaccine, of which I hope will be part of a comprehensive communication strategy.

name: Bernd Lange (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work he has At the end of the debate, when it is actually clear that next year 50% of vaccines will be reserved for only 14% of the population – especially in the industrialised countries – the question arises as to how we can use the global trade regime to ensure supplies for all people. Therefore, three questions that you can clearly answer in the affirmative or no: will the EU, the Commission and the Council, abandon the harsh 'no' to a wto discussion on a relaxation of patent protection, a waiver, towards 100 developing countries? Secondly, will the Commission, if there is to be an application for compulsory licences, if it becomes necessary to allow compulsory licences, support them in order to really start production? This is not always the case, logically, but it can be. Will the support be there? And the final question is this: will the Commission and the Council make sponsorships compulsory for production in developing countries – such as AstraZeneca, with other companies – with the companies with which there are already contracts, so that production can also take place there?

name: Margaritis Schinas
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, Minister, thank you all for your interventions. Let me start with the three areas where I think we all agree before addressing some of the specific points raised. First, we all agree that the arrival of the COVID—19 vaccines does not mean that the pandemic is over. I think this is a strong message that should come out of this debate. We also agree on the importance of the three golden principles that we set out some time ago, namely equal access, affordability and safety of vaccines. And finally, we do agree on something that is particularly important these days, that in Europe we do not improvise on safety. Nor do we cut corners on the procedures that we have established, and the European model is that independent regulatory authorities have to do their job and politicians have to base their authorisation on sound, scientific evidence. I think the strong support that all of you have shown through this process says a lot.  Let me now address three specific issues where some of you have raised the need for further explanations from the Commission. Let me start first with the issue of confidentiality. We fully recognise the importance of transparency in this process. Transparency is a guiding principle in all our work in the Commission. It is publicly known with which companies we have been negotiating, what type of vaccines and the process through which we have been doing this together with our Member States, but it should be clear that we are indeed bound by the confidentiality clauses in these contracts. Disclosure of any confidential information at this moment in time could undermine the ongoing negotiations we have with other companies, and, as the European Union, we would need to keep as strong a negotiating position as possible.  We cannot unilaterally decide to disclose confidential information such as information on prices under these contracts unless the companies themselves agree to it, and we are in the middle of negotiations which are still ongoing. However, on many occasions Commissioner Kyriakides has confirmed to you in this House that the Commission is ready within the contractual constraints and according to the rules for transmission of confidential information to the European Parliament to make information from these contracts available to nominated Members of this Parliament with specific arrangements once the sensitive ongoing negotiations are concluded.  Another issue that has been raised by many of you is the issue of TRIPS and intellectual property protections. I want to repeat in this House that we will ensure that intellectual property rights are not an obstacle to the universal access to vaccines, including in developing countries that do not have the means to cope. Mr Lange asked for a ‘yes’ or ‘no’ answer, but I think my answer is pretty clear – that there is an ongoing discussion now in the WTO on the idea of a waiver of intellectual property rights and protections and there are also important flexibilities so that the relevant trade agreement – TRIPS – could allow us to reach the same objective. But, in any case, I want to assure everybody here that we are ready to continue this discussion so that nothing stands in the way and that more vaccines get to where they’re needed worldwide.  Finally, some of you have raised the issue of campaigns. Of course, we are very sensitive and we shall encourage our Member States to continue with their national plans and public information campaigns on vaccination. We will have our own European campaign, if you like, which will be unveiled in the days to come. We do not compete with our Member States on information, but I think we can provide a useful complement to this process. And to that extent we will not only explain factually the benefits of the vaccines that are put on the market, but we would also like to mobilise important role models, important known Europeans. Some UEFA players have already kindly accepted our invitation to participate in our European campaigns, so stay tuned for that.  The rollout of the vaccines is a challenge of historic dimensions. This is a historic moment, and after all the work we’ve been doing for months, I am convinced that we’ll get it right.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The debate here in the European Parliament today has shown the breadth of all the arguments: some people are not fast enough, others are already warning – even though the vaccine has not yet been approved – of the possible consequences. Yes, honourable Members, we live in a risky situation, and if every headache remedy has side effects, it cannot, of course, be ruled out that this vaccine has side effects. No one says that this is without side effects. We have invested a great deal of money to shorten the usually long years it takes to allow a vaccine to be researched, to research it, to spend many billions to give people the protection they desperately need.  Nobody in the Council, no one in the Commission, no one who is in his right mind, stands here and claims that there is any solution that promises a 100% guarantee. I am somewhat perplexed when some Members – especially in this segment – stand here and arrogantly ignore the various strategies of the Member States, even though nationalists and populists in particular have repeatedly given the impression that it is a flu, a sniff that immediately goes away, that it is not necessary to take it seriously, that wearing a mask is superfluous. All these demonstrations, where human lives were risked, where police officers were used for violence, there is also a political responsibility for this. I would like to make that clear here.  I cannot just sit down here and say: yes, I have a 100% solution here. What we are doing at the moment remains fraught with risks. My only request to you, honourable Members, is that, at least here, we manage to have a fact-based, reason-based, fear-free discussion as political leaders in national governments, in the Commission, but also in Parliament. Out there, outside this room, the fear is already great enough – we are experiencing this in our own families. That is why we have a responsibility to ensure security, as far as a democracy can achieve. Of course, there are others who are faster. The Russians and the Chinese who vaccinate everywhere. Yes, but these are vaccines, which are not yet approved by us. I am seeing this myself: a Member has just mentioned how some media, but also some political forces, are playing their game with it. We just take our time. We must guarantee that – even if research into this vaccine has gone very, very quickly, really revolutionaryfast – then in the end the risks, including in terms of side effects, are responsible.  Some Members have made it clear once again, for very, very good reasons, that it cannot be enough for us in the European Union to look at ourselves alone. There must always be a strategy for how we can contribute globally. So far, however, I have the impression that the European Union – and everything is still better to do – has already done a great deal. After all, the connection to the so-called COVAX facility also includes specific financial contributions, and some EUR 860 million has already been paid by the EU and the Member States. Of course, it will also be a question of creating the conditions for – once again – access to this vaccine not to be measured by how economically strong a country is, how much money citizens have, or where they live in this world. We, as the European Union, must set an example in this respect. I have understood this message today, and I want to reassure you that we, as the Council, are also trying to live up to this responsibility.  Ladies and gentlemen, there is still a very, very long way to go. If the first vaccine can finally be used, then it is not a miracle weapon either. But it is a very, very important signal to take people's worries away. The economic and social consequences are, of course, devastating. But in the end, the protection of every human being counts, and every day counts. Every day that the vaccine is approved earlier can contribute to fewer people dying. I am pleased to have heard this message of priority health protection as a message from almost all the speeches, so thank you very much. This debate has made an important contribution to making the European Union's responsibility in this serious health crisis impressively clear. But we don't just talk, we act. This has been the case in recent weeks and months have also been expressed very impressively.
