name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. – The importance, importance and strength of the European Union can be seen these days. Without joint action by unified EU states, coronavirus vaccines would not have been available to Germans or French people for a long time to come. For Slovaks, not at all. Thanks to the EU, our citizens will be protected among the first, at the same time as germans, Luxembourgers, Swedes or Czechs. Since I am not indifferent to people with weakened immunity and many other diseases, I will definitely get vaccinated.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: Written. – Mr President, the coronavirus pandemic has tested the European Union's ability to act and its fundamental principles. There is much to learn from the crisis for the future. However, the Commission has managed to do relatively well in the coronavirus crisis on issues where it has decision-making powers and opportunities for action. The clearest example of this is the vaccines currently under discussion. It is thanks to the European Union that large investments in vaccine research and rapid joint agreements on the purchase of vaccines have been possible. Neither Member State alone could have achieved, especially on such a timetable. We would like this to be visible in the future, not only as a greater appreciation of European cooperation, but also in science and research. At the same time, I must say that I am disappointed with the coordination between the Member States, particularly with regard to travel restrictions. The coronavirus will be with us for a long time to come, and it is absolutely essential that member states should be able to act more uniformly in the future in order to contain the pandemic. Cooperation between Member States is key to the most effective and fair distribution of vaccines and to respond to vaccine criticality. The Commission's new opening of the Health Union and the larger EU4Health programme will contribute to closer cooperation in the fight against health threats. The coronavirus is a global crisis to respond to which we need not only action at EU level, but also global cooperation. The European Union must take responsibility in this situation so that the distribution of vaccines can also be made possible in the poorest countries. The Commission is therefore rightly committed to supporting the development of vaccines, medicines and diagnostics and the equal global availability of vaccines. The COVAX vaccine mechanism, which promotes equal access to vaccines, now requires the support of both the EU and the Member States, plays an important role.

name: Stefania Zambelli (ID)
text: in writing. It is certainly a good thing that the European Commission has concluded contracts with several pharmaceutical companies for the purchase and supply at European level of doses of coronavirus vaccine.  However, a number of unanswered questions about vaccines still a few days before the start of the vaccination campaign. First of all the temperature: Pfizer's vaccine will have to be stored at minus 80 degrees.  How will the cold chain be guaranteed from the moment of production of the vaccine until its administration? In addition, the methods of administration are not yet clear: how many doses should be given to people? Other questions concern vaccine prices. Why do some cost EUR 30 per dose, while others, such as the Oxford vaccine, do not even cost three euros? And on time, why has the UK already started vaccinating for over a week, while in the European Union they continue to tell us vague and unsciable dates about approval by the EMA?  Another worrying aspect is also the liability for damage caused by vaccines: why will the Member States have to compensate pharmaceutical companies for this issue? There are many, too many questions that we are still waiting for a certain answer to.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the EU Security Union Strategy (2020/2791(SDR)). I would remind honourable Members that for all the debates during this part-session there is no catch-the-eye procedure, nor will 'blue card' questions be accepted. Remote intervention is also planned from the European Parliament's Liaison Offices in the Member States.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, I would like to thank the Our joint work to improve the security of our citizens and our societies is a constant test, and with the Council conclusions on internal security and a European police partnership, we have launched a necessary process of reflection in order to significantly improve the future of internal security, especially with regard to the European dimension. And we have also succeeded in doing so: together with the joint ministerial declaration of November, which was adopted in the wake of the terrorist attacks in several Member States, and the Council resolution on encryption, this sets the direction for the work that lies ahead, and that will not be easy. We have identified a number of priorities, including instruments that have already been agreed, but which need to be implemented more quickly and better, and, of course, instruments where there are gaps and which need to be better addressed in the future. The recent terrorist attacks, honourable Members, have made it alarmingly clear that the online environment plays a very central role in providing a platform and a voice for violent extremism and terrorism. Several current and future initiatives are making a significant contribution to combating this development, such as the proposal on online terrorist content, on which political agreement has just been reached thanks to excellent cooperation between the European Parliament and the Council, as well as the recent proposal on the Digital Services Act. The attacks have also highlighted the test faced by law enforcement, judicial and security authorities in accessing digital information, especially when it is encrypted. We must ensure that our law enforcement and judicial authorities have the same legitimate powers and powers online and offline. It is in everyone's interest, honourable Members, that the Internet should not become a lawless area or a safe haven for criminals, and there is actually a very, very simple rule, honourable Members, which we simply have to implement: what is illegal offline is and must also be illegal online. Of course, we need to find a balance here, and we do not have a panacea for that either. This is also subject to democratic debate, especially with civil society, with experts. This is the balance between security on the one hand and fundamental rights in data protection on the other. And for this we need a broad inclusive and transparent dialogue between the various leaders, and in this area, of course, the European Union also has a very important role to play in this, also because of cross-border crime. Likewise, the use of artificial intelligence, access to data, the use of big data in law enforcement and internal security are relevant aspects that we need to address very quickly. I would also like to highlight our agencies, which play a very important role in this, in a forward-looking and responsible security agency that also supports the Member States in their tasks. We need to see how we can ensure that all law enforcement officers have access to all the information they need, how we can get more out of the wealth of information already available in our information systems, how we can work together more concretely and exchange information more efficiently across borders every day. Now perhaps some of you will say, 'Yes, why are you talking like this? Could have been done a long time ago." Yes! It is also, of course, essentially due to the fact that internal security issues are one of the core competences of the Member States. And there are no automatisms. And, of course, we need to be more preventive here. And we must also learn from serious crimes, especially from the horrific acts of terrorism, because we must of course recognise that these are not national phenomena; these are international phenomena, they are European phenomena. The implementation of all these measures, which I have now mentioned only very briefly, is part of the wider effort to contribute to the Union's objective, enshrined in the Treaties, of providing citizens with a common area of freedom, security and justice. This area, without internal borders, in which the free movement of people is guaranteed – especially now in this serious pandemic – is the purpose of the Schengen area. However, this Schengen area can only will then be permanently preserved in a crisis-ridden and terror-stricken world if we improve security cooperation, put it on a new footing, so that freedom and freedom of movement are guaranteed in the long term.

name: Margaritis Schinas
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me tell you how delighted I am to be able to switch from one pillar of the European way of life, normally public health, to another – security.  I welcome this resolution that we’re discussing today. The threats that we face today are many and varied, but they have something in common: they are fast moving, cross—border and cross—sectoral. Most of them work across borders, across national borders, across the distinction between online and offline and across the divide of internal and external security. All this points to the very simple fact that we need a joined—up European approach to cope with this evolving landscape of threats, and this is exactly what we did last July when we presented our new EU Security Union Strategy to be coherent and comprehensive, to break down the many barriers and many silos that stand in the way of the EU delivering security to citizens.  This strategy is our ambition for the coordinated work for the next five years, and we want it to be understood as a single roof underneath which we can build an edifice with individual rooms, that are now being constructed. These range from combating terrorism and organised crime to preventing and detecting hybrid threats, increasing the resilience of our critical infrastructure, promoting cybersecurity and fostering research and innovation. So I can only therefore welcome the opportunity that you give us through this resolution to be able to discuss our work in these areas.  Before I go into the design and implementation of the single roof, let me tell you how important we consider the issue and the place of fundamental rights in security policy. This is the touchstone for all our work and is indispensable as our common purpose. I do not see fundamental rights, being in charge of the Security Union, as an accessory or something that we have to visit ex post. I think that the issue of fundamental rights is a precondition before contemplating any security measures and there are ways to compromise and conciliate these two objectives, which are not as antithetical as some people want to make us believe. Let me now come to implementation. Implementation of the new Security Union started immediately on the day of its adoption, with a presentation on the agenda for the fight against drugs and action against firearms, that was also in the previous Commission. Last week we took another major step forward – the EU agenda on counter—terrorism following the heinous attacks in France and in Vienna. We want to strengthen the EU’s work to add value to Member States’ responsibilities, to anticipate, prevent, protect from and respond to terrorists. It sets out very concrete actions to help us do precisely that and we have also accompanied this proposal with another one for a reinforced mandate for Europol to be able to cope with these new types of threat. Europol, as you know, functions as police cooperation. With our proposal for a new mandate they can do much more.  Let me also welcome the – I would say historic – agreement reached last week on the regulation on terrorist content online. This is something that we need, and it was long overdue. Just three hours ago today, the Commission announced the strengthening of our cybersecurity strategy, which is most and foremost about security. Cybersecurity is not simply a consideration for a market, it’s not a consideration for businesses, it’s a consideration for society and the way we protect our people. The new cybersecurity strategy also includes two legislative proposals for the revision of our tools that need modernisation, like the Network and Information Systems Directive (NIS), and the critical infrastructure, the physical infrastructure. Both these proposals have been presented today. So there our idea is to reinforce and modernise anything that we can do to cope with cyber threats and cyber attacks.  Let me also highlight the importance of enforcement in all of this. For the first time, in the new NIS directive, we have specifically introduced the possibility for fines to facilitate enforcement and make sure that everybody plays by the rules. Last week, we also adopted a product which is very popular in this House – the progress report under the Security Union. This was the first progress report of this Commission and it shows that a lot has been done to support Member States in the past year. But we need to keep the momentum, and the citizens rightly expect not only pledges but also delivery.  There is much discussion and debate on whether this community EU action in the area of security is something that makes the European Union compete against our Member States. I think the Minister put it very right: we do not compete with anyone, we complement and produce added value to allow for the European Union to dissipate, organise and respond to these security threats.

name: Jeroen Lenaers
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, we have a strong set of security rules in place at EU level, but they are only good when they are effectively implemented. These were the words of Commissioner Schinas last week on the presentation of the progress report, and I think it’s the key message that we also need to put out here today. Because he’s right: a lot of work has been done in the past years. We have worked on the EU’s information systems and their interoperability; we have worked on combating terrorism, on protecting borders, on combating child abuse. And yet we see here that the regulations and the directives are in place, but we still have to read – and this is so frustrating – that, for instance, when it comes to the implementation of the anti-terror directive, huge gaps are still there; that there are infringement procedures against 23 Member States for not properly following the rules on tackling child abuse. This is, quite frankly, unacceptable, and we need to make sure that the eagerness with which we adopt rules is at least matched by the eagerness with which these rules are implemented, and that is a call on the Member States. So I strongly support the Commission’s approach on focusing relentlessly on implementation and enforcement. But next to implementation, additional efforts are absolutely needed. European citizens count on and expect us to deliver on security. We need to strengthen Europol’s mandate to be better equipped for today’s security challenges. We need to have more and better information-sharing between Member States. We need to have a better protection for societies against hybrid threats and foreign interference and disinformation, and we need to find a way to make sure that encryption continues to protect our privacy but no longer provides a shield for criminal behaviour. We must stand together against those who want to destroy our European way of life, and for that you can always count on the support of the EPP Group.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on 24 July 2020, the Commission adopted its Communication on the EU Strategy for a Security Union, to which the Council of Home Ministers, meeting on 14 December, has made its contribution to better protecting the security rights of European citizens.  And I would like to stress that security is a right in itself, a fundamental right enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union in the same article as the fundamental right to freedom and on an equal footing with it.  This Commission Communication places four strategic bets: the future, changing threats, terrorism and organised crime — of course!— and a safe ecosystem which envisages immediate or ongoing initiatives: those relating to the criminal prosecution of child sexual abuse, drugs and, of course, the trafficking in firearms.  But this European Parliament is speaking out in this debate. In the committee I chair — the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs — we have discussed this Commission Communication and made our contribution by pointing out, of course, the commitment to the fundamental rights and founding values of the Union, but also the need to shore up the fight against terrorism and the implementation and implementation of existing legislation , because there is anti-terrorism legislation adopted by this European Parliament.  There is European criminal law: there is an anti-terrorism directive in force, 2012; there is a 2011 Directive against child sexual abuse and child pornography; and a 2012 Victim Protection Directive.  But stressing the importance of implementation and implementation, it is important that we also be minded at the need to strengthen our commitment to terror and organized crime, against child sexual abuse, against trafficking in human beings on dangerous migration routes and, of course, against drugs. And, there, the Commission has effectively committed itself to a new counter-terrorism agenda, with a new anti-drug agenda, with a new cybersecurity agenda. And the committee I chair undertakes to complete the legislative work on the Regulation on online terrorist content. But finally, I would like to make a reference to the institutional dimension, because there are agencies that are operational and subject to the scrutiny of this European Parliament: Europol, CEPOL (the Agency for Police Training) and Eurojust.  Today I participated in the inaugural platform conference to combat the encryption used by organized crime: Europol Joint Research Centre Decryption Platform.  And it is important that this whole constellation of agencies be used thoroughly together with Pr'm to strengthen police cooperation, in a European architecture that has to ensure the interoperability of data in the pursuit of crime and cross-border criminality of European scope.

name: Fabienne Keller
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Minister of State, Vice-President of the Commission MargarusS Schinus, in the fight against crime and terrorism, citizens expect a strong Europe. I would like to focus on Europol. We welcome the Commission's proposals to strengthen Europol's mandate. The operational coordination of national police services to stop criminals and terrorists who play the borders is strategic. But with my Group Renew Europe, we are advocating more ambitious measures to make Europol the real armed arm of the Union in the fight against terrorism and organised crime, a real European FBI. We propose to increase Europol's powers to collect police data and produce joint analyses between Member States, to increase Europol's leadership role in cross-border investigations and to enable the surveillance of foreign fighters on European soil. I would also like, Mr Vice-President, to share a strong concern about the adequate funding of these measures. The European security agencies - Europol, but also Frontex, Cepol and EASO, mentioned at the time by President Lopez Aguilar - are given new missions, but they do not have the budgets, or above all the sufficient staff. Let's be more consistent. Ladies and gentlemen, we need a strong security policy against terrorism, against organised crime, to better meet the expectations of our fellow Europeans.

name: Annalisa Tardino
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the Commission has certainly started from good intentions, because it says in the communication that everything possible must be done to protect our citizens. Those who would not agree, moreover, are precisely what we expect from a European security strategy.  We have heard so many fine words, but they do not translate into action, and the resolution we are voting on today is a testimony to this. Despite the fact that there are some proposals that we can support, aimed at combating organised crime more effectively, the text is a victim of left-wing ideologies, usually focusing on references to disinformation, the role of NGOs or budget increases for European agencies and institutions.  On the other hand, it is only thanks to us that the text mentions, for example, Islamic terrorism which, given in hand, represents, to him, the greatest threat to our security, having claimed the deaths that we have mourned in recent years throughout Europe, such as those in Strasbourg in 2018. Citizens' security must instead be controls at Europe's external borders so as not to allow events such as those in Nice to happen again. We must focus on combating serious crime, tackling the problems at its root and in a concrete way, something that Parliament unfortunately does not do today, lacking courage and intellectual honesty. We are strongly calling for a sudden change of direction.

name: Saskia Bricmont
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, being and feeling safe in the anxious and upsetting context we are currently experiencing is fundamental and involves resilience in the face of terrorism and all forms of crime, but also confidence in our institutions and in law enforcement, guarantors of our fundamental freedoms and our rights in the face of arbitrariness both online and offline.  It is inequality, gender and intra-family violence, police violence, racist and xenophobic crimes, respect for the rule of law and corruption that must be tackled, among other things. Security challenges must be addressed through the prism of education, culture and socio-economic policies, in short, Articles 2 and 3 of the Treaty on the European Union. Parliament calls on the Commission to include these dimensions in its strategy.  With this in mind, the reform of Europol, but also the strengthening of the counter-terrorism agenda without an assessment of security policies and their impact on fundamental rights and without enhanced democratic control, are not acceptable. An ever-increasingly secure agenda, which satisfies populist appetites for tighter border controls, the human consequences of which shame Europe. Drone enthusiasts to establish a policy of mass surveillance worthy of the most authoritarian regimes on the planet and cooperation with non-democratic states; finally, a global security that has global only the name.  This agenda takes the path that terrorists and extremists want to push us in spite of respect for individual freedoms and fundamental rights. Let us be clear: we do not accept that the European Union should take this route.

name: Assita Kanko
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the threats around us evolve very fast, but our response is way too slow. The terror attacks of recent months and years were mostly perpetrated by Islamic extremists acting alone. We need, of course, a stronger role for Europol and more effective cross-border information sharing but this is not enough. It must be matched with measures that tackle the heart of a dangerous ideology that permeates our society – radical Islam. This is why the Commission and Member States are right to strengthen their efforts to tackle radicalisation. We must take steps to root out those who use religion and ideology to incite acts of violence. In order to do that we must cast aside political correctness and understand that defending our values must be central to any action. We need the resources, political will and policies, but above all, we need courage – the courage to be proud of who we are, the courage to defend our society and way of life. This renewed security union must deliver that.

name: Mick Wallace
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, this resolution highlights that terrorism aims to threaten democracy in Europe and European values. A lot of our security concerns come from western destabilisation of countries outside our borders so, if we’re really worried about security, why do we keep supporting US imperialism and their endless wars?   In 2019, Israeli Defence Forces killed 133 Palestinians, 28 of them children. Why didn’t we stop the Association Agreement with Israel? Why don’t we stop Member States from selling arms to Saudi and UAE, who are committing genocide in Yemen? Over 100 000 children have died in that war and we don’t even want to talk about it in here. Why did we support the NATO bombing and destruction of Libya and the displacement of millions that came back to haunt us? The truth be told, the people of Europe want security all right. They want the security of a home but, in 2018, the EU Member States spent EUR 78 billion on housing and over EUR 200 billion on arms and defence. Three times more. They want security of housing, affordable health care and education. If we want security, we should stop the militarisation of Europe. And I also suggest that the EU comes out more strongly and condemns the war crimes of Abiy Ahmed in Ethiopia or we’ll be looking at hundreds of thousands more wanting to cross the Mediterranean.

name: Antoni Comín i Oliveres (NI).
text: President, Commissioner, you have said that the Union is fighting terrorism in the name of democracy. And yet we need the security forces that are fighting this fight to be firmly committed to democratic principles. In September, Germany suspended 29 police officers for participating in Nazi cats. "The fight against the extreme right is part of the DNA of the German police," police officials said.  But in Spain, on the other hand, sympathy for the far right dominates with impunity part of the police and army. Today, three hours ago, we read the images of Spanish soldiers making Nazi salutes and singing the anthem of the military division that Franco sent to Hitler. Today, a significant part of the Spanish security forces has a very clear ideological bias against the Catalan national minority.  You are all, as European citizens, concerned with the objective of making the security forces of all our states impeccably democratic. The main threat to the rule of law in Europe does not come from Poland or Hungary. She's from Brussels. It is the shameful silence of the European institutions in the face of violations of the rule of law in Spain. There she is, the threat.

name: Lena Düpont (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the past month has unfortunately made it clear that security is back on the agenda, and it is thus where it needs to be – back on the agenda. That is why I especially thank Vice—President Schinas for his efforts, for the work to come out with a whole set of proposals enhancing the security of our citizens.  These proposals are crucial. They give the right answer to the challenges ahead. We need strong and bold cooperation in Europe to fight terrorism and radicalisation, but also organised crime, money—laundering and child sexual abuse, just to name a few. Vice—President, count on our support for the work ahead of us.  At the same time, we need to assure the work done in past years. What is key for that? It is the willingness of the Member States and implementation, implementation, implementation. It is good to have an understanding between the Member States of who poses a risk to our society, to our European way of life. A common definition in this regard would be better to foster and fasten the exchange of information ahead of the next attack.  It is good to have a set of instruments and data exchange, but making full use of them, as in this case, is key. We need to make sure we have the right data, at the right time, in the right hands, in order to protect our citizens. And, of course, it is good to support the counter—terrorism coordinator, but it is equally important to enable our agencies like Europol with the same aspiration, so that they can fully explore their potential.  So to the Council: support and trust the European added value of closer and bolder cooperation in the area of freedom, security and justice. Only by that can we provide security and the safety we are being asked for.

name: Петър Витанов (S&D).
text: – Mr President, security is a comprehensive issue affecting all walks of life. It is about the health of our children, the protection of personal data, the security of the city and our community.  For 13% of Europeans, terrorism, which is a key issue in the security coordinate system, is a significant threat. It undermines the democratic foundation and targets democratic values. The answer cannot lie solely in the adoption and introduction of chaotic measures and instruments to limit it. The framework of the new strategy is the European Union's contribution to enhancing the security of all of us. The complex of measures must include effective countering polarisation in society, discrimination and all other factors that increase vulnerability to radicalisation. Combating social inequalities that give birth to radicalisation, the food environment for terrorism, effectively countering hybrid attacks that reduce social cohesion, lowering trust in institutions, are also the root causes of security problems.  The strategy must connect all points in a security ecosystem and respond to an ever-changing criminal environment, and with today's erosion of democracy and the decline of the rule of law globally, regaining a sense of security is the most important condition in building trust in society and order.

name: Peter Kofod (ID).
text: Mr President! Safety and security are essential to a society.  You can't build a well-functioning society if people don't feel safe.  Action is needed. Empty talk is not enough. Empty talk has to be said that the EU system has been very deliverable in recent years. When it comes to our safety and security, the European Union has been sleeping for years. For me, security and security at our borders are starting. Precisely because criminal terrorists and troublemakers are crossing borders far more today than they did in the past. It goes without saying that we must, of course, take action at our borders. The European Union has been fighting the efforts that have taken place at our national borders and has tried to deal with the external borders. It's a bad combination. It doesn't work. The Union needs to come together, secure the external borders, allow us to have national border controls and allow us, of course, to send troublemakers, thugs and terrorists back where they come from.

name: Nicola Procaccini (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Schinas, we will shortly have European legislation that reconciles the urgency of combating the spread of terrorist content online with the right to freedom of expression.  This fundamental result bears the mark of the ECR and mr Jaki, the rapporteur for the joint proposal, whom I thank. Unfortunately, one decisive element is missing from this debate and in the joint text we are voting on: the relationship between illegal immigration and the terrorist threat, although many in this House do not support this report, the governments affected by the so-called secondary movements of migrants do not do the same, as President Macron's words following the nice attacks demonstrate.  I would like to point out to you that the closure of internal borders and the simultaneous absurd claim to keep the external borders open represent an unfair distribution of responsibilities between the Member States in the field of immigration, a threat to the security of our fellow citizens and the betrayal of the concept of the European Union.

name: Javier Zarzalejos (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Mr Vice-President, Mr Minister, security is an essential pillar of the contract with citizens. And it is true that today we can only guarantee that commitment if we move towards a Security Union, but at the pace and ambition required to respond to the threats to the freedoms of Europeans.  Mr Vice-President, we are on the right track, as this debate shows, and we must have the impetus to continue to walk through it.  We have identified the challenges: terrorism, which fuels ethnic and religious hatred and amplifies webcasting; organized crime, which expands its activity and has entered the online world; disinformation, as a destabilizing strategy of external and internal actors in the Union; the very risks associated with pressure on our external borders; and, of course, a new online full of challenges.  The perception of security, let us take into account, benefits extremism and fuels the narrative that wants to discredit democratic institutions and the rule of law by presenting them as weak and unable to provide the security and confidence that citizens demand.  We have the instruments. They've been mentioned here. We have to strengthen them. And we must be very aware that this Security Union to which we aspire must start by being that, a union, a closer union that pooles resources, capacities, objectives and strategies on the basis of mutual trust and with the shared purpose of better serving our citizens.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ID).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a total failure on illegal immigration and Islamic terrorism: this is the result achieved by Europe, by the Italian Government PD - 5 stars. You have failed in the fight against illegal immigration, because you have turned Italy into europe's refugee camp. You have failed in the fight against Islamic terrorism because the terrorist who slaughtered three Christians in church in Nice is an illegal immigrant who landed in Italy and arrived in France without controls.  Do you remember Commissioner Gentiloni saying that terrorists do not arrive with boats? Gentiloni and the false left-wing goodies have been disproved by the facts. And don't be happy, you give our money to dictator Erdogan's Turkey, which is arming The Islamic terrorists who strike our cities. Let me tell you: you are crazy and you are bringing Italy and Europe into a ravine. Make a big mea culpa and remember that italians are tired of your chatter.

name: Joachim Stanisław Brudziński (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. We are talking about the security of our citizens, about the security of Europe, and on the opposite side we have criminals, and they are the most dangerous criminals: terrorism, trafficking in human beings, drug trafficking, arms trafficking, child pornography. And on this scale, on the one hand, we have democratic states, and on the opposite side we have ruthless criminals.  Can democratic states be vulnerable? The obvious answer must be no. They cannot be defenseless. They must find the strength and determination to fight crime the most dangerous. And where do we see the threat? Unfortunately, this threat also lies in our countries, because a few weeks ago we talked about the sale of citizenship by some countries, including the most dangerous criminals. We have people smuggling, smuggling, which today brings more revenue than the arms or drug trade. And what? Member States, through, for example, various NGOs, also support these criminals.  We will win this fight if there is coordination, if we work together. The police must not be constrained by political correctness, for example in the fight against Islamic terrorism. Europe cannot be defenceless. We will win this war if we are as ruthless and as determined as the most dangerous criminals.

name: Jorge Buxadé Villalba (ECR).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the European Commission presented a security strategy in Europe last July, presenting a number of priorities, some of which I share: the fight against terrorism, organised crime or Islamist radicalisation.  However, the Commission still does not realize that any security strategy will continue to take if we do not immediately implement legislative measures to immediately expel illegally entering our borders from European territory.  How can the Commission ensure the protection of European citizens when more than one hundred thousand illegal immigrants have already entered Europe this year, forty thousand alone in Spain? I would remind you that two of the Islamist attacks that have shocked Europe the most — the deaths of three Catholics in Nice Cathedral and the beheading of a teacher in France — have been committed by false refugees.  On the other hand, Commissioner, how will measures to combat organised crime be ensured if a new, more effective European order, as well as measures for the recognition of judicial and police decisions, are not immediately implemented? The other day we saw the Belgian courts deny the surrender to Spain of the so-called rapper Valt-nyc, who, in his songs, announced or called for the death of Spanish civilian guards. If this is the strategy of fighting radicalisation, unfortunately we will turn the streets of Europe into a real battlefield.

name: Margaritis Schinas
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I’m very encouraged by this debate, which has shown clearly challenges and different caveats but also confirmed our common determination to work together to enhance our overall level of security, doing this within cohesive societies where our freedoms and values prevail and in full respect of fundamental rights. We have already achieved a lot, but we need to keep up the momentum, and that’s why I would encourage the co-legislators to quickly adopt some of the interesting proposals that are new and are on the table now. I would make particular mention of the need for a quick start to the discussions and work on the revised regulation on Europol. This proposal is essential to give law enforcement authorities better tools to combat organised crime and terrorism, and we need it sooner rather than later. Let me also seize the occasion to advance some of the proposals that we will be presenting next year in the area of security, continuing to build these individual rooms under the single roof of our Security Union Strategy.  Cooperation depends on information, so the exchange of data will be key, and that means engaging with the right authorities and ensuring that the right safeguards are in place, and Eurojust will be an important focus on this. We will also take measures such as an EU agenda to tackle organised crime and new legislation to effectively tackle child sexual abuse online. In the last quarter of next year, we also plan to make proposals to step up work on the freezing and confiscation of the proceeds of crime, as well as on asset recovery. We will continue to work on police cooperation by putting forward an EU Police Cooperation Code, which will be a key measure to modernise existing intra—EU law enforcement cooperation. Your House, this Parliament’s involvement in all this work will be essential and a key element in our success. Let me finish by referring to the various opinions expressed around radicalisation and the link with terrorism. I would like to ask you to take an interest in our proposal, presented together with Commissioner Johansson, on integration and inclusion. This is an action plan with 60 concrete actions that we would like to see implemented so that our societies are able to offer a chance for integration and inclusion to those vulnerable Europeans that very often fall through the cracks of our systems and become the ideal victims or prey to terrorism. Instead of declaring a priori enemies from the terrorist camp, I think we have a better chance if we strike a deal on integration and inclusion and we use the universality of our education systems, housing and health provision to give a sense of belonging to the most vulnerable citizens in society. This would allow us to shield them from the appeal of terrorism. At the same time, this is a two—way street. They would also have an obligation to join and benefit from the success and achievements of our European way of life.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, commissioner, Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for the work he has done on this I would like to thank you all for the debate, because it has once again made it clear that we are developing strategies on a common basis and that I do see a high degree of agreement between the three institutions. Of course, the debate on security for the citizens of Europe is particularly difficult for the Council, because, on the one hand, it is, of course, a question of making the best use of national competences in the interests of the citizens, but on the other hand, there must also be a willingness to significantly expand security cooperation where Europe brings concrete added value.  I am also grateful to the honourable Members who have pointed out a plethora of tests. This is not just about terrorism or drug trafficking, it is about many, many crimes that are serious for people, but which are also a major, big test – especially for our security forces. That is why I agree with everyone that we need to better enable the joint agencies, which we have, to support the Member States in these tasks. I would like to revisit one point, because I had the impression that it was one of the most sensitive, that is the issue of encryption. I would also like to explain the Council's position a little again. Indeed, the resolution on encryption clearly states that the Council wants to ensure that law enforcement and judicial authorities have the same opportunities online to prevent, detect, investigate and prosecute crimes, as well as offline. That is the core principle. Once again, what is illegal offline is and must also be illegal online. Secondly, our law enforcement and judicial authorities must have the same powers, both offline and online. These are the two key points for me, where I see great interfaces between the responsibilities of the Member States and the common tasks that the European Union – and therefore, of course, the Member States – has to face. Once again, thank you very much for the discussion. Thank you also for the appeal to strike a reasonable balance between security on the one hand and freedoms on the other. Respect for fundamental rights and fundamental values plays a prominent role not only for you, but also for the Council. Thank you again for this signal, which I am happy to take with me.

text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the need for a separate Council formation on gender equality (2020/2896(RSP)). I would like to remind you once again that no spontaneous speeches or blue cards are accepted in all the debates. There are also plans to connect from Parliament's liaison offices in the Member States.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, dear Helena, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Helena for the excellent work he has done on this report. Yes, it is probably my last speech i can give today, and also the last speech I can make as a representative of the German EU Presidency, and I would like to thank the European Parliament for the opportunity to speak on this subject, which is a matter of great concern to me.  Gender equality – equality between men and women – is not just an issue for women, but men must be equally committed to this task and to this core principle of a united Europe. And that is why it is not just any minor issue that has a secondary role to play, but it belongs in the policy area, in the core area of our political commitment, whether we are talking about development cooperation or international policy, about crisis management or about health policy. Right now, it has become clear – also in view of the restrictive measures that we have to take in the Member States – that violence against women and domestic violence have increased dramatically. And I know that there is also a call in the European Parliament for a separate Council formation on gender equality and gender equality to be set up. It is not my job as The Presidency to decide on Council formations. This is a decision taken by the Heads of State or Government in the European Council. This must be decided unanimously there.  However, I have also had a good experience of the fact that key issues play a role in all Council formations. I would just like to give you one example: I myself have been the Chairman of the General Affairs Council for almost six months now. Now you will ask yourself: what is the General Affairs Council? What is he actually dealing with? We have dealt not only with Brexit, not only with the rule of law and not only with many fundamental issues such as enlargement, but also with the MFF. And when I think of an initiative in the General Affairs Council, it is to make gender budgeting and gender mainstreaming a central part of our budget. This is an initiative that we discussed in the General Affairs Council. Now it could have been said that only the Ministers for Equal Opportunities should deal with this. But no, the Ministers for Europe, who are responsible for the multiannual financial framework, have also done so. This shows that it can also make sense for everyone to live up to their responsibilities – especially on such a large and important issue. But I am also very open about this, because we are also having this discussion in the Member States. We wonder whether we need our own Ministry of Gender Equality, or whether it is just a question of gender equality or whether we do not need to focus on all issues of equality. Because our commitment to equality does not only apply to men and women, but it must not matter who you believe in, who you love and where you come from and how high or how low your income is. So that too would be an approach that we could certainly take to the fore. I would like to reassure you that the issues of gender equality and gender equality were very important for the Presidency. I have already highlighted the MFF, and I say this somewhat enviously: we have a principle with gender mainstreaming and gender budgeting that does not exist at all in many, many Member States of the European Union, including my own country. In this respect, the European Union is setting standards here too and is a role model and a courageous encourager for many Member States – and I would like to emphasise this positively. However, I would also like to draw particular attention to the important role played by colleagues in the Field of Equal Opportunities Ministers. We alone had two policy debates between the Ministers responsible for Employment and Social Affairs on gender equality. On 13 October, my fellow Members discussed the issue of equal participation of women and men in the labour market. As you know, there are many different approaches and also views on how best to promote equality in the labour market. Possible approaches are measures for the reconciliation of work and private life, awareness-raising or wage transparency. However, there is also a further way of a fairer distribution of unpaid care, care and Housework - that's crucial! On 3 December, just a few weeks ago, we had a second policy debate, particularly in the light of the Commission's strategy for gender equality for the next five years. I would also like to express my thanks to the Commissioner responsible, who is also setting new standards here, which, of course, keep reminding us of what is left to do. And that is far from self-evident, because, particularly in the area of employment and social policy, we are concerned with taking measures that achieve a balanced sharing of paid work and unpaid care work.  And we have identified a number of important points. Firstly, it is not only women but also men who benefit from equality – as I said at the beginning. We need a partnership approach. If only women care about women's issues, then we are not making progress on the issue of equality. We need feminism– I may say this now – as a task for both sexes and not just for women. And i do not want to diminish the commitment – the outstanding, courageous commitment – of women. A second point is important to me: in my general opinion, equality means that every person, whoever he or she is, has the opportunity to fulfil his or her potential, and that equality is beneficial for all citizens and for the economy. The Commission is also appropriately in support of this broad approach. And a third point is important to me: in concrete terms, this consensus is reflected in the agreement that we have reached, to my delight, on the Council's conclusions on 'Combating the gender pay gap: assessing and sharing paid gainful employment and unpaid care, care and housework'. We presented this document as part of the annual review of the implementation of the Beijing Platform for Action. In this respect, there is still a great deal to be done, especially to combat gender stereotypes. And I say this again for the Presidency very, very clearly: gender equality is not a concept of struggle. It is a matter of course for liberal democracies, for liberal societies, and it should also be a matter of course for all three institutions – for the Commission, for Parliament, but also, of course, for the Council – and I was very pleased to have been able to make a small modest contribution to this over the last six months.  Thank you also for the suggestions I have received from this House, particularly on the issue of equality. This has enriched me, inspired me very much and has also made our Presidency a success. It would not have worked without your support. Thank you for that!

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I thank the European Parliament for its call to make gender equality more visible at ministerial level in the Council by setting up a dedicated Council for this policy area. I welcome the commitment that this House systematically provides to equality measures. With regard to the issue of today’s discussion, it is not the intention of the Commission to interfere with matters which are purely internal to other EU institutions. It is for the Council to agree on the need to have a new or different Council configuration. Of course I agree that political debates by ministers as co-legislators are essential to achieve our goals. For instance, ministerial debates allowed for the swift adoption of the work-life balance directive. As a Commission, we have always encouraged presidencies to hold such debates. As we heard earlier from Minister Roth, we saw this happening during this Presidency. We need ministerial debates to advance on core equality issues.

name: Frances Fitzgerald
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, a dedicated Council configuration is essential if we are to prioritise gender equality and of course we need to continue to mainstream the issue, and as Commissioner Dalli says, to have these ministerial discussions. We need greater political prioritisation and political powers to robustly and comprehensively tackle the challenges. We already have such fora in the Parliament and the Commission — it is crucial to have a counterpart in the Council.  Top level political leadership across the Member States is now essential on gender equality. The time for prevarication is over. Women have waited too long. Women can’t wait another 60 years and women and men of our younger generation cannot wait a further 60 years. Issues of equality are often dealt with in the Justice and Home Affairs Council and, as a Minister for Justice, I worked in that Council and gender equality rarely appears on the agenda due to the long list of priorities and competences that fall into the JHA.  To make sure that these priorities are driven forward, a dedicated Council configuration is an imperative, I believe, allowing equality ministers to meet on an ongoing basis, facilitating the discussion, and adaptation of key initiatives and to invest time in that all-important best practice sharing, what the EU is known for and utilises as one of its great strengths. The question of gender equality has been at the heart of the COVID-19 pandemic. Domestic violence, childcare pressures, accessing health care — these issues have not been resolved but exacerbated by the current crisis. I would say we still have 60% to 70% of the decisions in politics, in business, in finance and in AI technology being taken by one gender. Why? We need to act strongly. I ask the Council and the Portuguese Presidency to take on board this request of the Parliament, to take it seriously, to ensure that gender equality is at the heart of the European project and of the European institutions. Let that mark and let that be the achievement of the Portuguese Presidency.

name: Heléne Fritzon
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. – Madam President, Commissioner and President, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent One of my grandchildren is a six-year-old girl. If we continue at the same pace, europe will not achieve equality until she is 66 years old. Perhaps my grandson will receive an equal pension, but before that she will have fewer opportunities in the labour market, be paid less than her male colleagues and be more likely to be subjected to violence. We cannot accept this! It can't take 60 years! Equality and equality must be up to the highest political level. It requires its own Council of Ministers for the ministers responsible for these matters, just as in the Commission and in Parliament. I want my grandson to grow up in a Europe and a Europe that ensures that all children at her school have equal opportunities in their lives.

name: Irène Tolleret
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, only six months ago, at 8 p.m., we all applauded our first line, 87% female: those carers, cashiers, cleaners who allowed us to live.  Today, no one applauds at 8 p.m., no one dares to talk about the world after, too aware that the world of "during" will last. Simone de Beauvoir predicted as early as 1949 that an economic crisis would be enough for women's rights to be called into question. We are there: 75% of the job losses are female, domestic violence has tripled, not to mention the mental burden of confinement, telework and school closures. And we are even witnessing a decline in abortion rights in our Union.  Is Europe up to the task? The answer is no. The European Union has not yet ratified the Istanbul Convention, the directive on the presence of women on boards has been blocked in the Council for seven years, the directive on pay transparency has been postponed. Parliament is not left behind: this is the third time that we have betrayed our own resolution on gender equality in the appointments of economic and monetary affairs.  It is time to make equality a central point on the Union's political agenda. That is why we are calling for the creation of a gender equality council. This small step for the Council is a big step for equality. We owe it to our mothers, our daughters and all the strangers on the front line, whom I propose to applaud again.

name: Nicolaus Fest
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her You will be pleased: I am speaking to you today as a woman. When shaving, I was looking to change gender and extend the shave to your legs – you have to stay flexible. If gender, as gender activists claim, is a mere social construct, then the demand for equality is in itself a contradiction. Because you don't have to be treated on a gender basis, you can just do it.  Dear women, lesbians, transsexuals or whatever: just become men or whatever you want. You can decide for yourself - make it easy. Then, according to your own ideology, all gender issues are resolved immediately. Since they have been resolved, there is no need for a permanent forum of the Council for Equality. We have an EU Commission for Gender Equality, a Committee on Gender Equality, an Institute for Gender Equality, and we already have informal meetings on equality at Council level. In times of gender, it doesn't take any of it, because everyone can equate themselves – so make it easy. Then you also have time to deal with the really important problems of the people in The Corona times and not with this stus.
