name: Alice Kuhnke
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Equality and equality are, according to the Treaties, core values of the European Union. That's what we're going to stand for. That's what we're going to defend. At the same time, we know that there is an organised fight against human rights in the EU. Across Europe, threats, harassment and discrimination against LGBTQI people are on the increase. People on the run are painted as enemies of society. Racism and discrimination are spreading like wildfire. Every day – yes, every day – seven women in europe lose their lives because of men's violence in their homes. Black and white, in area after area, it goes in the wrong direction. Structural problems require structural solutions. Just as there is a Council of Ministers meeting on issues such as environmental issues, there needs to be a council for equality and equality. Only if we have structured cooperation for equality and equality at the highest European level can we bring about concrete changes.  Let me repeat my introductory words: equality and equality are core values of the European Union. It is time for Europe to move from fine words to action.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Once again, we find ourself in a situation where Parliament is attempting to extend its powers against the Treaties. Once again, representatives of the left-wing mainstream are pushing their political agenda. Contrary to this rhetoric, the lack of a dedicated body for equality in the Council does not mean a lack of commitment and appropriate action. Equality between women and men is a fundamental principle of the Union, so the Council is obliged to respect it. The Council must not be subject to political pressure, should be independent and free to decide on its organisational structure. And as a woman, I would like to say that our actions are concrete, so I would recommend that today we consider how many women among the European Parliament's catering staff who have been made redundant since the first of January are losing their jobs. You on the left will be admonished for the rights of women who lose their jobs in a pandemic here in the European Parliament. Finally, take care of the real problems.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, how would you react if a female Member earned less than a male MEMBER, or if a female Commissioner earned less than a male Commissioner? I am sure you would be amazed at this unequal treatment, yet that is exactly what is happening in Europe today. European women earn 16 % less than men, while the unemployment rate for women is much higher than that of men by around 10 %.  55 % of women have experienced one or more forms of sexual harassment and on average one woman dies every two and a half days as a result of domestic violence. The actions taken so far have not had the desired effects, which we had hoped for, because at this rate it will take more than sixty years to really achieve gender equality in Europe.  I therefore appeal to you, Commissioner Dalli, and to President von der Leyen, who has shown herself to be particularly sensitive to this issue of gender inequality, to help us achieve full equality, so that we can move our Europe forward, because, as Karl Marx said, social progress is measured by the social position of the fair sex.

name: Eugenia Rodríguez Palop
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, it is tremendous to have to verbalize in the 21st century that women have not achieved equality; that, if we continue at this rate, we will have to wait 84 more years just to collect the same as a male for the same job; that we have not ratified the Istanbul Convention and do not have the Directive on gender-based violence that we so desire to have; that the Equality Directive has been stopping for years in the European Union; and, worst of all, that we cannot ensure that the few progress made will be sustained over time.  We need institutions committed to women, strong, coherent and effective responses to the far right and religious and conservative groups, which use the argument of gender ideology to violate the rights we have been fighting for centuries.  Either the Council commits and assumes a coordinated strategy, or we will be the shameful generation that lived better than its mothers and daughters. Because we're going to condemn them to the twentieth century. That is why there has to be a configuration in the Council on equality which summons the ministers and secretaries of state in the field, as is the case in other areas.  It's a moment of frontier. It is the moment when feminism is on the streets and in institutions, but also misogyny is the streets and institutions. So it's time to act. It takes, however, to believe it, political will to show that the statements with which our mouths are filled are not empty words. The tools are there. Use them, use them at once.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it seems that fish are sometimes taken more seriously by the Council than women, at least institutionally, since there is a Council formation for fish but none for gender equality and not even on discrimination or diversity. Yet it has become ever so clear in the current crisis that we need gender equality and diversity, and we need it now. In the shadows of our society, another pandemic has been creeping on women for centuries: violence, the gender pay gap and so on. Diversity is one of our biggest assets as a community, and gender equality is one of our founding values. I am sure a dedicated Council formation would advance gender equality and all intersectional issues related like anti-racism, LGBTIQ rights and so much more. Let’s make sure that the European Council is an institution that has arrived in the 21st century.

name: Karen Melchior (Renew).
text: Madam. President! My period started today. I am among the approximately 26 percent of the world's population, which menstruates 2 to 7 days a month. If you don't know what to do with that information, don't worry, the pharmaceutical industry, science, and app developers mostly don't. Menstruation or women at large are too difficult to think about in the development of medications or apps. Despite the fact that it can be crucial to the work of the medicine, despite the fact that we are 26 percent of the world's population.  Women are many things besides being women. It doesn't make us any less women. Black women are black and women. Women with disabilities have a disability and they are women. Lesbian women are lesbians and women. Roma women are Roma and women. Muslim women are Muslim and women. Trans women are trans and women. Trans women are women. It gives us different experiences. This means that society sees us and treats us differently. But we're still all women. For too long, women have been made invisible and forgotten. The history books forget us. The pharmaceutical industry forgets us. Trouser pocket producers forget us. Well, but that our governments in the European Union forget us, despite the fact that almost all EU governments have an equal minister – no, surely? Black women, Roma women, Muslim women, trans women - we are all women. We demand that our governments remember women. We demand that they turn good intentions into action. So fuck the patriarchy!

name: Pierrette Herzberger-Fofana (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this month we are celebrating Marie Popelin, or rather the Popelin case. On 12 December 1888, the Brussels Court of Appeal denied women access to the legal professions. Marie Popelin, a feminist icon from Belgium, has paved the way for women to become judges. She fought for equal opportunities.  I hope that, in its wake, we will continue to fight against gender inequalities and other discrimination. We need to integrate women and recognize their skills in our institutions, including women from minorities. This strong signal is all the more important because there are still deep structural inequalities in our society.  The lack of diversity within the institutions is a good example of the fact that we still have work to do. The Council has an important role to play in this fight. That is why we hope that he will accept our request, that of creating a specific council on gender equality, so that we can finally adopt concrete measures in the fight against gender inequalities. It is time for more women to move into decision-making positions. In this way, we can build a more resilient Europe and achieve equal opportunities for men and women.

name: Margarita de la Pisa Carrión (ECR).
text: – Madam President, it is unusual how we want to be imposed by institutional means on ideas, occurrences without any scientific basis, that attack common sense and which can only fail because they go against nature.  Yes, in fact, you recognize it. Despite their efforts, despite forming ministries, commissions or councils dedicated to gender ideology, they fail to advance their results, although I sense that even you do not know where you want to go. They intend to manipulate, to confuse, so that people cannot give full meaning to their lives.  For you, women are a cultural product that you can build or deconstruct by social engineering. But no, we are not puppets who can be directed into their dark interests. Today's woman does not feel identified with these new gender roles that they are trying to impose on us.  There is no common feeling to support this madness. Listen to people's longings. Let us respect our identity; let's shed femininity, motherhood... All civilizations have done it. Focus on managing real problems and let people be people, not products of your imagination.

name: Laura Ferrara (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, putting gender equality at the top of the European Union's political agenda is even more necessary today. The pandemic has exacerbated existing inequalities and discrimination concerning the situation of women in the field of work, pay and in different areas of social life. Economic recovery and sustainable and inclusive development cannot ignore the strengthening of women's rights, their greater presence in decision-making and political processes, equal opportunities and treatment, the fight against all forms of physical and moral violence, the safeguarding of sexual and reproductive health and rights.  If equality between women and men is to be pursued as the founding value of the European Union, the adaptation of the Council's institutional architecture could contribute to this.  It is therefore hoped that we will soon see a Council formation dedicated to gender equality, capable of preparing measures and better addressing the challenges to be faced against all inequalities.

name: Maria da Graça Carvalho (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the European People's Party, I am very proud to see the political groups united on a subject which I consider vital to improving gender equality policies in Europe. It is not conceived that in 2020 there will be no ministerial, formal and institutional configuration at council level of ministers to ensure that representatives of the Member States meet regularly to discuss, legislate, take political decisions and exchange best practices in these areas. I am convinced that specific Council training on gender equality would be a key element in unlocking negotiations on the main dossiers on the subject, including the ratification of the Istanbul Convention and the unlocking of the Women's Directive on boards. If we want a progressive Europe, facing people and the 19th century. XXI, we must abandon the paternalistic clichés that these are less noble matters, relegated to a second row of JAI Councils. I therefore urge the Council to set up training as soon as possible to facilitate gender mainstreaming in all policies and all EU legislation.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for I will ask you: Are women victims of domestic, sexual and financial violence in the Countries of the European Union today? The answer is yes. Are there politicians who want to limit the role of women to giving birth, childcare, home? So. Do women in equal positions, especially in managerial positions, often earn less than men? The answer is yes. Are there governments in the European Union where there is a great gender imbalance, not to say: where is women as a cure? So. Under the guise of fighting ideology, are any initiatives aimed at levelling the playing field and protecting the gender that is discriminated against negated? So. Are some countries planning to denounce or oppose the ratification of the Istanbul Convention in order to maintain the patriarchal model of the family? The answer is yes. Are stereotypes doing well in Europe? Yes, of course. Are directives which refer to gender equality in their provisions blocked by certain members of the Council? So. Is it therefore necessary to create a separate composition of the Council on gender equality? Absolutely yes. And I hope that thanks to her action in a while we will get an answer to the questions I posed: no!

name: Marc Angel (S&D).
text: – Madam President, a dedicated Council configuration on gender equality and equality was never more needed than today. The COVID—19 crisis has shown us again that too many inequalities exist between women and men. Too much discrimination subsists for, amongst others, people with disabilities, people of colour and LGBTI persons. The most vulnerable people are often victims of intersectional discrimination. So let me also clearly also state that gender is not an ideology, as the very right—wing benches of this hemicycle always want to make us believe. No, it is about identity.  The S&D Group will stand against those who want to ban this word in European documents, and the same goes for intersectionality. Yes, multiple discrimination also exists in our Union, and we Socialists and Democrats appreciate that Commissioner Dalli insists that all equality strategies and policies from the Commission must talk to each other.   Gender equality, diversity and equality must be a horizontal task and concern all policy fields. Yes, that is true, and therefore I believe that a dedicated Council formation will be a motor, will highlight the importance of this and make sure equality and gender equality is mainstreamed in all EU policies to make our societies move away from patriarchy and become more equal and fair. (Applause)

name: Chrysoula Zacharopoulou (Renew).
text: Madam Commissioner, 2020 will go down in history, marked by an unprecedented health crisis. Women and men are on the front line, we thank them. The European Union has also surpassed itself: the birth of the Europe of health, the first climate law, a historic recovery plan. But we also have another duty to the next generations: to ensure gender equality in the 27 countries.  Commissioner, we share your ambitious political agenda for women's rights and gender equality. But all Member States, good and bad, must now commit.  Let us work together, learn the best of everyone: that is the spirit of the Simone Veil pact that we carry. That is the spirit of the European Union. In 2021, let us have the courage to build this council on an equal footing. We here have it. The Council must have it as well.

name: Hannah Neumann (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I’m just sick and tired of this debate, because gender equality is one of our fundamental values – but in some sectors we are at the moment even moving backwards. In national parliaments across the EU, gender equality would take an average of 60 – six zero – years if you continue at the current speed. I will be dead by then, my children will be retired and we would have lost another two generations, and that is why we really need to get things moving. But Member States, and even those praising themselves for being very progressive, block major steps ahead, and yes, the German Government is part of this, with the Gender Balance on Boards Directive, for example. And that’s why it’s time for us to have this Council configuration, to ensure that we finally get gender mainstreaming across all sectors in all EU Member States. Dear colleagues, gender equality is not the cherry on top of the cake. It’s the cake. (Applause)

name: Gwendoline Delbos-Corfield (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, in 2020, in this European Union, in a country, the right to abortion almost no longer exists. In other Member States, the differences between women and men are still institutionalised. And in general, in all our countries, the inequalities between women and men are still immense. When these women living in Europe are immigrants, children of immigrants, considered immigrants, when they do not have white skin, when they are not heterosexual, when they do not have the right religion, when they are disabled, when they are poor, when they are fragile, then they suffer even more inequality, injustice and discrimination. Formally bringing ministers together in training on gender equality would be a way to give real importance to these issues of inequality and to treat them with the importance they deserve - as much as trade, industrial, financial, economic and environmental issues. If we add the intersectional approach, then perhaps we will really give ourselves the means to act on these issues.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, in a context where gender has become a controversial word, and in a context where women are disproportionately affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, and when minorities have had similar experiences, it is important that equality and gender equality are on the Council’s agenda. So I thank the European Parliament for having organised this debate. Informal Council meetings of ministers in charge of gender equality are a good start – but only a start. As was said earlier, gender equality is not the cherry on the cake, but it’s the cake. So we need a formal setting for these meetings. On 3 December, the EPSCO Council agenda had several equality files as A or B points, that is the Council recommendation on Roma equality inclusion and participation, the European Disability Rights strategy, the proposal for a directive on equal treatment, and the LGBTIQ equality strategy. In addition, EPSCO also had a debate on the gender equality strategy. Nonetheless, EPSCO is the Council for Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumer Affairs. So having a Council formation with gender equality or equality in its name would certainly be an important step in our endeavour towards truly achieving a union of equality.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done on this report. Thank you once again for having the opportunity to take part in this discussion. And we have also seen how important it is – and indeed only in one speech – because gender equality is still the subject of a fierce political debate in Europe. There are people – and politicians – who think they can make a mark at the expense of minorities, women and the weaker. They ridicule them, they make them contemptuous. At least I have understood our debate today in such a way that we stand together– no matter what our position is on a separate formation for equality in the Council. I respect your view because there are good arguments in favour of your proposal. However, I would like to promote once again that the issue of equality should not only be focused on the issue of gender equality, but should be taken by a broader approach. And I am campaigning for it to be worthwhile, honourable Members, if economic ministers, finance ministers, social ministers, ministers of education, ministers of education and ministers must also deal with the issues of equality. It is a subject that covers all areas of life. I hope that the subsequent Presidencies of the Council will also make good use of the necessary exchanges of ministers for equality. We have done so as the German Presidency of the Council, and we hope that the subsequent presidencies will be able to continue to do so. These are not just conversations. I would like to remind you of a very specific initiative which has still not been implemented. In the face of a massive increase in domestic violence against women and children, The Ministers for Equal Opportunities have called for a Europe-wide number number for victims of domestic violence. This initiative has not yet been implemented. That, too, would be something we might want to tackle in the coming weeks and months. Since you mentioned the Istanbul Convention – which is very close to my heart – I would also like to reiterate, very frustrated, that so far only 21 Member States of the European Union have ratified the Istanbul Convention. And now that I have the pleasure of chairing the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe, I would like to say to you that one of our priorities will be to promote the Istanbul Convention. Not that states are leaving, but on the contrary: that more states are committed to the Istanbul Convention because it includes rights that protect women and children – people – from domestic violence. Thank you for this commitment - I wish you all the best. I have a word on my speech paper, and I do not like that at all: it says that equality policy needs patience. So I think this sentence is completely wrong. Equality policy needs vigilance, determination, courage and fighting spirit, and you have shown that time and again. Thank you for that.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: In accordance with Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure, two motions for resolutions have been tabled*. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 17 December 2020. Written statements (Article 171) --------- * See Minutes.

name: Christine Anderson (ID)
text: Writing. – Men and women are already on an equal footing under the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and the EU Treaties. Women are entitled to equal pay for equal work and equal access to education and career sanity, according to the case law of the ECJ. If there is no gender parity in some sectors, such as science or care, this is due to the professional interests and preferences of the respective sex. We reject a move away from attitudes towards suitability towards gender recruitment through rigid quota rules. We also reject the promotion and application of a gender ideology with more than two natural sexes up to more than 60 'social sexes'. I shall therefore vote against this point.

name: Έλενα Κουντουρά (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – There is no doubt that the impact of the pandemic has been disproportionately harsh on women, not only because it has revealed the existing structural inequalities, but also because it has exacerbated them. According to EIGE, at the current rate it will take 60 years to achieve full equality in the EU. We neither want nor can accept that we will wait another 60 years to integrate the gender dimension into all EU policies. For this reason, these issues must be dealt with at the highest political level. I am very pleased and I think it is a great success that the resolution calls for 'the creation of a special composition of the Council where ministers will meet on gender equality', which I personally have been fighting for since April, both with targeted amendments that I have tabled and have already been adopted by the plenary of the European Parliament, and with my speeches to the FEMM Committee. We will therefore be able to discuss and unsblemble important dossiers on gender equality, such as the Istanbul Convention against Gender Violence, the Women on Boards Directive, and the Anti-Discrimination Directive. Only in this way will we be able to convince European citizens that gender equality remains a fundamental objective of the EU.

name: Christine Schneider (PPE)
text: Writing. – Equality must be a cross-cutting issue in all policy areas. For this we need greater political prioritisation. In Parliament and in the Commission, we already have a forum to address gender equality. I therefore support the call for the Portuguese Presidency to promote an appropriate Council formation, so that exchanges on this important issue become more visible and to make progress on key issues of equality.
